original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Khuddakanikāye
analyzed: khuddaka nikāye
translated: In the Khuddakanikāya

original: Theragāthā-aṭṭhakathā
analyzed: thera gāthā aṭṭhakathā
translated: The Commentary on the Elders’ Verses🔽(First part)

original: (Paṭhamo bhāgo)🔽Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ  gantha ārambha kathā
translated: The Introduction

original: Mahākāruṇikaṃ nāthaṃ, ñeyyasāgarapāraguṃ;
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikam nātham ñeyya sāgara pāragum
translated: The one of great compassion, the protector, who has gone to the far shore of the ocean of what is to be known,

original: Vande nipuṇagambhīra-vicitranayadesanaṃ.
analyzed: vande nipuṇa gambhīra vicitra naya desanam
translated: I praise the one who teaches with skillful, profound, and varied methods.

analyzed: vijjā ācaraṇa sampannāḥ yena niyyanti lokataḥ
translated: The one who, having perfected knowledge and conduct, goes beyond the world,

analyzed: vande tam uttamam dhammam sammāsambuddha pūjitam  sīla ādi guṇa sampannaḥ ṭhitaḥ magga phalesu yaḥ  vande ariya saṅgham tam puñña kkhettam anuttaram
translated: I praise that supreme Dhamma, revered by the Perfectly Awakened One.🔽The one endowed with the qualities of virtue and so on, who abides in the fruits and paths,🔽I praise that noble Sangha, the unsurpassed field of merit.

original: Vandanājanitaṃ puññaṃ, iti yaṃ ratanattaye;
analyzed: vandanā janitam puññam iti yam rata nattaye
translated: The merit generated by this praise, in regard to the Three Jewels,

analyzed: hata antarāyaḥ sabbattha hutvā aham tassa tejasā  yā tā subhūti ādīhi kata kiccehi
translated: May I, with that power, be free from obstacles in all things.🔽Those verses spoken by the elders such as Subhūti, who have accomplished their task,

original: Therehi bhāsitā gāthā, therīhi ca nirāmisā.🔽Udānanādavidhinā, gambhīrā nipuṇā subhā;
analyzed: therehi bhāsitā gāthā therīhi ca nirāmisā  udāna nāda vidhinā gambhīrā nipuṇā subhā
translated: And by the elder nuns, free from worldly concerns,🔽With the method of uplifting exclamations, profound, skillful, and beautiful,

original: Suññatāpaṭisaṃyuttā, ariyadhammappakāsikā.
analyzed: suñña tā paṭisaṃyuttā ariya dhamma ppakāsikā
translated: Connected with emptiness, revealing the noble Dhamma,

original: Theragāthāti nāmena, therīgāthāti tādino;
analyzed: theragāthā ati nāmena therīgāthā ati tādinaḥ

analyzed: yā khuddaka nikāyamhi saṅgāyiṃsu mahā esayo
translated: Which the great seers compiled In the Khuddaka-Nikāya,

original: Tāsaṃ gambhīrañāṇehi, ogāhetabbabhāvato;
analyzed: tāsam gambhīra ñāṇehi ogāhetabba bhāvato
translated: Because they can be entered into By those of profound knowledge,

original: Kiñcāpi dukkarā kātuṃ, atthasaṃvaṇṇanā mayā.🔽Sahasaṃvaṇṇanaṃ yasmā, dharate satthu sāsanaṃ;
analyzed: kiñca api dukkarā kātum attha saṃvaṇṇanā mayā  saha saṃvaṇṇanam yasmai dharate satthu sāsanam
translated: And although it is difficult for me to do, I shall expound the meaning.🔽Because the Teacher’s Dispensation is upheld By the simultaneous explanation,

original: Pubbācariyasīhānaṃ, tiṭṭhateva vinicchayo.🔽Tasmā taṃ avalambitvā, ogāhetvāna pañcapi;
analyzed: pubba ācariya sīhānam tiṭṭhatā iva vinicchayaḥ  tasmā tam avalambitvā

analyzed: su visuddham asaṃkiṇṇam nipuṇa attha vinicchayam

original: Tāsaṃ tañca vibhāvento, dīpayanto vinicchayaṃ.
analyzed: tāsam tat ca vibhāventaḥ dīpayantaḥ vinicchayam
translated: I shall expound the meaning, and illuminate The verdict, distinguishing them.

original: Yathābalaṃ karissāmi, atthasaṃvaṇṇanaṃ subhaṃ;
analyzed: yathābalam karissāmi attha saṃvaṇṇanam subham
translated: I shall expound the meaning well, according to my ability,

original: Sakkaccaṃ theragāthānaṃ, therīgāthānameva ca.
analyzed: sakkaccam thera gāthānam therī gāthānam eva ca
translated: Of the Elders’ Verses and the Elders’ Verses of the Nuns.

original: Iti ākaṅkhamānassa, saddhammassa ciraṭṭhitiṃ;
analyzed: iti ākaṅkhamānassa saddhammassa ciraṭṭhitim
translated: Thus, those who desire the long-endurance Of the True Dhamma,

analyzed: tad attham vibhajantassa nisāmayatha sādhavaḥ ti
translated: Should listen attentively while I explain the meaning.”

analyzed: kā pana itā thera gāthā therī gāthā ca katham ca pavattā ati kāmañca ayam atthaḥ gāthāsu vuttaḥ yā iva
translated: What are these verses of the elders and verses of the elder nuns? And how did they come about? —Well, this matter is stated in the verses themselves.

analyzed: pākaṭa karaṇa attham pana puna api vuccate tattha thera gāthā tāva subhūti thera ādīhi

analyzed: buddhataḥ dve sahassāni bhikkhutaḥ
translated: “I have learned from the Buddha eighty-two thousand dhammas, from the bhikkhus two thousand,

translated: and eighty-four thousand dhammas have occurred to me.”

analyzed: ekā therī aṭṭhacattālīsa gāthā mahā nipāte pi ekā therī pañca sattati gāthā evam ettha
translated: there is one Therī, and there are forty-eight verses. In the Great Nidāna there is one Therī, and there are seventy-five verses. Thus

original: nipātānaṃ gāthāvaggānaṃ gāthānañca parimāṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nipātānam gāthā vaggānam gāthānam ca parimāṇam veditabbam
translated: the extent of the Nidānas, the extent of the Verses, and the extent of the Therīs should be understood.

original: Nidānagāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: nidāna gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the Nidāna Verses

original: Evaṃ paricchinnaparimāṇāsu panetāsu theragāthā ādi. Tatthāpi –
analyzed: evam paricchinna parimāṇāsu theragāthā
translated: In these verses, which have been thus defined in extent, the Verses of the Elders begins. Herein,

original: “Sīhānaṃva nadantānaṃ, dāṭhīnaṃ girigabbhare;
analyzed: sīhānam va nadantānam dāṭhīnam giri gabbhare
translated: “As lions roar in mountain caves, so do these who are developed

original: Suṇātha bhāvitattānaṃ, gāthā atthūpanāyikā”ti.
analyzed: suṇātha bhāvita ttānam gāthāḥ atthu upanāyikā iti
translated: Listen to the verses which are the means of understanding the meaning.”

original: Ayaṃ paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikāle āyasmatā ānandena tesaṃ therānaṃ thomanatthaṃ bhāsitā
analyzed: ayam paṭhama mahā saṅgīti kāle āyasmatā ānandena tesam therānam thomana attham bhāsitā
translated: This verse was spoken by the venerable Ānanda at the time of the First Great Rehearsal in order to encourage those Elders.

original: gāthā ādi. Tattha sīhānanti sīhasaddo “sīho, bhikkhave, migarājā”tiādīsu migarāje
analyzed: gāthā ādi tattha sīhānanti sīha saddaḥ sīhaḥ bhikkhave migarājā ati ādīsu migarāje
translated: Herein, “lions” is the lion’s roar in such passages as “The lion, monks, is the king of beasts” .

original: āgato. “Atha kho sīho senāpati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamī”tiādīsu paññattiyaṃ. “Sīhoti
analyzed: āgataḥ atha kho sīhaḥ senāpati yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami iti ādīsu paññattiyam sīha oti
translated: “Sīha the general approached the Fortunate One” and so on, in the description.

original: kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā”tiādīsu tathāgate.
analyzed: kho bhikkhave tathāgatassa itam adhivacanam arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati ādīsu tathāgate
translated: “Then the general Sīha went to the Blessed One” , in a description. “‘Sīha’ , bhikkhus, is a designation for the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One” , in a Tathāgata.🔽Herein, just as it is in the Tathāgata by way of the assumption of similarity, so it is here too.

original: Tattha yathā tathāgate sadisakappanāya āgato, evaṃ idhāpi sadisakappanāvaseneva veditabbo,
analyzed: tattha yathā tathāgate sadisa kappanāya āgataḥ evam idha api sadisa kappanā vasena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: Therefore it should be understood by way of the assumption of similarity.

original: tasmā sīhānaṃvāti sīhānaṃ iva. Sandhivasena saralopo “evaṃsa te”tiādīsu viya. Tattha
analyzed: sīhānam vāti sīhānam iva sandhi vasena sara lopaḥ evam sa teti ādīsu tattha
translated: Therefore it is like the lions’ , like the lions’. The sandhi-change -a- for -o- is by the rule of “evaṃsa te” , etc. Herein,

original: ivāti nipātapadaṃ. Suṇāthāti ākhyātapadaṃ. Itarāni nāmapadāni. Sīhānaṃvāti ca sambandhe
analyzed: iva ati nipāta padam suṇātha ati ākhyāta padam itarāni nāma padāni ca sambandhe
translated: like is a particle. Listen is a verbal noun. The rest are nouns. Like the lions’ is a possessive indication.

original: sāmivacanaṃ. Kāmañcettha sambandhī sarūpato na vutto, atthato pana vuttova hoti.🔽Yathā hi “oṭṭhasseva mukhaṃ etassā”ti vutte oṭṭhassa mukhaṃ viya mukhaṃ etassāti
analyzed: sāmi vacanam kāmam ca ittha sambandhī sarūpataḥ na vuttaḥ atthato pana vuttaḥ eva hoti  yathā hi oṭṭhassa iva mukham etassa ati vutte oṭṭhassa mukham viya mukham etassa ati
translated: Although the related object is not stated in the same form, still the meaning is stated.🔽For just as when it is said “This has a face like a lion’s” , the meaning “This has a face like a lion’s face” is stated,

original: ayamattho vutto eva hoti, evamidhāpi “sīhānaṃvā”ti vutte sīhānaṃ nādo viyāti ayamattho
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ vuttaḥ eva hoti evam idha api sīhānam vā iti vutte sīhānam nādaḥ viya ati ayam atthaḥ
translated: so too, when it is said “like the lions’ ” , the meaning “like the lions’ roar” is stated.

original: vutto eva hoti. Tattha mukhasaddasannidhānaṃ hotīti ce, idhāpi “nadantāna”nti padasannidhānato,
analyzed: vuttaḥ eva hoti tattha mukha sadda sannidhānam hoti iti ce idha api pada sannidhānato
translated: If it be said that there is proximity of the word “mouth” here, there is proximity of the word “roaring” here too.

original: tasmā sīhānaṃvāti nidassanavacanaṃ. Nadantānanti tassa nidassitabbena sambandhadassanaṃ.🔽Dāṭhīnanti tabbisesanaṃ. Girigabbhareti tassa pavattiṭṭhānadassanaṃ. Suṇāthāti savane
analyzed: tasmā nidassana vacanam tassa nidassitabbena sambandha dassanam  tad bisesanam giri gabbharā iti tassa pavatti ṭṭhāna dassanam suṇātha ati savane
translated: Therefore the phrase “of lions” is a demonstrative expression. “Roaring” shows the connection with what is to be demonstrated.🔽“Tuskers” is a specification of that. “In mountain caves” shows the place of their occurrence. “Listen” is the injunction to listen.

original: niyojanaṃ. Bhāvitattānanti sotabbassa pabhavadassanaṃ. Gāthāti sotabbavatthudassanaṃ.
analyzed: niyojanam sotabbassa pabhava dassanam gāthā ati sotabba vatthu dassanam
translated: “Who have developed” shows the source of what is to be heard. “Verses” shows the subject to be heard.🔽“Which are the guides to the good” is a specification of that.

original: Atthupanāyikāti tabbisesanaṃ. Kāmañcettha “sīhānaṃ nadantānaṃ dāṭhīna”nti pulliṅgavasena
analyzed: atthupanāyikā iti tad visesanam kāmam ca ittha sīhānam nadantānam dāṭhīnam ti pulliṅga vasena
translated: Although here “of lions roaring” is given in the masculine gender,

original: āgataṃ, liṅgaṃ pana parivattetvā “sīhīna”ntiādinā itthiliṅgavasenāpi attho veditabbo.🔽Ekasesavasena vā sīhā ca sīhiyo ca sīhā, tesaṃ sīhānantiādinā sādhāraṇā hetā tisso
analyzed: āgatam liṅgam pana parivattetvā sīhīnanti ādinā itthi liṅga vasena api atthaḥ veditabbo  ekasesa vasena vā sīhā ca sīhiyaḥ ca sīhā tesam sīha ananti ādinā sādhāraṇāḥ tissaḥ
translated: the meaning should be understood also in the feminine gender by changing the gender, as in “of lionesses” .🔽Or else, by the method of the collective singular, “lions” is a collective term for both male and female lions, and “of those lions” is a collective genitive.

original: nidānagāthā theragāthānaṃ therīgāthānañcāti.
analyzed: nidāna gāthā thera gāthānam therī gāthānam ca ati
translated: These three introductory verses are common to the Theragāthā and the Therīgāthā.

original: Tattha sahanato hananato ca sīho. Yathā hi sīhassa migarañño balavisesayogato sarabhamigamattavaravāraṇāditopi🔽parissayo nāma natthi, vātātapādiparissayampi so sahatiyeva, gocarāya pakkamantopi
analyzed: tattha sahanataḥ hananataḥ ca sīhaḥ yathā hi sīhassa miga raññaḥ bala visesa yogataḥ sarabha miga matta vara vāraṇa āditaḥ pi  parissayaḥ nāma natthi vāta ātapa ādi parissayam pi so sahatiyā iva gocarāya pakkamantaḥ pi
translated: Herein, they are “lions” because of their endurance and their slaying. For just as a lion, king of beasts, has no fear of any animal, such as a wild buffalo, a mighty tusker, etc., because he is endowed with strength and special qualities,🔽and he endures even the discomfort of wind and sun, and when he goes out to his pasture,

original: tejussadatāya mattagandhahatthivanamahiṃsādike samāgantvā abhīrū achambhī abhibhavati,
analyzed: tejuḥ sadatāya matta gandha hatthi vanam ahiṃsā ādike samāgantvā abhīrū a chambhī abhibhavati
translated: he overpowers with his own might any such creatures as a forest elephant, a wild ox, a gayal, etc., that come against him,

original: abhibhavanto ca te aññadatthu hantvā tattha mudumaṃsāni bhakkhayitvā sukheneva viharati,
analyzed: abhibhavanto ca te aññadatthu hantvā tattha mudu maṃsāni bhakkhayitvā sukhena iva viharati
translated: and when he has overpowered them, he kills them and eats their tender flesh and so lives happily,

original: evametepi mahātherā ariyabalavisesayogena sabbesampi parissayānaṃ sahanato, rāgādisaṃkilesabalassa
analyzed: evam ete api mahā therāḥ ariya bala visesa yogena sabbesam pi parissayānam sahanataḥ rāga ādi saṃkilesa balassa
translated: so too these Great Elders, because of their endurance of all discomforts and their slaying of the strength of the defilements such as lust, etc.,

original: abhibhavitvā hananato pajahanato tejussadabhāvena kutocipi abhīrū achambhī jhānādisukhena
analyzed: abhibhavitvā hananataḥ pajahanataḥ tejuḥ sat abhāvena kutocipi abhīrū a chambhī jhāna ādi sukhena
translated: because of their overpowering and slaying of them by abandoning them, and because of their living happily in the bliss of jhāna, etc., without fear and trembling from any quarter, by virtue of their great might,

original: viharantīti sahanato hananato ca sīhā viyāti sīhā. Saddatthato pana yathā kantanatthena
analyzed: viharantī iti sahanataḥ hananataḥ ca sīhā viyāti sīhā saddatthataḥ pana yathā kantanatthena
translated: they are “lions” because of their endurance and their slaying. But in the sense of the word sūra,

original: ādiantavipallāsato takkaṃ vuccati, evaṃ hiṃsanaṭṭhena sīho veditabbo. Tathā sahanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: ādi anta vipallāsato takkam vuccati evam hiṃsana ṭṭhena sīhaḥ veditabbaḥ tathā sahana ṭṭhena
translated: It is called “speculation” because of the perversion of the beginning and the end. The lion should be understood in the sense of “harming” in this way. And in the sense of “enduring” .

original: Pisodarādipakkhepena niruttinayena pana vuccamāne vattabbameva natthi.🔽Atha vā yathā migarājā kesarasīho attano tejussadatāya ekacārī viharati, na kañci
analyzed: pisodara ādi pakkhepena nirutti nayena pana vuccamāne vattabbam eva natthi  atha vā yathā miga rājā kesarasīhaḥ eka cārī viharati na kañcid
translated: But when it is said by way of the method of “exclusion” with the exclusion of the “foetus” and so on, there is nothing to be said.

original: sahāyaṃ paccāsīsati, evametepi tejussadatāya vivekābhiratiyā ca ekacārinoti ekacariyaṭṭhenapi
analyzed: evam ete pi tejussada tāya viveka abhiratiyā ca eka cārinā ti eka cariya ṭṭhena api
translated: Or, just as the king of beasts, the lion, lives as a solitary because of the abundance of his own power and does not seek a companion, so too these, because of the abundance of their own power and their delight in solitude, are solitary. Therefore, by reason of their being solitary,

original: sīhā viyāti sīhā, tenāha – bhagavā “sīhaṃvekacaraṃ nāga”nti.
analyzed: sīhā viyāti sīhā tena āha bhagavā
translated: they are “lions” . Therefore it is said: “The Buddha, the lion who goes alone” .

original: Atha vā asantāsanajavaparakkamādivisesayogato sīhā viyāti sīhā, ete mahātherā. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: atha vā asanta āsana java parakkama ādi visesa yogataḥ sīhāḥ viyāti sīhāḥ ete mahā therāḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Or alternatively, because of the possession of such special qualities as fearlessness, swiftness, and courage, they are “lions” . These are the great elders. For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Dveme, bhikkhave, asaniyā phalantiyā na santasanti, katameva dve? Bhikkhu ca khīṇāsavo sīho ca migarājā”ti.
analyzed: dve me bhikkhave asaniyā phalantiyā na santasanti katame iva dve bhikkhu ca khīṇa asavaḥ sīhaḥ ca miga rājā ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are two who are not frightened when the lightning flashes and the thunder peals. Which two? The bhikkhu whose cankers are destroyed and the lion, king of beasts” .

original: Javopi sīhassa aññehi asādhāraṇo, tathā parakkamo. Tathā hi so usabhasatampi laṅghitvā
analyzed: javaḥ api sīhassa aññehi asādhāraṇaḥ tathā parakkamaḥ tathā hi saḥ usabha satam pi laṅghitvā
translated: Swiftness is not common to the lion and others, nor is courage. For the lion, having leaped over even a hundred bulls,

original: vanamahiṃsādīsu nipatati, potakopi samāno pabhinnamadānampi mattavaravāraṇānaṃ paṭimānaṃ🔽bhinditvā dantakaḷīraṃva khādati. Etesaṃ pana ariyamaggajavo iddhijavo ca aññehi
analyzed: nipatati potakaḥ api matta vara vāraṇānam  bhinditvā danta kaḷīram va khādati etesam pana ariya magga javo iddhi javo ca aññehi
translated: He falls upon wild elephants, and even a young one breaks the pride of huge rutting bulls and eats the tip of their tusks.

original: asādhāraṇo, sammappadhānaparakkamo ca niratisayo. Tasmā sīhānaṃvāti sīhasadisānaṃ
analyzed: asādhāraṇaḥ sammappadhāna parakkamo ca niratisayaḥ tasmai sīhānam vā ati sīha sadisānam
translated: But the speed of the noble path and the speed of supernormal power are not shared by others, and the exertion of right endeavour is beyond measure. Therefore it is said: “Like lions’ roars.”

original: viya. Sīhassa cettha hīnūpamatā daṭṭhabbā, accantavisiṭṭhassa sahanādiatthassa theresveva labbhanato.🔽Nadantānanti gajjantānaṃ. Gocaraparakkamatuṭṭhivelādīsu hi yathā sīhā attano āsayato🔽nikkhamitvā vijambhitvā sīhanādaṃ abhītanādaṃ nadanti, evaṃ etepi visayajjhattapaccavekkhaṇaudānādikālesu
analyzed: viya sīhassa ca ittha hīna upama tā daṭṭhabbā accanta visiṭṭhassa sahana ādi atthassa theresu eva labbhanato  nadantānam ti gajjantānam gocara parakkama tuṭṭhi velā ādīsu hi yathā sīhāḥ attanaḥ āsayataḥ  nikkhamitvā vijambhitvā sīha nādam abhīta nādam nadanti evam ete pi visaya jjhatta paccavekkhaṇa udāna ādi kālesu
translated: But here the lion should be regarded as the inferior simile, since the meaning of “endurance” and so on is found only in the elders, who are the most distinguished.🔽Roaring: roaring out. For just as lions, after coming out from their lair, yawning and stretching themselves, roar their fearless roar on occasions of ranging the forest, seeking a mate, rejoicing in their strength, and so on,

original: imaṃ abhītanādaṃ nadiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ – “sīhānaṃva nadantāna”nti. Dāṭhīnanti dāṭhāvantānaṃ.
analyzed: imam abhīta nādam nadiṃsu tena vuttam sīhānam va nadantānam ti dāṭhīnam ti dāṭhāvantānam
translated: so these elders roared out this fearless roar on occasions of reviewing their own domain, of rejoicing in inspiration, and so on. Hence it is said: “Like lions’ roars.”🔽With tusks: with tusks.

original: Pasaṭṭhadāṭhīnaṃ, atisayadāṭhānanti vā attho. Yathā hi sīhā ativiya daḷhānaṃ tikkhānañca
analyzed: pasaṭṭha dāṭhīnam atisaya dāṭhānam ti vā atthaḥ yathā hi sīhāḥ ativiya daḷhānam tikkhānam ca
translated: Or else the meaning is: “They were of wide jaws, of outstanding jaws.” For just as lions, by the power of their four jaws, which are very strong and sharp,

original: catunnaṃ dāṭhānaṃ balena paṭipakkhaṃ abhibhavitvā attano manorathaṃ matthakaṃ pūrenti,
analyzed: catunnam dāṭhānam balena paṭipakkham abhibhavitvā attanaḥ manoratham matthakam pūrenti
translated: overcome their opponents and fulfill their own desires,

original: evametepi catunnaṃ ariyamaggadāṭhānaṃ balena anādimati saṃsāre anabhibhūtapubbapaṭipakkhaṃ
analyzed: evam ete api catunnam ariya magga dāṭhānam balena anādimati saṃsāre an abhibhūta pubba paṭipakkham
translated: so too these disciples, by the power of the four noble paths, which are like jaws, overcame their opponents, who had never before been overcome in the beginningless round of rebirths,

original: abhibhavitvā attano manorathaṃ matthakaṃ pāpesuṃ. Idhāpi dāṭhā viyāti dāṭhāti sadisakappanāvaseneva attho veditabbo.🔽Girigabbhareti pabbataguhāyaṃ, samīpatthe bhummavacanaṃ. “Girigavhare”ti keci paṭhanti.🔽Pabbatesu vanagahane vanasaṇḍeti attho. Idaṃ pana nesaṃ virocanaṭṭhānadassanañceva
analyzed: abhibhavitvā attanaḥ manoratham matthakam idha api dāṭhā viya ati dāṭhā ati sadisa kappanā vasena iva atthaḥ veditabbo  giri gabbharā iti pabbata guhā ayam samīpa atthe bhumma vacanam giri gavharā iti keci paṭhanti  pabbatesu vana gahane vana saṇḍe ti attho idam pana nesam virocana ṭṭhāna dassanam ca iva
translated: and fulfilled their own desires. Here too the meaning should be understood in the same way as the simile of the jaws.🔽In mountain caves: in mountain caverns. The locative case is used in the sense of proximity. Some read “girigavhare,” but this is not correct.🔽The meaning is: “in mountain forests, in mountain thickets.” But this shows the place where they shone forth

original: sīhanādassa yogyabhūmidassanañca. Nadantānaṃ girigabbhareti yojanā. Yathā hi sīhā
analyzed: sīha nādassa yogya bhūmi dassanam ca nadantānam giri gabbharā iti yojanā yathā hi sīhā
translated: and the place suitable for the lion’s roar. The construction is: “roaring in mountain caves.” For just as lions,

original: yebhuyyena girigabbhare aññehi durāsadatāya janavivitte vasantā attano dassanena
analyzed: yebhuyyena giri gabbhare aññehi durāsada tāya jana vivitte vasantā attanaḥ dassanena
translated: and because they were living in lonely places, in mountain caves, etc., which were difficult of access to others, they were free from the fear of the small animals which are frightened by the sight of man.

original: uppajjanakassa khuddakamigasantāsassa pariharaṇatthaṃ gocaragamane sīhanādaṃ nadanti,🔽evametepi aññehi durāsadagirigabbharasadiseva suññāgārevasantā guṇehi khuddakānaṃ
analyzed: uppajjanakassa khudda ka miga santāsassa pariharaṇa attham gocara gamane sīha nādam nadanti  evam ete api aññehi durāsada giri gabbhara sadisā iva suñña āgāra vasantāḥ guṇehi khuddakānam
translated: In order to avoid the fear of the small animals which arose in them when they went out for alms, they roared the lion’s roar.🔽In the same way, these bhikkhus, living in lonely places, in empty halls, etc., which were difficult of access to others, like the mountain caves, etc., of the lions,

original: puthujjanānaṃ taṇhādiṭṭhiparittāsaparivajjanatthaṃ vakkhamānagāthāsaṅkhātaṃ abhītanādaṃ
analyzed: puthujjanānam taṇhā diṭṭhi parittāsa parivajjana attham vakkhamāna gāthā saṅkhātam abhīta nādam
translated: in order to avoid the small people, the worldlings, who are frightened by the sight of the qualities of the bhikkhus,

original: nadiṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ “sīhānaṃva nadantānaṃ, dāṭhīnaṃ girigabbhare”ti.🔽Suṇāthāti savanāṇattikavacanaṃ, tena vakkhamānānaṃ gāthānaṃ sannipatitāya parisāya
analyzed: tena vuttam sīhānam va nadantānam dāṭhīnam giri gabbhara iti  suṇātha ati savanāṇattika vacanam tena vakkhamānānam gāthānam sannipatitāya parisāya
translated: roared the lion’s roar, the collection of verses called the Dhammapada, which they were about to recite.🔽“Listen” is a word of attention; it arouses interest in the listeners by arousing in them a desire to hear the verses about to be recited.

original: sotukāmataṃ uppādento savane ādaraṃ janeti, ussāhaṃ samuṭṭhāpento gāravaṃ bahumānañca
analyzed: sotu kāma tam uppādentaḥ savane ādaram janeti ussāham samuṭṭhāpentaḥ gāravam bahu mānam ca
translated: It produces respect by arousing eagerness, and it produces reverence and esteem by arousing enthusiasm.

original: upaṭṭhapeti. Atha vā “sīhāna”ntiādīnaṃ padānaṃ sadisakappanāya vinā mukhyavaseneva
analyzed: upaṭṭhapeti atha vā sīha ananti ādīnam padānam sadisa kappanāya vinā mukhya vasena iva
translated: Or else, in order to illustrate the words “of the lions,” etc., without taking the primary meanings,

original: attho veditabbo. Tasmā daḷhatikkhabhāvena pasaṭṭhātisayadāṭhatāya dāṭhīnaṃ girigabbhare
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ tasmā daḷha tikkha bhāvena pasaṭṭha atisaya dāṭha tāya dāṭhīnam giri gabbhare
translated: The meaning should be understood. Therefore, just as the lion’s roar of the lions, the kings of beasts, who are roaring with the strength of their great and sharp teeth,

original: nadantānaṃ sīhagajjitaṃ gajjantānaṃ sīhānaṃ migarājūnaṃ viya tesaṃ abhītanādasadisā
analyzed: nadantānam sīha gajjitam gajjantānam sīhānam miga rājūnam viya tesam abhīta nāda sadisā
translated: is like their fearless shout in the mountain caves,

original: gāthā suṇāthāti attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “yathā sīhanādaṃ nadantānaṃ sīhānaṃ migarājūnaṃ🔽kutocipi bhayābhāvato so abhītanādo tadaññamigasantāsakaro, evaṃ bhāvitattānaṃ appamattānaṃ
analyzed: gāthā suṇātha ati attho idam vuttam hoti yathā sīha nādam nadantānam sīhānam miga rājūnam  kutocipi bhaya abhāvato so abhīta nādaḥ tad añña miga santāsa karo evam bhāvita ttānam appamattānam
translated: so listen to the verses which are like their fearless shout. The meaning is: “Just as the fearless shout of the lions, the kings of beasts, who are roaring with the lion’s roar,🔽is frightening to other beasts because there is no fear from anywhere, so listen to the verses which are like the fearless shout of the elders who have developed themselves and are heedful,

original: therānaṃ sīhanādasadisiyo sabbaso bhayahetūnaṃ suppahīnattā abhītanādabhūtā, pamattajanasantāsakarā gāthā suṇāthā”ti.🔽Bhāvitattānanti bhāvitacittānaṃ. Cittañhi “attā hi kira duddamo yo ve ṭhitatto tasaraṃva
analyzed: therānam sīhanāda sadisiyaḥ sabbasas bhaya hetūnam su pahīna ttā abhīta nāda bhūtā pamatta jana santāsa karā gāthā suṇātha ati  bhāvita ttānam ti bhāvita cittānam cittam hi attā hi kira duddamaḥ yaḥ
translated: because they are completely devoid of any cause for fear, and are frightening to heedless people.”🔽“Who have developed themselves”: who have developed their minds. For the mind is called “self” in such passages as “The self, it seems, is hard to subdue as long as it is unsteady,

original: ujjū”ti ca “attasammāpaṇidhī”ti ca evamādīsu attāti vuccati, tasmā adhicittānuyogena
analyzed: ujjū ti ca atta sammāpaṇidhī iti ca evamādīsu attā ati vuccati tasmai adhi citta anuyogena
translated: but when it is well subdued it is straight” , and “The self is rightly directed” . Therefore, by the practice of higher consciousness,

original: samathavipassanābhivaḍḍhitacittānaṃ samathavipassanābhāvanāmatthakaṃ pāpetvā ṭhitānanti
analyzed: samatha vipassanā abhivaḍḍhita cittānam samatha vipassanā bhāvanām atthakam pāpetvā ṭhitānanti
translated: Their minds were developed with serenity and insight, and they were established in the fruit of serenity and insight.

original: attho. Atha vā bhāvitattānanti bhāvitasabhāvānaṃ, sabhāvabhūtasīlādibhāvitānanti
analyzed: attho atha vā bhāvita tta ananti bhāvita sabhāvānam sabhāva bhūta sīla ādi bhāvita ananti
translated: Or else, “developed” means “having become the nature of,” “having become the essence of,” “having become the virtue, etc., that is their nature.”

original: attho. Gīyatīti gāthā, anuṭṭhubhādivasena isīhi pavattitaṃ catuppadaṃ chappadaṃ vā
analyzed: atthaḥ gīyati iti gāthā anuṭṭhubha ādi vasena isīhi pavattitam catuppadam chappadam vā
translated: A verse is a stanza, a composition in four lines or six lines by seers, etc., in the form of prose-exposition, etc.

original: vacanaṃ. Aññesampi taṃsadisatāya tathā vuccanti. Attatthādibhede atthe upanenti tesu🔽vā upaniyyantīti atthūpanāyikā.
analyzed: vacanam aññesam pi tad sadisa tāya tathā vuccanti atta ttha ādi bhede atthe upanenti tesu  vā upaniyyanti iti atthūpanāyikā
translated: It is called a verse because it is sung. Others are called that by analogy with it.🔽They are “about the meaning” because they lead to the meaning, or because they are led to the meaning, in the classification of meaning as personal advantage, etc.

original: Atha vā bhāvitattānanti bhāvitattābhāvānaṃ, attabhāvo hi āhito ahaṃ māno etthāti
analyzed: atha vā bhāvi tattānanti bhāvi tattā bhāvānam atta bhāvaḥ hi āhitaḥ aham ettha ati
translated: Or else, “developed” means “having become the nature of,” “having become the essence of.” The individual essence is called “self” because it is the basis for the conceit “I am.”

original: “attā”ti vuccati, so ca tehi appamādabhāvanāya anavajjabhāvanāya bhāvito sammadeva
analyzed: attā iti vuccati saḥ ca tehi appamāda bhāvanāya anavajja bhāvanāya bhāvito sammad eva
translated: And that was developed by them through the development of heedfulness and the development of blamelessness,🔽and it took on the fragrance of the special qualities.

original: guṇagandhaṃ gāhāpito. Tena tesaṃ kāyabhāvanā sīlabhāvanā cittabhāvanā paññābhāvanāti
analyzed: guṇa gandham gāhāpito tena tesam kāya bhāvanā sīla bhāvanā citta bhāvanā paññā bhāvanā ti
translated: Thus their development of body, their development of virtue, their development of mind, and their development of understanding,

original: catunnampi bhāvanānaṃ paripuṇṇabhāvaṃ dasseti. “Bhāvanā”ti ca sambodhipaṭipadā idhādhippetā.
analyzed: catunnam pi bhāvanānam paripuṇṇa bhāvam dasseti bhāvanā ati ca sambodhi paṭipadā idha adhippetā
translated: and it shows the fulfilment of all four kinds of development. “Development” here is intended as the way to enlightenment.

original: Yāyaṃ saccasambodhi atthi, sā duvidhā abhisamayato tadatthato ca. Sambodhi pana tividhā
analyzed: yā ayam sacca sambodhi atthi sā duvidhā abhisamayato tad atthato ca sambodhi pana tividhā
translated: Enlightenment is twofold as penetration and as its meaning. But enlightenment is threefold

original: sammāsambodhi paccekasambodhi sāvakasambodhīti. Tattha sammā sāmaṃ sabbadhammānaṃ🔽bujjhanato bodhanato ca sammāsambodhi. Sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānaṃ maggañāṇaṃ maggañāṇapadaṭṭhānañca
analyzed: sammāsambodhi paccekasambodhi sāvaka sambodhi iti tattha sammā sāmam sabba dhammānam  bujjhanataḥ bodhanataḥ ca sammāsambodhi sabbaññuta ññāṇa padaṭṭhānam magga ñāṇam magga ñāṇa padaṭṭhānañca
translated: as supreme enlightenment, individual enlightenment, and disciple enlightenment. Herein, supreme enlightenment is so called because of the act of fully awakening and the act of awakening others to all things,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ “sammāsambodhī”ti vuccati. Tenāha –
analyzed: sabbaññu ta ññāṇam sammāsambodhi iti vuccati tena āha
translated: because of the act of fully awakening and the act of awakening others to all things. The path knowledge that has the knowledge of omniscience as its support and the knowledge of omniscience that has path knowledge as its support are called “supreme enlightenment.” Hence it is said:

original: “Buddhoti yo so bhagavā sayambhū anācariyako pubbe ananussutesu dhammesu sāmaṃ saccāni abhisambujjhi, tattha ca sabbaññutaṃ patto balesu ca vasībhāva”nti.
analyzed: buddhaḥ ti yaḥ saḥ bhagavā sayambhu an ācariyako pubbe an anussutesu dhammesu sāmam saccāni abhisambujjhi tattha ca sabbaññu tam pattaḥ balesu ca vasībhāvanti
translated: “‘Enlightened’: he who is the Blessed One, the Self-becoming One, the One without a Teacher, who fully awakened and awakened others to the truths by himself, who attained omniscience and mastery over all things” .

original: Bodhaneyyabodhanattho hi balesu vasībhāvo. Paccekaṃ sayameva bodhīti paccekasambodhi,
analyzed: bodhaneyya bodhana atthaḥ hi balesu vasībhāvaḥ paccekam sayam eva bodhi iti pacceka sambodhi
translated: For mastery over all things is the meaning of “awakening others” in the case of the Blessed One. Individual enlightenment is so called because of the act of awakening by oneself.

original: ananubuddho sayambhūñāṇena saccābhisamayoti attho. Sammāsambuddhānañhi sayambhūñāṇatāya🔽sayameva pavattamānopi saccābhisamayo sānubuddho aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ saccābhisamayassa🔽hetubhāvato. Imesaṃ pana so ekassāpi sattassa saccābhisamayahetu na hoti. Satthu
analyzed: an anubuddhaḥ sayambhu ñāṇena sacca abhisamayaḥ ti attho sammāsambuddhānam hi sayambhu ñāṇa tāya  sayam eva pavattamānaḥ api sacca abhisamayaḥ sa anubuddhaḥ aparimāṇānam sattānam sacca abhisamayassa  hetu bhāvataḥ imesam pana saḥ ekassa api sattassa sacca abhisamaya hetu na hoti satthu
translated: the meaning is, he has not penetrated the truths by his own knowledge, as have the Self-Awakened Ones.🔽For the penetration of the truths, though occurring by itself in the case of the Fully Enlightened Ones because of their knowledge that is self-originated,🔽is nevertheless “penetrated” because it is a cause for the penetration of the truths by countless other beings.🔽But this man’s penetration of the truths is not a cause for the penetration of the truths by even a single other being.🔽

original: dhammadesanāya savanante jātāti sāvakā. Sāvakānaṃ saccābhisamayo sāvakasambodhi.🔽Tividhāpesā tiṇṇaṃ bodhisattānaṃ yathāsakaṃ āgamanīyapaṭipadāya matthakappattiyā
analyzed: dhamma desanāya savana ante jātā ati sāvakā sāvakānam sacca abhisamayo sāvaka sambodhi  tividhā apesā tiṇṇam bodhisattānam yathāsakam āgamanīya paṭipadāya matthaka ppattiyā
translated: The meaning is that he has not penetrated the truths by his own independent knowledge. For the penetration of the truths, though occurring independently in the case of the Buddhas, is nevertheless called “penetrated” since it is a cause for the penetration of the truths by countless beings through the teaching of the Buddhas. But in the case of the Paccekabuddhas, the penetration of the truths is not a cause for the penetration of the truths by any other being. The disciples are so called because they have been born by the sound of the Master’s teaching of the Dhamma. The penetration of the truths by the disciples is the enlightenment of the disciples.

original: satipaṭṭhānādīnaṃ sattatiṃsāya bodhipakkhiyadhammānaṃ bhāvanāpāripūrīti veditabbā
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna ādīnam sattatiṃsāya bodhi pakkhiya dhammānam bhāvanā pāripūrī iti veditabbā
translated: This is threefold as the enlightenment of the three kinds of Buddhas, that is to say, the Buddhas, the Paccekabuddhas, and the disciples. It should be understood that it is the completion of the development of the thirty- seven states partaking of enlightenment, namely, the four foundations of mindfulness, the four right endeavours, the four bases for success, the five spiritual faculties, the five spiritual powers, and the Noble Eightfold Path, through the attainment of the peak of the respective paths of progress of the three kinds of Buddhas.

original: itarābhisamayānaṃ tadavinābhāvato. Na hi sacchikiriyābhisamayena vinā bhāvanābhisamayo
analyzed: itara abhisamayānam tad avinābhāvataḥ na hi sacchikiriyā abhisamayena vinā bhāvanā abhisamayaḥ
translated: For the other kinds of penetration are not dissociated from this one. For without the penetration by realization there is no penetration by development,

original: sambhavati, sati ca bhāvanābhisamaye pahānābhisamayo pariññābhisamayo ca siddhoyeva hotīti.
analyzed: sambhavati sati ca bhāvanā abhisamaye pahāna abhisamayo pariññā abhisamayo ca siddho yā iva hoti iti
translated: and when there is penetration by development, the penetration by abandoning and the penetration by full understanding are already established.

original: Yadā hi mahābodhisatto paripūritabodhisambhāro carimabhave katapubbakicco bodhimaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: yadā hi mahā bodhisatto paripūrita bodhi sambhāro carima bhave kata pubba kiccaḥ bodhimaṇḍam
translated: For when the Great Being had fulfilled the requisites for enlightenment, had done his duty in his last existence, and had ascended the terrace of enlightenment,

original: āruyha – “na tāvimaṃ pallaṅkaṃ bhindissāmi, yāva na me anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccissatī”ti
analyzed: āruyha na tau imam pallaṅkam bhindissāmi yāva na me an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimuccissati iti
translated: he made a vow, saying, “I will not break this cross-legged posture until my mind is liberated from the taints without remainder.”

original: paṭiññaṃ katvā aparājitapallaṅke nisinno asampattāya eva sañjhāvelāya mārabalaṃ vidhamitvā🔽purimayāme pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇena anekākāravokāre pubbe nivutthakkhandhe anussaritvā
analyzed: paṭiññam katvā aparājita pallaṅke nisinnaḥ a sampattāya eva sañjhā velāya māra balam vidhamitvā  purima yāme pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇena aneka ākāra vokāre pubbe nivuttha kkhandhe anussaritvā
translated: Then, sitting on the invincible throne, before the night was over, he crushed Māra’s army,🔽recalled the aggregates of existence in their various aspects and modes during his previous existences by means of the knowledge of recollection of past births in the first watch of the night,

original: majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuvisodhanena cutūpapātañāṇaanāgataṃsañāṇāni adhigantvā pacchimayāme
analyzed: majjhima yāme dibba cakkhu visodhanena cutu upapāta ñāṇa anāgataṃsa ñāṇāni adhigantvā pacchima yāme
translated: and in the middle watch he attained the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings and the knowledge of the future by means of the purification of the divine eye. In the last watch of the night,

original: “kicchaṃ vatāyaṃ loko āpanno jāyati ca jīyati ca mīyati ca cavati ca upapajjati ca,
analyzed: kiccham vata ayam lokaḥ āpannaḥ jāyati ca jīyati ca mīyati ca cavati ca upapajjati ca
translated: he thought: “Alas, this world has fallen into trouble, in that it is born, ages, dies, passes away, and re-appears,🔽and yet it does not understand the escape from this suffering, from old age and death.”

original: atha ca panimassa dukkhassa nissaraṇaṃ nappajānāti jarāmaraṇassā”tiādinā jarāmaraṇato
analyzed: atha ca panimassa dukkhassa nissaraṇam na ppajānāti jarā maraṇassa ati ādinā jarā maraṇato
translated: Thus he reflected on old age and death,

original: paṭṭhāya paṭiccasamuppādamukhena vipassanaṃ abhinivisitvā mahāgahanaṃ chindituṃ nisadasilāyaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya paṭiccasamuppāda mukhena vipassanam abhinivisitvā mahā gahanam chinditum nisada silāyam
translated: and, beginning with the dependent origination, he entered upon insight, as if sitting on a rock seat and cutting down the great forest with an axe.

original: pharasuṃ nisento viya kilesagahanaṃ chindituṃ lokanātho ñāṇapharasuṃ tejento buddhabhāvāya
analyzed: pharasum nisentaḥ viya kilesa gahanam chinditum lokanāthaḥ ñāṇa pharasum tejentaḥ buddha bhāvāya
translated: The Lord of the World, sharpening the axe of knowledge in order to cut down the forest of defilements,

original: hetusampattiyā paripākaṃ gatattā sabbaññutaññāṇādhigamāya vipassanaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhāpento
analyzed: hetu sampattiyā paripākam gata ttā sabbaññu ta ññāṇa adhigamāya vipassanam gabbham gaṇhāpentaḥ
translated: and having reached maturity in the perfection of the cause, he conceived insight for the attainment of omniscient knowledge.

original: antarantarā nānāsamāpattiyo samāpajjitvā yathāvavatthāpite nāmarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā
analyzed: antar antarā nānā samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjitvā yathāvavavatthāpite nāma rūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā
translated: He entered into various attainments again and again, and having placed the three characteristics upon the name-and-form as it is defined,🔽he contemplated the formations of many kinds and aspects by way of the insight of the conditioned nature of things.

original: anupadadhammavipassanāvasena anekākāravokārasaṅkhāre sammasanto chattiṃsakoṭisatasahassamukhena
analyzed: anupada dhamma vipassanā vasena aneka ākāra vokāra saṅkhāre sammasanto chattiṃsa koṭi sata sahassa mukhena
translated: He extended the contemplation to a hundred and forty koṭis of times,

original: sammasanavāraṃ vitthāretvā tattha mahāvajirañāṇasaṅkhāte vipassanāñāṇe tikkhe sūre
analyzed: sammasana vāram vitthāretvā tattha mahā vajira ñāṇa saṅkhāte vipassanā ñāṇe tikkhe sūre
translated: and when the insight knowledge called the Great Diamond, which is sharp, bright,🔽and proceeds to the emergence, was occurring, he then combined it with the path.

original: pasanne vuṭṭhānagāminibhāvena pavattamāne yadā taṃ maggena ghaṭeti, tadā maggapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: pasanne vuṭṭhāna gāmini bhāvena pavattamāne yadā tam maggena ghaṭeti tadā magga paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Then, in the order of the path,

original: diyaḍḍhakilesasahassaṃ khepento aggamaggakkhaṇe sammāsambodhiṃ adhigacchati nāma,🔽aggaphalakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya adhigato nāma. Sammāsambuddhabhāvato dasabalacatuvesārajjādayopi
analyzed: diyaḍḍha kilesa sahassam khepentaḥ agga magga kkhaṇe sammāsambodhim adhigacchati nāma  agga pha lakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya adhigataḥ nāma sammāsambuddha bhāvataḥ dasa bala catu vesārajja ādayaḥ api
translated: He is said to reach the supreme enlightenment at the moment of the path of stream-entry when he has abandoned the first thousand of the two-and-a-half-thousand categories of defilements.🔽He is said to have reached it from the moment of the fruit of stream-entry onwards. And the ten powers, four kinds of fearlessness, and so on, are also in his hands at that moment because of his being a supreme Buddha.

original: tassa tadā hatthagatāyeva hontīti ayaṃ tāva abhisamayato sammāsambodhipaṭipadā. Tadatthato
analyzed: tassa tadā hattha gatāya iva honti iti ayam tāva abhisamayataḥ sammāsambodhi paṭipadā tad atthato
translated: This, in the first place, is the way of practice for the supreme enlightenment in the act of penetration.

original: pana mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya yāva tusitabhavane nibbatti, etthantare pavattaṃ bodhisambhārasambharaṇaṃ.
analyzed: pana mahā abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya yāva tusita bhavane nibbatti etthantare pavattam bodhi sambhāra sambharaṇam
translated: But as to the meaning of the words, the accumulation of the requisites for enlightenment takes place from the time of the great aspiration up to the time of rebirth in the Tusita heaven.

original: Tattha yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbākārasampannaṃ cariyāpiṭakavaṇṇanāyaṃ vitthārato vuttamevāti
analyzed: tattha yat vattabbam tat sabba ākāra sampannam cariyāpiṭaka vaṇṇanāyam vitthārataḥ vuttam eva ati
translated: Herein, what should be said has all been said in the commentary to the Cariyāpiṭaka in the section dealing with the perfection of wisdom, which is the perfection dealt with in the Cariyāpiṭaka.

original: tattha vuttanayeneva gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tattha vutta nayena iva gahetabbam
translated: So it can be understood as given there.

original: Paccekabodhisattāpi paccekabodhiyā katābhinīhārā anupubbena sambhatapaccekasambodhisambhārā
analyzed: pacceka bodhisattā api pacceka bodhiyā kata abhinīhārāḥ anupubbena sambhata paccekasambodhi sambhārā
translated: And the Paccekabuddhas, who have made their great aspiration for paccekabodhi, gradually accumulate the requisites for paccekabodhi,

original: tādise kāle carimattabhāve ṭhitā ñāṇassa paripākagatabhāvena upaṭṭhitaṃ saṃveganimittaṃ
analyzed: tādise kāle carimatta bhāve ṭhitā ñāṇassa paripāka gata bhāvena upaṭṭhitam saṃvega nimittam
translated: and when the time is right they are reborn in their last existence and the sign of the accumulation of their knowledge appears to them as a result of the maturity of their knowledge.

original: gahetvā savisesaṃ bhavādīsu ādīnavaṃ disvā sayambhūñāṇena pavatti pavattihetuṃ nivatti🔽nivattihetuñca paricchinditvā “so ‘idaṃ dukkha’nti yoniso manasi karotī”tiādinā āgatanayena
analyzed: gahetvā sa visesam bhava ādīsu ādīnavam disvā sayambhu ñāṇena pavatti pavatti hetum  nivatti hetuñca paricchinditvā saḥ idam dukkhanti yonisas manasi karoti itiādinā āgata nayena
translated: and having seen the danger in the round of rebirths in the various kinds of becoming, etc., he defines the cause of the occurrence of the round and the cause of its cessation by means of his own knowledge,🔽and then he develops the meditation subject of the Four Noble Truths in the way stated thus: “He gives careful attention to it as impermanent, as suffering, as a disease, as a tumour, as a barb, as a calamity, as an affliction, as alien, as disintegrating, as void, as not self” .

original: catusaccakammaṭṭhānaṃ paribrūhentā attano abhinīhārānurūpaṃ saṅkhāre parimaddantā🔽anukkamena vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā maggapaṭipāṭiyā aggamaggaṃ adhigacchantā paccekasambodhiṃ🔽abhisambujjhanti nāma, aggaphalakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya paccekasambuddhā nāma hutvā sadevakassa
analyzed: catu sacca kammaṭṭhānam attanaḥ abhinīhāra anurūpam saṅkhāre parimaddantā  anukkamena vipassanam ussukkāpetvā magga paṭipāṭiyā agga maggam adhigacchantā paccekasambodhim  abhisambujjhanti nāma agga phalakkhaṇato paṭṭhāya paccekasambuddhāḥ nāma hutvā sa devakassa
translated: and he directs his thoughts to the formations in accordance with his aspiration,🔽and he eventually arouses insight, and he reaches the supramundane path in the sequence appropriate to it, and he realizes the supreme fruit of the path. He is then called a paccekabuddha “awakened one for himself” .

original: lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyā honti.
analyzed: lokassa aggadakkhiṇeyyāḥ honti
translated: From the time he has reached the supreme fruit he is worthy of the highest offerings in the world with its deities.

original: Sāvakā pana satthu sabrahmacārino vā catusaccakammaṭṭhānakathaṃ sutvā tasmiṃyeva
analyzed: sāvakā pana satthu sabrahmacārinaḥ vā catu sacca kammaṭṭhāna katham sutvā tasmiṃ yeva
translated: But the disciples, either while listening to the teacher or to a fellow-student expound the meditation subject of the Four Noble Truths,

original: khaṇe kālantare vā tajjaṃ paṭipattiṃ anutiṭṭhantā ghaṭentā vāyamantā vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā,
analyzed: khaṇe kāla antare vā tajjam paṭipattim anutiṭṭhantā ghaṭentā vā āyamantā vipassanam ussukkāpetvā
translated: or afterwards, either then or later, as they practise the appropriate way in earnest, strive and struggle, and arouse insight,

original: yadi vā paṭipadāya vaḍḍhantiyā, saccāni paṭivijjhantā attano abhinīhārānurūpasiddhiaggasāvakabhūmiyā
analyzed: yadi vā paṭipadāya vaḍḍhantiyā saccāni paṭivijjhantāḥ attanaḥ abhinīhāra anurūpa siddhi agga sāvaka bhūmiyā
translated: Or else, as the path develops, they penetrate the truths, and they reach the highest fruit of being chief disciples in accordance with their aspiration.

original: vā kevalaṃ vā aggamaggakkhaṇe sāvakasambodhiṃ adhigacchanti nāma. Tato paraṃ sāvakabuddhā🔽nāma honti sadevake loke aggadakkhiṇeyyā. Evaṃ tāva abhisamayato paccekasambodhi
analyzed: vā kevalam vā agga magga kkhaṇe sāvaka sambodhim adhigacchanti nāma tatas param sāvakabuddhāḥ  nāma honti sa devake loke agga dakkhiṇeyyāḥ evam tāva abhisamayato paccekasambodhi
translated: Or else, they reach the enlightenment of disciples at the moment of the highest path. After that they are called “fully enlightened Buddhas for themselves”

original: sāvakasambodhi ca veditabbā.
analyzed: sāvaka sambodhi ca veditabbā
translated: and are the most worthy recipients of offerings in the world with its deities. This, in the first place, is how the enlightenment of disciples and the enlightenment of the fully enlightened Buddhas for themselves should be understood as to penetration.🔽As to the meaning of the word: the word bodhi is derived from the verb budh, “to understand.” The word bodhi is used when the understanding of the four noble truths occurs in any one of the three ways stated.

original: Tadatthato pana yathā mahābodhisattānaṃ heṭṭhimaparicchedena cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: tad atthato pana yathā mahā bodhisattānam heṭṭhima paricchedena cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: But the word sambodhi is used when the understanding of the four noble truths occurs in all the three ways and in all the four truths.

original: kappānaṃ satasahassañca bodhisambhārasambharaṇaṃ icchitabbaṃ majjhimaparicchedena🔽aṭṭha asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānaṃ satasahassañca, uparimaparicchedena soḷasa asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: kappānam sata sahassam ca bodhi sambhāra sambharaṇam icchitabbam majjhima paricchedena  aṭṭha asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānam sata sahassam ca uparima paricchedena soḷasa asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: The word sambodhi is derived from the verb sam-budh, “to understand fully.”🔽The word paccekabodhi is used when the understanding of the four noble truths occurs in the three ways stated, but not in all the four truths.🔽The word paccekabodhi is derived from the verb pacceka-budh, “to understand separately.”

original: kappānaṃ satasahassañca ete ca bhedā paññādhikasaddhādhikavīriyādhikavasena veditabbā.
analyzed: kappānam sata sahassam ca ete ca bhedā paññā adhika saddhā adhika vīriya adhika vasena veditabbā
translated: The word buddhabodhi is used when the understanding of the four noble truths occurs in the three ways stated and in all the four truths, and also when the understanding of all things occurs in the three ways stated and in all the eighteen kinds of things.

original: Paññādhikānañhi saddhā mandā hoti paññā tikkhā, tato ca upāyakosallassa visadanipuṇabhāvena🔽nacirasseva pāramiyo pāripūriṃ gacchanti. Saddhādhikānaṃ paññā majjhimā hotīti tesaṃ
analyzed: paññā adhikānam hi saddhā mandā hoti paññā tikkhā tatas ca upāya kosallassa visada nipuṇa bhāvena  nacirassa iva pāramiyaḥ pāripūrim gacchanti saddhā adhikānam paññā majjhimā hoti iti tesam
translated: For those who are superior in understanding have weak faith and keen understanding, and so, because of the excellence and subtlety of their skill in means,🔽their pāramīs are fulfilled in no long time. But those who are superior in faith have medium understanding, and so

original: nātisīghaṃ nātisaṇikaṃ pāramiyo pāripūriṃ gacchanti. Vīriyādhikānaṃ pana paññā mandā
analyzed: na ati sīgham na ati saṇikam pāramiyaḥ pāripūrim gacchanti vīriya adhikānam pana paññā mandā
translated: their pāramīs are fulfilled neither too quickly nor too slowly. And those who are superior in energy have weak understanding, and so

original: hotīti tesaṃ cireneva pāramiyo pāripūriṃ gacchanti. Na evaṃ paccekabodhisattānaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti tesam cirena iva pāramiyaḥ pāripūrim gacchanti na evam pacceka bodhisattānam
translated: their pāramīs are fulfilled only after a long time. But it is not so with the paccekabuddhas.

original: Tesañhi satipi paññādhikabhāve dve asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānaṃ satasahassañca bodhisambhārasambharaṇaṃ
analyzed: tesam hi paññā adhika bhāve dve asaṅkhyeyyāni kappānam sata sahassam ca bodhi sambhāra sambharaṇam
translated: For although they are superior in understanding, they must gather the requisites for enlightenment for two incalculable periods and a hundred thousand eons,

original: icchitabbaṃ, na tato oraṃ. Saddhādhikavīriyādhikāpi vuttaparicchedato paraṃ katipaye
analyzed: icchitabbam na tatas oram saddhā adhika vīriya adhikā api vutta paricchedato param katipaye
translated: not less. Those who are superior in faith and energy, after exceeding the stated limit,

original: eva kappe atikkamitvā paccekasambodhiṃ abhisambujjhanti, na tatiyaṃ asaṅkhyeyyanti.
analyzed: eva kappe atikkamitvā paccekasambodhim abhisambujjhanti na tatiyam asaṅkhyeyyanti
translated: attain paccekabodhi after a few more eons, but not after a third incalculable period.

original: Sāvakabodhisattānaṃ pana yesaṃ aggasāvakabhāvāya abhinīhāro, tesaṃ ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ
analyzed: sāvaka bodhisattānam pana yesam aggasāvaka bhāvāya abhinīhāro tesam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam
translated: But the sāvaka-bodhisattvas, who aspire to the state of chief disciples, must gather the requisites for enlightenment for one incalculable period and a hundred thousand eons,

original: kappānaṃ satasahassañca sambhārasambharaṇaṃ icchitabbaṃ. Yesaṃ mahāsāvakabhāvāya,
analyzed: kappānam sata sahassam ca sambhāra sambharaṇam icchitabbam yesam mahāsāvaka bhāvāya
translated: and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a great disciple.🔽For those who are to become Buddhas, a hundred thousand eons is required for the equipment of the requisites for enlightenment,

original: tesaṃ kappānaṃ satasahassameva, tathā buddhassa mātāpitūnaṃ upaṭṭhākassa puttassa ca. Tattha yathā –
analyzed: tesam kappānam sata sahassam eva tathā buddhassa mātā pitūnam upaṭṭhākassa puttassa ca tattha yathā
translated: and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a chief disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a great disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a chief female disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a great female disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a paccekabuddha, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s mother, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s father, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s chief disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s chief female disciple, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s principal attendant, and a hundred thousand eons for the equipment of the requisites for the state of a Buddha’s son.🔽Herein, it is said:

original: “Manussattaṃ liṅgasampatti, hetu satthāradassanaṃ;
translated: “Human birth, sex, cause, seeing the Master,

original: Pabbajjā guṇasampatti, adhikāro ca chandatā;
analyzed: pabbajjā guṇa sampatti adhikāraḥ ca chanda tā
translated: Going forth, virtue, and likewise desire to act,🔽And the eight requisites—when these are present,

original: Aṭṭhadhammasamohānā, abhinīhāro samijjhatī”ti. –
analyzed: aṭṭha dhamma samohānā abhinīhāro samijjhati iti
translated: Aspiration succeeds.”

original: Evaṃ vutte aṭṭha dhamme samodhānetvā katapaṇidhānānaṃ mahābodhisattānaṃ mahābhinīhārato🔽pabhuti savisesaṃ dānādīsu yuttappayuttānaṃ divase divase vessantaradānasadisaṃ mahādānaṃ
analyzed: evam vutte aṭṭha dhamme samodhānetvā kata paṇidhānānam mahā bodhisattānam mahā abhinīhārato  sa visesam dāna ādīsu divase divase vessantara dāna sadisam mahā dānam
translated: When this is said, then it is only great Bodhisattvas who have formed their aspirations after accumulating the eight requisites that,🔽from the time of their great aspiration, are intent on giving, etc., in all its aspects, and who,

original: dentānaṃ tadanurūpasīlādike sabbapāramidhamme ācinantānampi yathāvuttakālaparicchedaṃ
analyzed: dentānam tad anurūpa sīla ādike sabba pārami dhamme ācinantānam pi yathā vutta kāla paricchedam
translated: while they are thus intent, give great gifts day by day like the gift of Vessantara, and who, while they are thus giving, also accumulate all the other pāramīs such as virtue, etc., in like manner, and who, while they are thus giving and accumulating, do not attain to Buddhahood in the interval, though they have passed through the time stated,

original: asampatvā antarā eva buddhabhāvappatti nāma natthi. Kasmā? Ñāṇassa aparipaccanato.
analyzed: a sampatvā antarā eva buddha bhāva ppatti nāma natthi kasmā ñāṇassa a paripaccanato
translated: because their knowledge has not reached maturity.

original: Paricchinnakāle nipphāditaṃ viya hi sassaṃ buddhañāṇaṃ yathāparicchinnakālavaseneva
analyzed: paricchinna kāle nipphāditam viya hi sassam buddha ñāṇam yathā paricchinna kāla vasena iva
translated: For the knowledge of a Buddha, like a crop produced at a fixed time,

original: vuddhiṃ viruḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjantaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhantaṃ paripākaṃ gacchatīti evaṃ –
analyzed: vuddhim viruḷhim vepullam āpajjantam gabbham gaṇhantam paripākam gacchati iti evam
translated: grows, increases, and expands, and takes on a state of maturity only within the time-span determined.

original: “Manussattaṃ liṅgasampatti, vigatāsavadassanaṃ;
analyzed: manussattam liṅga sampatti vigata āsava dassanam
translated: “Human birth, the right sex, sound of mind, a Buddha’s appearance,

original: Adhikāro chandatā ete, abhinīhārakāraṇā”ti. –
analyzed: ete
translated: Opportunity, and aspiration: these are the conditions for the Great Resolve.

original: Ime pañca dhamme samodhānetvā katābhinīhārānaṃ paccekabodhisattānaṃ “adhikāro chandatā”ti
analyzed: ime pañca dhamme samodhānetvā kata abhinīhārānam pacceka bodhisattānam adhikāraḥ
translated: “Opportunity, and aspiration” are the two factors of the aspiration made by the Paccekabuddhas, who have formed their resolve after considering the five ideas.

original: dvaṅgasamannāgatāya patthanāya vasena katapaṇidhānānaṃ sāvakabodhisattānañca tattha🔽tattha vuttakālaparicchedaṃ asampatvā antarā eva paccekasambodhiyā yathāvuttasāvakasambodhiyā
analyzed: dvaṅga samannāgatāya patthanāya vasena kata paṇidhānānam sāvaka bodhisattānam ca tattha  tattha vutta kāla paricchedam a sampatvā antarā eva pacceka sambodhiyā yathā vutta sāvaka sambodhiyā
translated: “Opportunity, and aspiration” are also the two factors of the aspiration made by the Bodhisattvas who are disciples, who have made their aspiration with the words,🔽“May I become a Buddha in the future when the human life span is a hundred years.”

original: ca adhigamo natthi. Kasmā? Ñāṇassa aparipaccanato. Imesampi hi yathā mahābodhisattānaṃ
analyzed: ca adhigamaḥ natthi kasmā ñāṇassa a paripaccanataḥ imesam pi hi yathā mahā bodhisattānam
translated: But there is no attainment of the Paccekabodhi or the Bodhi of the disciples, as described above, without the lapse of time stated in each case. Why? Because the knowledge has not matured. For in these two kinds of Bodhisattvas,

original: dānādipāramīhi paribrūhitā paññāpāramī anukkamena gabbhaṃ gaṇhantī paripākaṃ gacchantī🔽buddhañāṇaṃ paripūreti, evaṃ dānādīhi paribrūhitā anupubbena yathārahaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhantī
analyzed: dāna ādi pāramīhi paribrūhitā paññāpāramī anukkamena gabbham gaṇhantī paripākam gacchantī  buddha ñāṇam paripūreti evam dāna ādīhi paribrūhitā anupubbena yathāraham gabbham gaṇhantī
translated: The perfection of wisdom, which is developed by the perfections of giving, etc., gradually conceives a child, and it grows in the womb.🔽It fulfills the knowledge of a Buddha. In the same way, the perfections of giving, etc., which are developed by the perfection of wisdom, gradually conceive a child, and it grows in the womb.

original: paripākaṃ gacchantī paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ sāvakabodhiñāṇañca paripūreti. Dānaparicayena
analyzed: paripākam gacchantī pacceka bodhiñāṇam sāvaka bodhiñāṇam ca paripūreti dāna paricayena
translated: It fulfills the knowledge of a Paccekabuddha and the knowledge of a disciple. By the practice of giving,

original: hete tattha tattha bhave alobhajjhāsayatāya sabbattha asaṅgamānasā anapekkhacittā
analyzed: hete tattha tattha bhave sabbattha asaṅga mānasāḥ anapekkha cittāḥ
translated: in various existences, because of the inclination to non-greed, he has a mind free from attachment and a mind free from concern.

original: hutvā, sīlaparicayena susaṃvutakāyavācatāya suparisuddhakāyavacīkammantā parisuddhājīvā
analyzed: hutvā sīla paricayena su saṃvuta kāya vācatāya su parisuddha kāya vacī kammantā parisuddha ājīvā
translated: By the practice of virtue, because of the well-controlled body and speech, he has pure bodily and verbal conduct and a pure livelihood.

original: indriyesu guttadvārā bhojane mattaññuno hutvā jāgariyānuyogena cittaṃ samādahanti,
analyzed: indriyesu gutta dvārā bhojane mattaññunaḥ hutvā jāgariya anuyogena cittam samādahanti
translated: By the practice of meditation, because of the guarded sense faculties and moderation in eating, he has collectedness of mind.

original: svāyaṃ tesaṃ jāgariyānuyogo gatapaccāgatikavattavasena veditabbo.
analyzed: su ayam tesam jāgariya anuyogaḥ gatapaccāgatika vatta vasena veditabbo
translated: This practice of meditation should be understood as the practice of going out and coming back.

original: Evaṃ pana paṭipajjantānaṃ adhikārasampattiyā appakasireneva aṭṭha samāpattiyo pañcābhiññā
analyzed: evam pana paṭipajjantānam adhikāra sampattiyā appa kasirena iva aṭṭha samāpattiyaḥ pañca abhiññā
translated: But for those who practice in this way, the attainment of the opportunity is not difficult. They attain the eight attainments and the five supernormal knowledges.

original: chaḷabhiññā adhiṭṭhānabhūtā pubbabhāgavipassanā ca hatthagatāyeva honti. Vīriyādayo🔽pana tadantogadhā eva. Yañhi paccekabodhiyā sāvakabodhiyā vā atthāya dānādipuññasambharaṇe
analyzed: chaḷ abhiññā adhiṭṭhāna bhūtā pubbabhāga vipassanā ca hattha gatāya iva honti vīriya ādayaḥ  pana tad antogadhāḥ eva yat hi pacceka bodhiyā sāvaka bodhiyā vā atthāya dāna ādi puñña sambharaṇe
translated: and the six kinds of direct knowledge and the insight of the prior stage are as good as in his hand. But the others, namely, energy,

original: abbhussahanaṃ, idaṃ vīriyaṃ. Yaṃ tadanuparodhassa sahanaṃ, ayaṃ khanti. Yaṃ dānasīlādisamādānāvisaṃvādanaṃ,🔽idaṃ saccaṃ. Sabbatthameva acalasamādhānādhiṭṭhānaṃ, idaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ. Yā dānasīlādīnaṃ
analyzed: idam vīriyam yam tad an uparodhassa sahanam ayam khanti yam dāna sīla ādi samādāna avisaṃvādanam  idam saccam sabbattham eva acala samādhāna adhiṭṭhānam idam adhiṭṭhānam yā dāna sīla ādīnam
translated: etc., are included in that . For the willingness to endure in the accumulation of the requisites of merit such as giving, etc., for the sake of paccekabodhi or of sāvakabodhi is energy. The endurance of what is hostile to that is patience. The non-deception of those who have undertaken giving, virtue, etc.,

original: pavattiṭṭhānabhūtesu sattesu hitesitā, ayaṃ mettā. Yaṃ sattānaṃ katavippakāresu ajjhupekkhanaṃ,🔽ayaṃ upekkhāti. Evaṃ dānasīlabhāvanāsu sīlasamādhipaññāsu ca sijjhamānāsu vīriyādayo
analyzed: pavatti ṭṭhāna bhūtesu sattesu hita īsitā ayam mettā yam sattānam kata vippakāresu ajjhupekkhanam  ayam upekkhāti evam dāna sīla bhāvanāsu sīla samādhi paññāsu ca sijjhamānāsu vīriya ādayaḥ
translated: is truth. The unshakable resolve in all circumstances is resolution. The desire for the welfare of beings who are the foundation for the occurrence of giving, virtue, etc., is loving kindness. The equanimity towards beings who have done harm is equanimity. Thus when giving, virtue, and development of the kinds stated are successful, energy, etc.,

original: siddhā eva honti. Sāyeva paccekabodhiatthāya sāvakabodhiatthāya ca dānādipaṭipadā
analyzed: siddhāḥ eva honti sāyā iva pacceka bodhi atthāya sāvaka bodhi atthāya ca dāna ādi paṭipadā
translated: are also successful. And that very undertaking of giving, etc., for the sake of paccekabodhi and for the sake of sāvakabodhi

original: tesaṃ bodhisattānaṃ santānassa bhāvanato paribhāvanato bhāvanā nāma. Visesato dānasīlādīhi🔽svābhisaṅkhate santāne pavattā samathavipassanāpaṭipadā, yato te bodhisattā pubbayogāvacarasamudāgamasampannā
analyzed: tesam bodhisattānam santānassa bhāvanato paribhāvanataḥ bhāvanā nāma visesataḥ dāna sīla ādīhi  sva abhisaṅkhate santāne pavattā samatha vipassanā paṭipadā yatas te bodhisattā pubba yogāvacara samudāgama sampannā
translated: It is called “development” because of the development and increase of those ideas in the continuity of those Bodhisattvas.🔽It is the course of serenity and insight that occurs in the continuity that is self-determined by means of the special qualities of giving, virtue, etc.,

original: honti. Tenāha bhagavā –🔽“Pañcime, ānanda, ānisaṃsā pubbayogāvacare. Katame pañca? Idhānanda, pubbayogāvacaro
analyzed: honti tena āha bhagavān  pañcime ānanda ānisaṃsā pubbayogāvacare katame pañca idha ānanda pubbayogāvacaro
translated: by which those Bodhisattvas become possessed of the attainment of the preliminary stage of the path. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ ārādheti, no ce diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ ārādheti,🔽atha maraṇakāle aññaṃ ārādheti, atha devaputto samāno aññaṃ ārādheti, atha buddhānaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhe iva dhamme paṭikacca aññam ārādheti no ce diṭṭhe iva dhamme paṭikacca aññam ārādheti  atha maraṇa kāle aññam ārādheti atha deva putto samānaḥ aññam ārādheti atha buddhānam
translated: “Ananda, there are these five advantages for one who is devoted to the preliminary work. What five? Here, Ananda, one devoted to the preliminary work succeeds in discerning what is wholesome and what unwholesome. If he does not succeed in discerning what is wholesome and what unwholesome in this very life,

original: sammukhībhāve khippābhiñño hoti, atha pacchime kāle paccekasambuddho hotī”ti.
analyzed: sammukhībhāve khippa abhiññaḥ hoti atha pacchime kāle paccekasambuddhaḥ hoti iti
translated: then at the time of death he succeeds in discerning what is wholesome and what unwholesome. If not, then as a god he succeeds in discerning what is wholesome and what unwholesome. If not, then when the Buddhas appear he succeeds in discerning what is wholesome and what unwholesome. If not, then in his last life he becomes a Private Buddha” .

original: Iti pubbabhāgapaṭipadābhūtāya pāramitāparibhāvitāya samathavipassanābhāvanāya nirodhagāminipaṭipadābhūtāya
analyzed: iti pubba bhāga paṭipadā bhūtāya pāramitā paribhāvitāya samatha vipassanā bhāvanāya nirodha gāmini paṭipadā bhūtāya
translated: Thus it is the development of serenity and insight that is the preliminary stage of the path, that is developed by the special qualities of giving, virtue, etc., that is the way leading to the cessation of suffering,

original: abhisamayasaṅkhātāya maggabhāvanāya ca bhāvitattabhāvā buddhapaccekabuddhabuddhasāvakā
analyzed: abhisamaya saṅkhātāya magga bhāvanāya ca bhāvi tatta bhāvāḥ buddha paccekabuddha buddha sāvakāḥ
translated: and the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples, who are the persons who have developed themselves by the development of the path called penetration.

original: bhāvitattā nāma. Tesu idha buddhasāvakā adhippetā.🔽Ettha ca “sīhānaṃvā”ti iminā therānaṃ sīhasamānavuttitādassanena attano paṭipakkhehi🔽anabhibhavanīyataṃ, te ca abhibhuyya pavattiṃ dasseti. “Sīhānaṃva nadantānaṃ…pe…
analyzed: bhāvita ttāḥ nāma tesu idha buddha sāvakāḥ adhippetā  ettha ca iminā therānam sīha samāna vutti tā dassanena attanaḥ paṭipakkhehi  te ca abhibhuyya pavattim dasseti sīhānam va nadantānam pe
translated: They are “developed” in virtue of that development. Herein, it is the disciples who are intended.🔽And here the expression “like lions” shows that the elders’ way of living is like that of lions, and so it shows that they are not overmastered by their opposites and that they live overcoming them.

original: gāthā”ti iminā theragāthānaṃ sīhanādasadisatādassanena tāsaṃ paravādehi anabhibhavanīyataṃ,
analyzed: gāthā ati iminā thera gāthānam sīha nāda sadisa tā dassanena tāsam paravādehi
translated: The expression “like the lion’s roar” shows that the elders’ verses are like the lion’s roar, and so it shows that they are not overmastered by other doctrines and that they live overcoming them.

original: te ca abhibhavitvā pavattiṃ dasseti. “Bhāvitattāna”nti iminā tadubhayassa kāraṇaṃ
analyzed: te ca abhibhavitvā pavattim dasseti iminā tad ubhayassa kāraṇam
translated: The expression “developed” shows the cause of both.

original: vibhāveti. Bhāvitattabhāvena therā idha sīhasadisā vuttā, tesañca gāthā sīhanādasadisiyo.
analyzed: vibhāva iti bhāvi tatta bhāvena therāḥ idha sīha sadisāḥ vuttā tesam ca gāthā sīha nāda sadisiyo
translated: The elders are called “like lions” here because they have developed themselves, and their verses are like the lion’s roar.

original: “Atthūpanāyikā”ti iminā abhibhavane payojanaṃ dasseti. Tattha therānaṃ paṭipakkho
analyzed: atthu upanāyikā ti iminā abhibhavane payojanam dasseti tattha therānam paṭipakkho
translated: The expression “of great meaning” shows the purpose of the overmastering. Herein, the elders’ opposites are

original: nāma saṃkilesadhammo, tadabhibhavo tadaṅgivikkhambhanappahānehi saddhiṃ samucchedappahānaṃ.
analyzed: nāma saṃkilesa dhammo tad abhibhavaḥ tad aṅgi vikkhambhana ppahānehi saddhim samuccheda ppahānam
translated: and the abandoning of the defilements by cutting them off together with the abandoning by suppression and by substitution of opposites is the abandoning by eradication.

original: Tasmiṃ sati paṭipassaddhīppahānaṃ nissaraṇappahānañca siddhameva hoti, yato te bhāvitattāti🔽vuccanti. Maggakkhaṇe hi ariyā appamādabhāvanaṃ bhāventi nāma, aggaphalakkhaṇato
analyzed: tasmin sati paṭipassaddhī ppahānam nissaraṇa ppahānam ca siddham eva hoti yatas te bhāvita ttā iti  vuccanti magga kkhaṇe hi ariyāḥ appamāda bhāvanam bhāventi nāma agga phala kkhaṇato
translated: When that is present, the abandoning by substitution of opposites and the abandoning by means of the escape are established too, and so it is said that “when they are developed”🔽the noble ones develop the development of diligence at the moment of the path.

original: paṭṭhāya bhāvitattā nāmāti vuttovāyamattho.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya bhāvita ttā nāma ati vuttaḥ uva ayam attho
translated: But the meaning stated is that they are called “developed” because they have been developed from the time of the first path onwards.

original: Tesu tadaṅgappahānena nesaṃ sīlasampadā dassitā, vikkhambhanappahānena samādhisampadā,
analyzed: tesu tad aṅga ppahānena nesam sīla sampadā dassitā vikkhambhana ppahānena samādhi sampadā
translated: Herein, their perfection of virtue is shown by the abandoning by substitution of opposites, their perfection of concentration by the abandoning by suppression,

original: samucchedappahānena paññāsampadā, itarena tāsaṃ phalaṃ dassitaṃ. Sīlena ca tesaṃ🔽paṭipattiyā ādikalyāṇatā dassitā, “ko cādi kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ? Sīlañca suvisuddhaṃ”,
analyzed: samuccheda ppahānena paññā sampadā itarena tāsam phalam dassitam sīlena ca tesam  paṭipattiyāḥ ādi kalyāṇa tā dassitā kusalānam dhammānam sīlam ca su visuddham
translated: their perfection of understanding by the abandoning by eradication, and their fruit by the abandoning by means of the escape.🔽And their virtue is shown as the beginning of their practice,🔽since it is said, “What is the beginning of profitable things? Virtue that is quite purified,”🔽“Having established virtue” , and “By abstention from all evil” .

original: “sīle patiṭṭhāya”, “sabbapāpassa akaraṇa”nti ca vacanato sīlaṃ paṭipattiyā ādikalyāṇaṃva
analyzed: sīle patiṭṭhāya sabba pāpassa akaraṇanti ca vacanato sīlam paṭipattiyā ādi kalyāṇam va
translated: So virtue is the beginning of practice that is good in the beginning,

original: avippaṭisārādiguṇāvahattā. Samādhinā majjhekalyāṇatā dassitā, “cittaṃ bhāvayaṃ”,🔽“kusalassa upasampadā”ti ca vacanato samādhipaṭipattiyā majjhekalyāṇova, iddhividhādiguṇāvahattā.
analyzed: a vippaṭisāra ādi guṇa āvaha ttā samādhinā majjhe kalyāṇa tā dassitā cittam bhāvayan  kusalassa upasampadā iti ca vacanataḥ samādhi paṭipattiyā majjhe kalyāṇaḥ uva iddhividha ādi guṇa āvaha ttā
translated: because it brings about the special qualities of non-remorse, and so on.🔽The excellence in the middle is shown by concentration, because of the words “Develops consciousness” and “The consummation of what is profitable” .

original: Paññāya pariyosānakalyāṇatā dassitā, “sacittapariyodapanaṃ”, “paññaṃ bhāvaya”nti
analyzed: paññāya pariyosāna kalyāṇa tā dassitā sa citta pariyodapanam paññam bhāvayanti
translated: The path of progress by means of concentration is only excellent in the middle because it brings about the special qualities of the kinds of direct-knowledge, and so on.

original: ca vacanato paññā paṭipattiyā pariyosānaṃva, paññuttarato kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ sāva
analyzed: ca vacanato paññā paṭipattiyā pariyosānam va paññuttarato kusalānam dhammānam
translated: The excellence at the end is shown by understanding, because of the words “The cleansing of consciousness” and “Develops understanding” .🔽The path of progress by means of understanding is only at the end because it is superior to the profitable states that are associated with the first two paths.

original: kalyāṇā iṭṭhāniṭṭhesu tādibhāvāvahattā.
analyzed: kalyāṇā iṭṭha aniṭṭhesu ta ādi bhāva āvahattā
translated: because it brings about the state of being the same in regard to what is agreeable or disagreeable.🔽As it is said:🔽“Just as a solid mass of rock

original: “Selo yathā ekaghano, vātena na samīrati; ;
analyzed: selaḥ yathā eka ghanaḥ vātena na samīrati
translated: Is not perturbed by the wind,🔽So the wise are not perturbed

original: Evaṃ nindāpasaṃsāsu, na samiñjanti paṇḍitā”ti. –
analyzed: evam nindā apasaṃsāsu na samiñjanti paṇḍita ati
translated: By blame or by praise” .

original: Hi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: hi vuttam
translated: is said.

original: Tathā sīlasampadāya tevijjabhāvo dassito. Sīlasampattiñhi nissāya tisso vijjā pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: tathā sīla sampadāya tevijja bhāvaḥ dassitaḥ sīla sampattim hi nissāya tissaḥ vijjā pāpuṇanti
translated: So too, the state of being one who has the three knowledges is shown by the perfection of virtue. For the three knowledges are reached by means of the perfection of virtue.

original: Samādhisampadāya chaḷabhiññābhāvo. Samādhisampattiñhi nissāya chaḷabhiññā pāpuṇanti.
analyzed: samādhi sampadāya samādhi sampattim hi nissāya chaḍ abhiññā pāpuṇanti
translated: The state of being one possessing the six kinds of direct-knowledge is shown by the perfection of concentration. For the six kinds of direct-knowledge are reached by means of the perfection of concentration.

original: Paññāsampadāya pabhinnapaṭisambhidābhāvo. Paññāsampadañhi nissāya catasso paṭisambhidā🔽pāpuṇanti. Iminā tesaṃ therānaṃ keci tevijjā, keci chaḷabhiññā, keci paṭisambhidāpattāti
analyzed: paññā sampadāya pabhinna paṭisambhidā bhāvo paññā sampadam hi nissāya catasso paṭisambhidā  pāpuṇanti iminā tesam therānam keci tevijjāḥ keci chaḍabhiññā keci paṭisambhidā pattā ati
translated: For the four discriminations are attained by depending on the perfection of wisdom.

original: ayamattho dassitoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ayam attho dassito ti veditabbam
translated: By this it should be understood that the meaning shown is that some of those elders were masters of the three knowledges, some were possessed of the six kinds of direct knowledge, and some had attained the discriminations.

original: Tathā sīlasampadāya tesaṃ kāmasukhānuyogasaṅkhātassa antassa parivajjanaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: tathā sīla sampadāya tesam kāma sukha anuyoga saṅkhātassa antassa parivajjanam dasseti
translated: Similarly, by the perfection of virtue he shows the avoidance of the extreme of indulgence in pleasure,

original: Samādhisampadāya attakilamathānuyogasaṅkhātassa, paññāsampadāya majjhimāya paṭipadāya🔽sevanaṃ dasseti. Tathā sīlasampadāya tesaṃ vītikkamappahānaṃ kilesānaṃ dasseti. Samādhisampadāya
analyzed: samādhi sampadāya atta kilamatha anuyoga saṅkhātassa paññā sampadāya majjhimāya paṭipadāya  sevanam dasseti tathā sīla sampadāya tesam vītikkama pahānam kilesānam dasseti samādhi sampadāya
translated: by the perfection of concentration the extreme of self-mortification, and by the perfection of wisdom the middle way.🔽Or alternatively, by the perfection of virtue he shows the abandoning of transgression, by the perfection of concentration the abandoning of obsession, and by the perfection of wisdom the abandoning of inherent tendency.

original: pariyuṭṭhānappahānaṃ, paññāsampadāya anusayappahānaṃ dasseti. Sīlasampadāya vā duccaritasaṃkilesavisodhanaṃ,
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhāna ppahānam paññā sampadāya anusaya ppahānam dasseti sīla sampadāya vā duccarita saṃkilesa visodhanam
translated: Or by the perfection of virtue he shows the purification of the defilement of misconduct,

original: samādhisampadāya taṇhāsaṃkilesavisodhanaṃ, paññāsampadāya diṭṭhisaṃkilesavisodhanaṃ
analyzed: samādhi sampadāya taṇhā saṃkilesa visodhanam paññā sampadāya diṭṭhi saṃkilesa visodhanam
translated: by the perfection of concentration the purification of the defilement of craving, and by the perfection of wisdom the purification of the defilement of views.

original: dasseti. Tadaṅgappahānena vā nesaṃ apāyasamatikkamo dassito. Vikkhambhanappahānena
analyzed: dasseti tad aṅga ppahānena vā nesam apāya samatikkamaḥ dassitaḥ vikkhambhana ppahānena
translated: Or else the transcending of the unhappy destinies is shown by the abandoning of the factors of those destinies.

original: kāmadhātusamatikkamo, samucchedappahānena sabbabhavasamatikkamo dassitoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: kāmadhātu samatikkamaḥ samuccheda ppahānena sabba bhava samatikkamaḥ dassito ti veditabbam
translated: The transcending of the sense-desire element is shown by the abandoning of the suppression of the defilements, and the transcending of all becoming is shown by the abandoning of the cutting off of the defilements.🔽Or else, here, in the passage beginning “having developed” there are three kinds of development to be understood,

original: “Bhāvitattāna”nti vā ettha sīlabhāvanā, cittabhāvanā paññābhāvanāti tisso bhāvanā
analyzed: vā ettha sīla bhāvanā citta bhāvanā paññā bhāvanā ti tissaḥ bhāvanā
translated: namely, development of virtue, development of concentration, and development of understanding.

original: veditabbā kāyabhāvanāya tadantogadhattā. Sīlabhāvanā ca paṭipattiyā ādīti sabbaṃ🔽purimasadisaṃ. Yathā pana sīhanādaṃ pare migagaṇā na sahanti, kuto abhibhave, aññadatthu
analyzed: veditabbā kāya bhāvanāya tad antogadha tā sīla bhāvanā ca paṭipattiyāḥ ādi iti sabbam  purima sadisam yathā pana sīha nādam pare miga gaṇāḥ na sahanti kutas abhibhave añña datthu
translated: And the development of virtue should be understood as included in the development of concentration, and all the rest as in the previous instance.

original: sīhanādova te abhibhavati evameva aññatitthiyavādā therānaṃ vāde na sahanti, kuto🔽abhibhave, aññadatthu theravādāva te abhibhavanti. Taṃ kissa hetu? “Sabbe saṅkhārā
analyzed: sīhanādaḥ uva te abhibhavati evam eva añña titthiya vādā therānam vāde na sahanti kutas  abhibhave thera vādāḥ ava te abhibhavanti tam kissa hetu sabbe saṅkhārā
translated: But just as the other herds of deer cannot stand the lion’s roar, so too the doctrines of the sectarians cannot stand the Elder’s doctrine,🔽and they are overwhelmed by it. Why is that? Because it proceeds thus: “All formations are impermanent, all formations are painful, all ideas are not self, the element of nibbana is pleasant,”

original: aniccā, sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā, sabbe dhammā anattā”ti “nibbānadhātū”ti ca pavattanato.
analyzed: aniccā sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā sabbe dhammā anattā ati nibbāna dhātū ti ca pavattanato
translated: and so on.

original: Na hi dhammato sakkā kenaci aññathā kātuṃ appaṭivattanīyato. Yaṃ panettha vattabbaṃ,🔽taṃ parato āvibhavissati. Evamettha saṅkhepeneva paṭhamagāthāya atthavibhāvanā veditabbā.
analyzed: na hi dhammataḥ sakkā kenacid aññathā kātum a paṭivattanīyataḥ yat pana ittha vattabbam  tam paratas āvibhavissati evam ettha saṅkhepena iva paṭhama gāthāya attha vibhāvanā veditabbā
translated: What has to be said here will be shown later.🔽This is how the commentary on the meaning of the first stanza should be understood in brief.

original: Dutiyagāthāyaṃ pana ayaṃ sambandhadassanamukhena atthavibhāvanā. Tattha yesaṃ therānaṃ
analyzed: dutiya gāthāyam pana ayam sambandha dassana mukhena attha vibhāvanā tattha yesam therānam
translated: As to the second stanza, the commentary on the meaning should be understood by way of the demonstration of the connection. Herein, those elders

original: gāthā sāvetukāmo, te sādhāraṇavasena nāmato gottato guṇato ca kittetuṃ “yathānāmā”tiādi
analyzed: te sādhāraṇa vasena nāmataḥ gottataḥ guṇataḥ ca kittetum yathā nāma ati ādi
