translated: So he reached Arahantship by developing insight with the goad as object, and then he made his own taming of his mind coincide with the taming of the ox and uttered the third stanza.

original: karonti. Namanavasena tacchakā nemiādīnaṃ atthāya tacchantā dāruṃ namayanti attano
analyzed: karonti namana vasena tad śakāḥ nemi ādīnam atthāya tad śantāḥ dārum namayanti
translated: Herein, the word ‘hi’ is merely a particle. ‘They lead the water’: they lead it to this or that place on the ground by digging a channel and filling in the low-lying places, or by making a dyke or by putting it in a bamboo tube, and so they lead it to the place they want. So they are ‘leaders’ . ‘They lead the fire’: they lead it by fanning it. This is what is meant. ‘Leaders’ lead water to the place they want according to their own wish. ‘Fan-makers’ lead fire by fanning it. They make it straight. ‘Fletchers’ make wood straight by planing it for the sake of arrows, etc., and so they lead it to the place they want.

original: ruciyā ujuṃ vā vaṅkaṃ vā karonti. Evaṃ ettakaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā subbatā yathāsamādinnena
analyzed: ruciyā ujum vā vaṅkam vā karonti evam ettakam ārammaṇam katvā subbatā yathā samādinnena
translated: They make it straight or crooked according to their wish. So far as the object is concerned, the wise, by means of the beauty of virtue, etc., as it was originally undertaken,

original: sīlādinā sundaravatā dhīrā sotāpattimaggādīnaṃ uppādentā attānaṃ damenti, arahattaṃ
analyzed: sīla ādinā sundaravatā dhīrā sa utāpatti magga ādīnam uppādentā attānam damenti arahattam
translated: cause themselves to be tamed by arousing the path of stream-entry, etc.,

original: pana pattesu ekantadantā nāma hontīti.
analyzed: pana pattesu ekanta dantāḥ nāma honti iti
translated: but when they have reached Arahantship they are completely tamed.

original: Kulattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽10. Ajitattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Maraṇe me bhayaṃ natthīti āyasmato ajitattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira ekanavute
analyzed: kula tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  ajita thera gāthā vaṇṇanā  maraṇe me bhayam natthi iti āyasmataḥ ajita therassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira ekanavute
translated: The commentary on the verses of the Elder Kulattha is ended.🔽The Elder Ajita

original: kappe vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ passitvā pasannacitto kapitthaphalaṃ adāsi. Tato parampi🔽taṃ taṃ puññaṃ katvā devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ kappe anuppanne eva amhākaṃ
analyzed: kappe vipassim bhagavantam passitvā pasanna cittaḥ kapittha phalam adāsi tato param pi  tam tam puññam katvā deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin kappe an uppanne eva amhākam
translated: “I have no fear of death” : this verse was uttered by the Elder Ajita. How did it arise? It seems that in the past, ninety-one eons ago, he saw the Blessed One Vipassi and, with a mind full of faith, gave him a wood-apple. From then on,

original: satthari sāvatthiyaṃ mahākosalarañño aggāsaniyassa brāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti.
analyzed: satthari sāvatthiyam mahākosala raññaḥ aggāsaniyassa brāhmaṇassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti
translated: having performed various meritorious deeds, he wandered through the heavenly world and the human world. When our Teacher had not yet appeared in this world, he was reborn as the son of a brahmin who was the chief counsellor to the king of Kosala at Savatthi.

original: Tassa ajitoti nāmaṃ ahosi. Tasmiñca samaye sāvatthivāsī bāvarī nāma brāhmaṇo tīhi
analyzed: tassa ajitaḥ iti nāmam ahosi tasmin ca samaye sāvatthi vāsī bāvarī nāma brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: His name was Ajita. At that time a brahmin named Bavari was living at Savatthi.

original: mahāpurisalakkhaṇehi samannāgato tiṇṇaṃ vedānaṃ pāragū sāvatthito nikkhamitvā tāpasapabbajjaṃ
analyzed: mahāpurisa lakkhaṇehi samannāgato tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū sa avatthitaḥ nikkhamitvā tāpasapabbajjam
translated: He was endowed with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, and he was a master of the Three Vedas. He left Sāvatthī and went forth into the ascetic life.

original: pabbajitvā godhāvarītīre kapitthārāme vasati. Atha ajito tassa santike pabbajito
analyzed: pabbajitvā godhāvarī tīre kapittha ārāme vasati atha ajito tassa santike pabbajitaḥ
translated: He went forth into the ascetic life in the presence of Ajita.

original: atthakāmāya devatāya coditena bāvarinā satthu santikaṃ pesito tissametteyyādīhi saddhiṃ
analyzed: attha kāmāya devatāya coditena bāvarinā satthu santikam pesitaḥ tissametteyya ādīhi saddhim
translated: He was sent to the Teacher by Bāvari, who was urged by a deity who wished him well. Together with Tissa Metteyya and others,

original: bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā manasāva pañhe pucchitvā tesu vissajjitesu pasannacitto
analyzed: bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā manasā ava pañhe pucchitvā tesu vissajjitesu pasanna cittaḥ

original: Idhāpi sālacchadanaṃ, hessati sabbakālikaṃ.
analyzed: idha api sāla chadanam hessati sabbakālikam
translated: Here, too, shall be a shelter, a shade of sala trees, all the year round.

original: “Mahāmuniṃ tosayitvā, gotamaṃ sakyapuṅgavaṃ;
analyzed: mahā munim tosayitvā gotamam sakya puṅgavam
translated: Having pleased the Great Seer, the Gotama, the Best of the Sakyans,

original: Pattomhi acalaṃ ṭhānaṃ, hitvā jayaparājayaṃ.
analyzed: acalam ṭhānam hitvā jaya parājayam
translated: I have attained the unshakable state, having abandoned victory and defeat.

original: “Aṭṭhārase kappasate, yaṃ buddhamabhipūjayiṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhārase kappa sate yam buddham abhipūjayiṃ
translated: For one hundred and eighteen aeons, I worshipped the Buddha;

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, buddhapūjāyidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi buddha pūjāya idam phalam
translated: I do not know of a bad destination, this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ, bhavā sabbe samūhatā;
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham sabbe
translated: My defilements are burnt up, all my existences are destroyed;

original: Nāgova bandhanaṃ chetvā, viharāmi anāsavo.
analyzed: nāgaḥ iva bandhanam chetvā viharāmi anāsavaḥ
translated: Like an elephant who has broken his bonds, I live without defilements.

original: “Svāgataṃ vata me āsi, buddhaseṭṭhassa santike;
analyzed: svāgatam vata me āsi buddha seṭṭhassa santike
translated: Welcome indeed was it to me, to be in the presence of the Best Buddha;

original: Tisso vijjā anuppattā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: tissaḥ vijjāḥ anuppattā katam buddhassa sāsanam
translated: The three knowledges have been attained, the instruction of the Buddha has been done.

original: “Paṭisambhidā catasso, vimokkhāpi ca aṭṭhime;
analyzed: paṭisambhidā catasso vimokkhā api ca aṭṭhime
translated: The four analytical knowledges, and the eight liberations as well;

original: Chaḷabhiññā sacchikatā, kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: chaṭṭhā abhiññā sacchikatā katam buddhassa sāsanam ti
translated: The six super-knowledges have been realised, the instruction of the Buddha has been done.”

original: Evaṃ pana chaḷabhiñño hutvā phalasukhena vītināmento sāsanassa niyyānikabhāvavibhāvanatthaṃ aññābyākaraṇavasena “nāhaṃ bhayassa bhāyāmī”ti gāthaṃ abhāsi.
analyzed: evam pana chaḷabhiññaḥ hutvā phala sukhena vītināmento sāsanassa niyyānika bhāva vibhāvana attham aññā byākaraṇa vasena na aham bhayassa bhāyāmi iti gātham abhāsi
translated: But having become one with the six knowledges, and while spending his time in the happiness of the fruits , in order to show the completeness of the Dispensation, he spoke this verse beginning, “I do not fear for the future,” by way of announcing his knowledge.

original: 21. Tattha bhāyanti etasmāti bhayaṃ, jātijarādi. Bhayassāti nissakke sāmivacanaṃ,🔽bhayato bhāyitabbanimittaṃ jātijarāmaraṇādinā hetunā nāhaṃ bhāyāmīti attho. Tattha🔽kāraṇamāha “satthā no amatassa kovido”ti. Amhākaṃ satthā amate kusalo veneyyānaṃ🔽amatadāne cheko. Yattha bhayaṃ nāvatiṭṭhatīti yasmiṃ nibbāne yathāvuttaṃ bhayaṃ na
analyzed: tattha bhāyanti etasmā ati bhayam jāti jarā ādi bhayassa ati nissakke sāmi vacanam  bhayataḥ bhāyitabba nimittam jāti jarā maraṇa ādinā hetunā na aham bhāyāmi iti tattha  kāraṇam āha satthā no amatassa kovidaḥ ti amhākam satthā amate kusalaḥ veneyyānam  amata dāne chekaḥ yattha bhayam na avatiṭṭhati iti yasmim nibbāne yathā vuttam bhayam na
translated: “Bhaya” is birth, aging, etc. “Bhayassu” is the instrumental case of the gerund “bhayato” ;🔽the meaning is: “I do not fear through the cause of fear, through the cause of what should be feared, through birth, aging, death, etc.” Herein,🔽he gives the reason: “Our teacher is skilled in the Deathless.” Our teacher is skilled in the Deathless, adept at giving the Deathless to disciples.🔽“Where fear does not exist” : in Nibbāna, the fear stated in the way just described does not exist.

original: tiṭṭhati okāsaṃ na labhati. Tenāti tato nibbānato. Vajantīti abhayaṭṭhānameva gacchanti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati okāsam na labhati tena ati tatas nibbānataḥ vajanti iti abhaya ṭṭhānam eva gacchanti
translated: Herein, fear is what is feared, namely birth, aging, and so on. From fear: the instrumental case is used in the sense of cause. The meaning is: I do not fear through the cause of fear, through the cause of what should be feared, namely birth, aging, death, and so on. Herein, he gives the reason: “Our teacher is skilled in the Deathless.” Our teacher is skilled in the Deathless, adept at giving the Deathless to disciples. Where fear does not exist: in that Nibbāna where the fear stated in the preceding line does not exist, does not occur. By that: by that Nibbāna. They go: they go to the place of fearlessness.

original: Nibbānañhi abhayaṭṭhānaṃ nāma. Kena pana vajantīti āha “maggena vajanti bhikkhavo”ti,🔽aṭṭhaṅgikena ariyamaggena satthu ovādakaraṇā bhikkhū saṃsāre bhayassa ikkhanakāti
analyzed: nibbānam hi abhaya ṭṭhānam nāma kena pana vajanti iti āha maggena vajanti bhikkhavaḥ ti  aṭṭhaṅgikena ariya maggena satthu ovāda karaṇā bhikkhū saṃsāre bhayassa ikkhanakā ati
translated: For Nibbāna is called the place of fearlessness. But by what do they go? He says: “The bhikkhus go by the path.”

original: attho. Yatthāti vā yaṃ nimittaṃ yassa ariyamaggassa adhigamahetu attānuvādādikaṃ
analyzed: atthaḥ yattha ati vā yam nimittam yassa ariya maggassa adhigama hetu atta anuvāda ādikam
translated: The bhikkhus who do the Teacher’s bidding go by the Noble Eightfold Path. The meaning is: they look for fear in the round of rebirths. Or else, yattha = yaṃ nimittaṃ, “the sign by which” is the meaning. The bhikkhus go by the path of the Noble Eightfold Path, the cause for attaining that Nibbāna. Attānuvādādikam = attānuvādādi.

original: pañcavīsatividhampi bhayaṃ nāvatiṭṭhati patiṭṭhaṃ na labhati, tena ariyena maggena
analyzed: pañcavīsatividham pi bhayam na avatiṭṭhati patiṭṭham na labhati tena ariyena maggena
translated: and the twenty-five kinds of fear do not stand firm, do not get a footing, by that Noble Path

original: vajanti abhayaṭṭhānaṃ satthu sāsane bhikkhū, tena maggena ahampi gato, tasmā nāhaṃ
analyzed: vajanti abhaya ṭṭhānam satthu sāsane bhikkhū tena maggena aham pi gataḥ tasmā na aham
translated: the monks go to the place of fearlessness in the Teacher’s Dispensation, and by that path I have gone, therefore

original: bhayassa bhāyāmīti thero aññaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: bhayassa bhāyāmi iti theraḥ aññam byākāsi
translated: I do not fear fear.” The Elder declared his enlightenment.

original: Nigrodhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: nigrodha tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Nigrodha is finished.

original: 2. Cittakattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: cittakatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: Cittaka’s Verses

original: Nīlāsugīvāti āyasmato cittakattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira padumuttarabuddhakālato
analyzed: nīlāsugīvā ti āyasmataḥ cittaka ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira padumuttara buddha kālataḥ
translated: Nīlāsugīvā. These are the verses of the venerable Cittaka. What is the origin of the story? It seems that beginning with the time of the Buddha Padumuttara

original: paṭṭhāya vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ ācinanto ito ekanavute kappe manussayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā
analyzed: paṭṭhāya vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam ācinantaḥ itas ekanavute kappe manussa yoniyam nibbattitvā
translated: he had accumulated profitable roots with open rebirth-linking, and after a period of nineteen incalculable ages and a 100,000 cycles he was reborn in the human world

original: viññuttaṃ patto vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ passitvā pasannamānaso pupphehi pūjaṃ katvā
analyzed: viññuttam pattaḥ vipassim bhagavantam passitvā pasanna mānasaḥ pupphehi pūjam katvā
translated: and, having become a lay devotee, he saw the Blessed One Vipassi and, his mind being confident, he worshipped with flowers

original: vanditvā “santadhammena nāma ettha bhavitabba”nti satthari nibbāne ca adhimucci.
analyzed: vanditvā santadhammena nāma ettha bhavitabbanti satthari nibbāne ca adhimucci
translated: and, after paying homage, he resolved thus: “There must be a good state of existence here” and he resolved on the extinction of the Master.

original: So tena puññakammena tato cuto tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbatto aparāparaṃ puññāni katvā
analyzed: so tena puñña kammena tatas cutaḥ tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbattaḥ apara aparam puññāni katvā
translated: By that profitable action he passed away and was reborn in the Abode of the Thirty-three, and after doing various good works

original: devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde rājagahe vibhavasampannassa brāhmaṇassa
analyzed: deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde rājagahe vibhavasampannassa brāhmaṇassa
translated: Passing from birth to birth among gods and men, he appeared in this Dispensation as the son of a wealthy brahmin

original: putto hutvā nibbatti cittako nāma nāmena. So bhagavati rājagahaṃ gantvā veḷuvane
analyzed: puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti cittakaḥ nāma nāmena saḥ bhagavati rājagaham gantvā veḷuvane
translated: in Rājagaha. He was called Citta. When the Blessed One went to Rājagaha and stayed in the Bamboo Grove,

original: viharante satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā cariyānukūlaṃ
analyzed: viharante satthāram upasaṅkamitvā dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā cariyā anukūlam
translated: he approached the Teacher, heard the Dhamma, and gained faith. He went forth and received a meditation subject suitable to his temperament.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā araññāyatanaṃ pavisitvā bhāvanānuyutto jhānaṃ nibbattetvā jhānapādakaṃ
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā arañña āyatanam pavisitvā bhāvanā anuyuttaḥ jhānam nibbattetvā jhāna pādakam
translated: He entered a forest and devoted himself to meditation. He produced the jhānas and developed insight based on the jhānas.

original: vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā nacireneva arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā nacirena iva arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Not long afterwards he reached Arahantship. Therefore it is said in the Apadāna:

original: “Kaṇikāraṃva jotantaṃ, nisinnaṃ pabbatantare;
analyzed: kaṇikāram iva jotantam nisinnam pabbata antare
translated: “Shining like a kanikara flower,

original: Addasaṃ virajaṃ buddhaṃ, vipassiṃ lokanāyakaṃ.
analyzed: addasam virajam buddham vipassim loka nāyakam
translated: I saw the dust-free Buddha, Vipassī, the Leader of the world.🔽I took three kanikara flowers

original: “Tīṇi kiṅkaṇipupphāni, paggayha abhiropayiṃ;
analyzed: tīṇi kiṅkaṇi pupphāni paggayha abhiropayiṃ
translated: and placed them in his bowl.🔽Having worshipped the Sambuddha,

original: Sambuddhaṃ abhipūjetvā, gacchāmi dakkhiṇāmukho.
analyzed: sambuddham abhipūjetvā gacchāmi dakkhiṇāmukhaḥ
translated: I went away facing south.🔽By that good deed well done,

original: “Tena kammena sukatena, cetanāpaṇidhīhi ca;
analyzed: tena kammena su katena cetanā paṇidhīhi ca
translated: and by my aspiration,🔽I abandoned the human body

original: Jahitvā mānusaṃ dehaṃ, tāvatiṃsaṃ agacchahaṃ.
analyzed: jahitvā mānusam deham tāvatiṃsam agaccha aham
translated: and went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.”

original: “Ekanavute ito kappe, yaṃ buddhamabhipūjayiṃ;
analyzed: ekanavute itas kappe yam buddham abhipūjayiṃ
translated: “For ninety-one eons past, I worshipped a Buddha,

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, buddhapūjāyidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi buddha pūjāya idam phalam
translated: And I do not recall any state of woe; this is the fruit of worshipping a Buddha.”

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are destroyed … I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā satthāraṃ vandituṃ rājagahaṃ upagato tattha bhikkhūhi “kiṃ,
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā satthāram vanditum rājagaham upagataḥ tattha bhikkhūhi kim
translated: But after attaining arahatship, he went to Rājagaha to pay homage to the Teacher. There the bhikkhus asked him, “Friend, what did you do, living heedfully in the forest?”🔽When he told them how he had lived heedfully, he uttered another utterance of reminiscence:

original: āvuso, araññe appamatto vihāsī”ti puṭṭho attano appamādavihāranivedanena aññaṃ byākaronto
analyzed: āvuso araññe appamatto vihāsi iti puṭṭhaḥ attanaḥ appamāda vihāra nivedanena aññam byākaronto
translated: “Blue-necked, well-necked, with crests, peacocks

original: “nīlāsugīvā”ti gāthaṃ abhāsi.🔽22. Tattha nīlāsugīvāti nīlasugīvā, gāthāsukhatthañhettha dīgho kato, rājivantatāya🔽sundarāya gīvāya samannāgatoti attho. Te yebhuyyena ca nīlavaṇṇatāya nīlā. Sobhanakaṇṭhatāya
analyzed: gātham abhāsi  tattha nīlāsugīvā ati nīlasugīvā gāthā sukhattham ha ittha dīghaḥ kataḥ rājivanta tāya  sundarāya gīvāya samannāgataḥ iti attho te yebhuyyena ca nīla vaṇṇa tāya nīlā sobhana kaṇṭha tāya
translated: In the Kāḷakhemaka jungle cry out.”

original: sugīvā. Sikhinoti matthake jātāya sikhāya sassirikabhāvena sikhino. Morāti mayūrā.
analyzed: su gīvā sikhinoti matthake jātāya sikhāya sassirika bhāvena sikhinaḥ morā ati mayūrā
translated: Herein, blue-necked, well-necked is blue-necked, well-necked. The long vowel is a metrical extension. The meaning is that he is endowed with a beautiful neck. And they are blue because they are mostly blue in colour. They are well-necked because their necks are beautiful. With crests is with crests on their heads, with crests on their heads. Peacocks is peafowl.

original: Kārambhiyanti kārambarukkhe. Kārambhiyanti vā tassa vanassa nāmaṃ. Tasmā kārambhiyanti
analyzed: kārambhiyanti kāramba rukkhe kārambhiyanti vā tassa vanassa nāmam tasmā kārambhiyanti
translated: In the Kāḷakhemaka jungle is in the Kāḷakhemaka jungle. Or Kāḷakhemaka is the name of that jungle. Therefore it is said: “In the Kāḷakhemaka jungle.”

original: kārambhanāmake vaneti attho. Abhinadantīti pāvussakāle meghagajjitaṃ sutvā kekāsaddaṃ🔽karontā utusampadāsiddhena sarena haṃsādike abhibhavantā viya nadanti. Teti te morā.
analyzed: kārambha nāmake vane ti atthaḥ abhinadanti iti pāvussa kāle megha gajjitam sutvā kekā saddam  karontāḥ utu sampadā asiddhena sarena haṃsa ādike abhibhavantāḥ viya nadanti te iti te morāḥ
translated: In the Kārambha forest, is the meaning. They call out: hearing the thunder of the clouds at the time of the rainy season, they make a sound like the cawing of crows.🔽They call out with a voice that is successful through the excellence of the season, as if outdoing the geese and so on. They: those peacocks.

original: Sītavātakīḷitāti sītena meghavātena sañjātakīḷitā madhuravassitaṃ vassantā. Suttanti
analyzed: sīta vāta kīḷitā ati sītena megha vātena sañjāta kīḷitā madhura vassitam vassantā suttanti
translated: Play in the cool breeze: they play in the cool breeze of the clouds, and they rain down sweet showers. They sleep:

original: bhattasammadavinodanatthaṃ sayitaṃ, kāyakilamathapaṭipassambhanāya vā anuññātavelāyaṃ
analyzed: bhatta sammada vinodana attham sayitam kāya kilamatha paṭipassambhanāya vā anuññāta velāyam
translated: they sleep for the purpose of removing the weariness of eating, or they sleep at the time permitted for the purpose of removing the fatigue of the body.

original: supantaṃ. Jhāyanti samathavipassanājhānehi jhāyanasīlaṃ bhāvanānuyuttaṃ. Nibodhentīti🔽pabodhenti. “Imepi nāma niddaṃ anupagantvā jāgarantā attanā kattabbaṃ karonti, kimaṅgaṃ
analyzed: supantam jhāyanti samatha vipassanā jhānehi jhāyana sīlam bhāvanā anuyuttam nibodhenti iti  pabodhenti ime api nāma niddam an upagantvā jāgarantāḥ attanā kattabbam karonti kimaṅgam
translated: They meditate: they are devoted to the development of meditation that is characterized by meditation on serenity and insight. They awaken:

original: panāha”nti evaṃ sampajaññuppādanena sayanato vuṭṭhāpentīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: pana ahanti evam sampajañña uppādanena sayanataḥ vuṭṭhāpenti iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: the intention is that they awaken them from sleep by saying: “Even these, without going to sleep, are awake and doing what should be done. What then of us?”

original: Cittakattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: cittakatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Citta is finished.

original: 3. Gosālattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: gosālatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Gosāla

original: Ahaṃ kho veḷugumbasminti āyasmato gosālattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Sopi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: aham kho veḷugumbasmin ti āyasmataḥ gosāla ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ api purima buddhesu
translated: I am the man who found a piece of wood, etc. This is the story of the Elder Gosāla.🔽What was the origin of this story? He too had formed his aspiration under former Buddhas,

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ kusalaṃ ācinanto ito ekanavute kappe
analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha vivaṭṭu upanissayam kusalam ācinantaḥ itas ekanavute kappe
translated: and had stored up the wholesome roots of merit by making his living by the practice of medicine.

original: aññatarasmiṃ pabbate rukkhasākhāyaṃ olambamānaṃ paccekabuddhassa paṃsukūlacīvaraṃ🔽disvā “arahaddhajo vatāya”nti pasannacitto pupphehi pūjehi. So tena puññakammena
analyzed: aññatarasmim pabbate rukkha sākhāyam olambamānam paccekabuddhassa paṃsukūla cīvaram  disvā arahat hajaḥ vatāyanti pasanna citto pupphehi pūjehi saḥ tena puñña kammena
translated: At the end of ninety-one cycles of time he was reborn in the Abode of the Thirty-three.

original: tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbatto. Tato paṭṭhāya devamanussesuyeva saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde
analyzed: tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbatto tatas paṭṭhāya deva manussesu yeva saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde
translated: From that time forth he passed from birth to birth in the families of gods and men, and in this dispensation🔽he was reborn in the family of a laborer in the kingdom of Magadha. His name was Gosāla.

original: magadharaṭṭhe ibbhakule nibbatto gosālo nāma nāmena. Soṇena pana koṭikaṇṇena kataparicayattā
analyzed: magadha raṭṭhe ibbha kule nibbattaḥ gosālaḥ nāma nāmena soṇena pana koṭikaṇṇena kata paricaya ttā
translated: But because he had formed an acquaintance with Soṇa Koṭikaṇṇa,

original: tassa pabbajitabhāvaṃ sutvā “sopi nāma mahāvibhavo pabbajissati, kimaṅgaṃ panāha”nti
analyzed: tassa pabbajita bhāvam sutvā saḥ api nāma mahā vibhavaḥ pabbajissati kim aṅgam pana ahanti
translated: when he heard that the latter had gone forth from home into the homeless state, he thought to himself, “If he, who was so great a lord, has gone forth from home into the homeless state, why should not I?”

original: sañjātasaṃvego bhagavato santike pabbajitvā cariyānukūlaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā sappāyaṃ
analyzed: sañjāta saṃvegaḥ bhagavato santike pabbajitvā cariyā anukūlam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā sappāyam
translated: And filled with remorse, he went to the Teacher, received the going forth under him, and taking up his abode in a place suitable for the practice of meditation,

original: vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gavesanto attano jātagāmassa avidūre ekasmiṃ sānupabbate vihāsi. Tassa
analyzed: vasana ṭṭhānam gavesantaḥ attanaḥ jāta gāmassa avidūre ekasmin sānupabbate vihāsi tassa
translated: Searching for a place to live, he dwelt on a mountain slope not far from his native village.

original: mātā divase divase bhikkhaṃ deti. Athekadivasaṃ gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭhassa mātā madhusakkharābhisaṅkhataṃ
analyzed: mātā divase divase bhikkham deti atha eka divasam gāmam piṇḍāya paviṭṭhassa mātā madhu sakkhara abhisaṅkhatam

analyzed: aññam byākarontaḥ api pitu pūjana attham kacci naḥ ti tam eva gātham abhāsi
translated: And when he was asked to make a declaration, he uttered the same verse, “Are you not wrapped in robes? ” in order to honour his father.

original: 28. Tattha kaccīti pucchāyaṃ nipāto. Noti paṭisedhe. Vatthapasutoti vatthe pasuto
analyzed: tattha kacci iti pucchā ayam nipātaḥ no ti paṭisedhe vattha pasuto ti vatthe pasuto
translated: Herein, kacci is a particle expressing a question. No is a denial. Vatthapasuto means wrapped in robes.

original: vatthapasuto, cīvaramaṇḍanābhirato. Nidassanamattañcetaṃ pattamaṇḍanādicāpallapaṭikkhepassāpi
analyzed: vattha pasutaḥ cīvara maṇḍana abhirataḥ nidassana mattam ca itam patta maṇḍana ādi cāpalla paṭikkhepassa api
translated: Vatthapasuto means wrapped in robes, devoted to adorning robes. But this is merely an illustration, since it is also intended to include the prohibition of adorning the bowl, etc.

original: adhippetattā. “Kacci na vatthapasuto”tipi pāṭho, so evattho. Bhūsanāratoti attabhāvavibhūsanāya
analyzed: adhippeta ttā kacci na pāṭho saḥ evatthaḥ bhūsana ārataḥ ti atta bhāva vibhūsanāya
translated: “Kacci na vatthapasuto” is also a reading, and it has the same meaning. Bhūsanārato means devoted to, intent upon, adorning the person.

original: rato abhirato, yathekacce pabbajitvāpi capalā kāyadaḷhibahulā cīvarādiparikkhārassa
analyzed: rataḥ abhirataḥ yathā ekacce pabbajitvā api capalā kāya daḷhi bahulā cīvara ādi parikkhārassa
translated: Some, though they have gone forth, are restless, with much bodily activity, devoted to adorning the requisites such as the robes, etc.,

original: attano sarīrassa ca maṇḍanavibhūsanaṭṭhānāya yuttā honti. Kimeva parikkhārapasuto
analyzed: attanaḥ sarīrassa ca maṇḍana vibhūsana ṭṭhānāya yuttāḥ honti kim eva parikkhāra pasuto
translated: They are fit for adorning and beautifying one’s own body. Why were you not intent on the equipment,

original: bhūsanārato ca nāhosīti ayamettha padadvayassāpi attho. Sīlamayaṃ gandhanti akhaṇḍādibhāvāpādanena
analyzed: ca ayam ettha pada dvayassa api attho sīla mayam gandhanti akhaṇḍa ādi bhāva āpādanena
translated: and why were you not fond of adorning? This is the meaning of the two terms here. As to the verse ‘The scent of virtue’ ,

original: suparisuddhassa catubbidhassapi sīlassa vasena yvāyaṃ “yo ca sīlavataṃ pajāti na🔽itarā dussīlapajā, dussīlattāyeva dussilyamayaṃ duggandhaṃ vāyati, evaṃ tvaṃ duggandhaṃ
analyzed: su parisuddhassa catubbidhassa api sīlassa vasena yvā ayam yaḥ ca sīlavatam pajāti na  itarā dussīla pajā dussīla ttāya iva dussilyam ayam dus gandham vāyati evam tvam dus gandham
translated: by means of the four kinds of virtue that have been purified by being uncracked, etc.,🔽the kind of virtue that is born of the virtuous is not the other kind that is born of the unvirtuous. Because of their unvirtue, the scent of unvirtue wafts from them. So you, not wafting the scent of unvirtue,

original: avāyitvā kacci sīlamayaṃ gandhaṃ vāyasīti attho. Atha vā netarā pajāti na itarā dussīlapajā,
analyzed: avāyitvā kacci sīla mayam gandham vāyasi iti attho atha vā na itarā pajāti na itarā dussīla pajā
translated: have you wafted the scent of virtue? This is the meaning. Or alternatively, the kind of virtue that is born of the virtuous is not the other kind that is born of the unvirtuous.

original: taṃ kacci na hoti, yato sīlamayaṃ gandhaṃ vāyasīti byatirekena sīlagandhavāyanameva vibhāveti.
analyzed: tam kacci na yatas sīla mayam gandham vāyasi iti byatirekena sīla gandha vāyanam eva vibhāvā iti
translated: Have you not been that? Since you have wafted the scent of virtue, he shows by a superlative that he wafts the scent of virtue.

original: Jambugāmiyaputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jambugāmiyaputta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the verses of the Elder Jambugāmiya’s son is ended.

original: 9. Hāritattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: The verses of the Elder Hārita

original: Samunnamayamattānanti āyasmato hāritattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira purimabuddhesu
analyzed: āyasmataḥ hārita ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira purima buddhesu
translated: Samunnamayamattānanti. This is the verse of the venerable Elder Hārita. How did it arise? It seems that in the past he

original: katādhikāro hutvā tattha tattha vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññasambhāraṃ upacinanto ito ekatiṃse
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ hutvā tattha tattha vivaṭṭu upanissayam puñña sambhāram upacinantaḥ itas ekatiṃse
translated: and after he had done so, he accumulated the requisites of merit in various places, and after the lapse of thirty-one aeons,

original: kappe sudassanaṃ nāma paccekasambuddhaṃ disvā pasannamānaso kuṭajapupphehi pūjaṃ
analyzed: kappe sudassanam nāma paccekasambuddham disvā pasanna mānasaḥ kuṭaja pupphehi pūjam
translated: he saw the Paccekabuddha named Sudassana, and with a devout heart he worshipped him with jasmine flowers.

original: katvā tena puññakammena sugatīsuyeva parivattento imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthinagare
analyzed: katvā tena puñña kammena sugatīsu yeva parivattentaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthi nagare
translated: By the power of that meritorious deed he passed from one happy state of existence to another, and in this generation of the Buddha he was reborn in the city of Sāvatthi

original: brāhmaṇamahāsālakule nibbatti. Hāritotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. Tassa vayappattassa mātāpitaro
analyzed: brāhmaṇa mahāsāla kule nibbatti hāritotissa nāmaṃ ahosi tassa vaya ppattassa mātā pitaraḥ
translated: in a great Brāhmaṇa family. His name was Hārita. When he had grown up his parents

original: kularūpādīhi anucchavikaṃ kumārikaṃ brāhmaṇadhītaraṃ ānesuṃ. So tāya saddhiṃ bhogasukhaṃ
analyzed: kula rūpa ādīhi anucchavikam kumārikam brāhmaṇa dhītaram ānesum saḥ tāya saddhim bhoga sukham
translated: brought him a Brāhmaṇa maiden, a suitable match for him in respect of family, beauty, and other accomplishments. He enjoyed the pleasures of life with her,

original: anubhavanto ekadivasaṃ attano tassā ca rūpasampattiṃ oloketvā dhammatāya codiyamāno
analyzed: anubhavantaḥ eka divasam attanaḥ tassā ca rūpa sampattim oloketvā dhamma tāya codiyamāno
translated: but one day, as he was looking at his own beauty and that of his wife, he was moved by the natural impulse of compassion,

original: “īdisaṃ nāma rūpaṃ nacirasseva jarāya maccunā ca abhippamaddīyatī”ti saṃvegaṃ paṭilabhi.
analyzed: īdisam nāma rūpam nacirassa iva jarāya maccunā ca abhippamaddīyati iti saṃvegam paṭilabhi
translated: and he was filled with a sense of urgency, thinking: “Such beauty as this will soon be destroyed by old age and death.”

original: Katipayadivasātikkameneva cassa bhariyaṃ kaṇhasappo ḍaṃsitvā māresi. So tena bhiyyosomattāya
analyzed: katipaya divasa atikkamena iva ca assa bhariyam kaṇha sappaḥ ḍaṃsitvā māresi saḥ tena bhiyyosomattāya
translated: After a few days had passed, a black snake bit his wife and killed her. He was filled with grief🔽and sorrow.

original: sañjātasaṃvego satthu santikaṃ gantvā dhammaṃ sutvā gharabandhane chinditvā pabbaji.
analyzed: sañjāta saṃvegaḥ satthu santikam gantvā dhammam sutvā ghara bandhane chinditvā pabbaji
translated: He went to the Teacher, heard the Dhamma, went forth, and cut off the fetter of householdership.

original: Tassa ca cariyānukūlaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā viharantassa kammaṭṭhānaṃ na sampajjati,
analyzed: tassa ca cariyā anukūlam kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā viharantassa kammaṭṭhānam na sampajjati
translated: He took up a meditation subject suitable to his own temperament and went to live in a forest. But his meditation subject did not progress,

original: cittaṃ ujugataṃ na hoti. So gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭho aññataraṃ usukāraṃ usudaṇḍaṃ yante
analyzed: cittam uju gatam na hoti saḥ gāmam piṇḍāya paviṭṭhaḥ aññataram usukāram usu daṇḍam yante
translated: and his mind did not become unified. As he was entering the village for alms, he saw a ploughman straightening a share by heating it red-hot and bending it with a stone.

original: pakkhipitvā ujuṃ karontaṃ disvā “ime acetanampi nāma ujuṃ karonti, kasmā ahaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: pakkhipitvā ujum karontam disvā ime acetanam pi nāma ujum karonti kasmai aham cittam
translated: “Even inanimate things are straightened by being heated,” he thought. “Why should I not straighten my mind by the fire of knowledge?”

original: ujuṃ na karissāmī”ti cintetvā tatova paṭinivattitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinno vipassanaṃ
analyzed: ujum na karissāmi iti cintetvā tatas va paṭinivattitvā divāṭṭhāne nisinnaḥ vipassanam
translated: He turned back at once, sat down in his day-quarters, and began to practice insight.

original: ārabhi. Athassa bhagavā upari ākāse nisīditvā ovādaṃ dento “samunnamayamattāna”nti
analyzed: ārabhi athassa bhagavā upari ākāse nisīditvā ovādam dentaḥ
translated: The Blessed One came and sat down in the air above him and gave him advice, saying, “Straighten yourself, O Bhikkhu.”

original: gāthaṃ abhāsi. Ayameva thero attānaṃ paraṃ viya ovadanto abhāsīti ca vadanti.🔽29. Tattha samunnamayanti sammā unnamento, samāpattivasena kosajjapakkhe patituṃ
analyzed: gātham abhāsi ayam eva theraḥ attānam param viyan ovadantaḥ abhāsi iti ca vadanti 🔽tattha samunnamayanti sammā unnamento samāpatti vasena kosajja pakkhe patitum
translated: They say that the Elder himself spoke this verse, advising himself as if he were another.

original: adatvā tato uddharanto vīriyasamataṃ yojentoti attho. Attānanti cittaṃ, atha vā samunnamayāti🔽kosajjapakkhato samunnamehi. Ma-kāro padasandhikaro. Hīnavīriyatāya tava cittaṃ kammaṭṭhānavīthiṃ
analyzed: a datvā tatas uddharantaḥ vīriya samatam yojento ti attho cittam atha vā samunnamayāti  kosajja pakkhataḥ samunnamehi makāro pada sandhi karaḥ hīna vīriya tāya tava cittam kammaṭṭhāna vīthim
translated: “Without taking out” means without applying the energy-balance. “Your own self” means the mind. Or else, “raise up” means raise up from the side of laziness.

original: nappaṭipajjati ce, taṃ vīriyārambhavasena sammā unnamehi, anonataṃ anapanataṃ karohīti
analyzed: na paṭipajjati ce tam vīriya ārambha vasena sammā unnamehi an onatam an apanatam karohi iti
translated: The syllable ma is a word-divider. If your mind does not enter the course of the meditation subject because of low energy, then raise it up by arousing energy. Make it neither stooping nor over-reaching.🔽This is the meaning. But when you do so, then “like a bee that finds a lotus-pond,

original: adhippāyo. Evaṃ pana karonto usukārova tejanaṃ. Cittaṃ ujuṃ karitvāna, avijjaṃ bhinda🔽hāritāti. Yathā nāma usukāro kaṇḍaṃ īsakampi onataṃ apanatañca vijjhanto lakkhaṃ🔽bhindanatthaṃ ujuṃ karoti, evaṃ kosajjapātato arakkhaṇena onataṃ uddhaccapātato arakkhaṇena
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ evam pana karontaḥ usukārā uva tejanam cittam ujum karitvāna avijjam bhinda  yathā nāma usukāro kaṇḍam onatam apanatam ca vijjhantaḥ lakkham  bhindana attham ujum karoti evam kosajja pātataḥ arakkhaṇena onatam uddhacca pātataḥ arakkhaṇena
translated: and having made the mind straight, pierce ignorance and break out.”

original: apanataṃ vijjhanto appanāpattiyā cittaṃ ujuṃ karitvāna samāhitacitto vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā
analyzed: apanatam vijjhantaḥ appanā āpattiyā cittam ujum karitvāna samāhita cittaḥ vipassanam ussukkāpetvā
translated: Just as a bee, when it finds a lotus-pond, makes the stalk straight by piercing it neither too deeply nor too superficially but at the right depth for the purpose of breaking the stalk, so too, by not guarding against falling into laziness you pierce the mind when it is stooping, and by not guarding against falling into restlessness you pierce it when it is over-reaching, and you make it straight for the purpose of attaining absorption. Having made the mind straight in this way, you should develop insight with a concentrated mind and strive to reach the plane of the noble ones.

original: sīghaṃ aggamaggañāṇena avijjaṃ bhinda padālehīti. Taṃ sutvā thero vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā
analyzed: sīgham agga magga ñāṇena avijjam bhinda padālehi iti tam sutvā theraḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: Having heard this, the Elder developed insight and

original: nacireneva arahā ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: nacirena iva arahā ahosi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: before long attained arahantship. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Himavantassāvidūre, vasalo nāma pabbato;
analyzed: himavantassa avidūre vasalaḥ nāma pabbato
translated: “Not far from the Himalayas, there is a mountain named Vasala;

original: Buddho sudassano nāma, vasate pabbatantare.
analyzed: buddhaḥ sudassanaḥ nāma vasate pabbata antare
translated: A Buddha named Sudassana dwelt in the midst of that mountain.

original: “Pupphaṃ hemavantaṃ gayha, vehāsaṃ agamāsahaṃ;
analyzed: puppham hemavantam gayha vehāsam agama asaham
translated: “Taking a golden flower, I went through the air;

original: Tatthaddasāsiṃ sambuddhaṃ, oghatiṇṇamanāsavaṃ.
analyzed: sambuddham ogha tiṇṇa manāsavam
translated: There I saw the Sambuddha, who had crossed over the flood and was free from taints.

original: “Pupphaṃ kuṭajamādāya, sīse katvānahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: puppham kuṭajam ādāya sīse katvā an aham tadā
translated: “Taking a flower of the kuṭaja tree, I placed it on my head;

original: Buddhassa abhiropesiṃ, sayambhussa mahesino.
analyzed: buddhassa abhiropesim sayambhussa mahesinaḥ
translated: I offered it to the Buddha, the Great Sage who is self-become.

original: “Ekatiṃse ito kappe, yaṃ pupphamabhipūjayiṃ;
analyzed: ekatiṃse itas kappe yam puppham abhipūjayiṃ
translated: “Thirty-one eons ago, I paid homage with a flower;

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, pupphapūjāyidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi puppha pūjāya idam phalam
translated: I do not recall any state of woe; this is the fruit of paying homage with a flower.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are destroyed … the Buddha’s teaching has been done.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā aññaṃ byākarontopi tameva gāthaṃ abhāsi.🔽Hāritattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā aññam byākarontaḥ api tam eva gātham abhāsi  hārita thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: But after attaining arahantship, he uttered the same verse in his declaration of final knowledge.🔽The commentary on the verses of the Elder Hārita is finished.

original: 10. Uttiyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: uttiya thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the Elder Uttiya is finished.

original: Ābādhe me samuppanneti āyasmato uttiyattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira purimabuddhesu🔽katādhikāro tattha tattha vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññaṃ upacinanto ito catunavute kappe
analyzed: ābādhe me samuppannā iti āyasmataḥ uttiya ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira purima buddhesu  kata adhikāro tattha tattha vivaṭṭu upanissayam puññam upacinantaḥ itas catunavute kappe
translated: In a previous birth he had made a vow to become a Buddha.

original: siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle candabhāgāya nadiyā mahārūpo susumāro hutvā nibbatto.
analyzed: siddhatthassa bhagavataḥ kāle candabhāgāya nadiyā mahārūpaḥ susumāraḥ hutvā nibbattaḥ
translated: In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa he was a great fish in the river Ganges.

original: So pāraṃ gantuṃ nadiyā tīraṃ upagataṃ bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannacitto pāraṃ netukāmo🔽tīrasamīpe nipajji. Bhagavā tassa anukampāya piṭṭhiyaṃ pāde ṭhapesi. So haṭṭho udaggo
analyzed: saḥ pāram gantum nadiyāḥ tīram upagatam bhagavantam disvā pasanna cittaḥ pāram netu kāmaḥ  tīra samīpe nipajji bhagavā tassa anukampāya piṭṭhiyam pāde ṭhapesi saḥ haṭṭhaḥ udaggo
translated: One day he saw the Buddha on the bank of the river, and being filled with joy, he resolved to carry the Buddha across the river.🔽He lay down on the bank, and the Buddha, moved with compassion, placed his foot on the fish’s back.

original: pītivegena diguṇussāho hutvā sotaṃ chindanto sīghena javena bhagavantaṃ paratīraṃ🔽nesi. Bhagavā tassa cittappasādaṃ oloketvā “ayaṃ ito cuto devaloke nibbattitvā tato
analyzed: pītivegena diguṇussāhaḥ hutvā sotam chindantaḥ sīghena javena bhagavantam para tīram  nesi bhagavā tassa citta ppasādaṃ oloketvā ayam itas cutaḥ deva loke nibbattitvā tatas
translated: The fish, filled with joy and gladness, doubled his strength and, cutting the stream of the river, carried the Buddha to the other side with great speed.

original: paṭṭhāya sugatīsuyeva saṃsaranto ito catunavute kappe amataṃ pāpuṇissatī”ti byākaritvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya sugatīsuyā iva saṃsarantaḥ itas catunavute kappe amatam pāpuṇissati iti byākaritvā pakkāmi
translated: The Buddha, beholding the faith of the fish, said, “After you have passed hence, you will be reborn in the World of the Gods, and thenceforth you will pass from one state of bliss to another until at the end of ninety-four cycles of time you shall attain Nibbāna.” So saying, he departed.

original: So tathā sugatīsuyeva paribbhamanto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa
analyzed: saḥ tathā su gatīsuyā iva paribbhamantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa
translated: Wandering thus in happy states of existence, he was reborn in this Buddha-epoch as the son of a certain Brahman in Sāvatthi,

original: putto hutvā nibbatti uttiyo nāma nāmena. So vayappatto “amataṃ pariyesissāmī”ti paribbājako
analyzed: puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti uttiyaḥ nāma nāmena saḥ vaya pattaḥ amatam pariyesissāmi iti paribbājakaḥ
translated: and received the name of Uttiya. When he had reached years of maturity, he said to himself, “I will seek the Deathless.” Accordingly he became a wanderer,

original: hutvā vicaranto ekadivasaṃ bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ sutvā sāsane pabbajitvāpi
analyzed: hutvā vicarantaḥ eka divasam bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā dhammam sutvā sāsane pabbajitvā api
translated: and while wandering about, one day he approached the Exalted One and listened to the Law. He retired from the world and became a monk under the Buddha,

original: sīlādīnaṃ avisodhitattā visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ asakkonto aññe bhikkhū visesaṃ nibbattetvā
analyzed: sīla ādīnam a visodhita ttā visesam nibbattetum a sakkontaḥ aññe bhikkhū visesam nibbattetvā
translated: but because he had not purified his morality, he was unable to produce the Supernatural Faculties. He saw other monks produce the Supernatural Faculties

original: aññaṃ byākaronte disvā satthāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā saṅkhepeneva ovādaṃ yāci. Satthāpi
analyzed: aññam byākaronte disvā satthāram upasaṅkamitvā saṅkhepena iva ovādam yāci satthā api
translated: and make their declaration of the Paths and the Fruits. Accordingly he approached the Teacher and asked him for advice. The Teacher

original: tassa “tasmātiha tvaṃ, uttiya, ādimeva visodhehī”tiādinā saṅkhepeneva ovādaṃ adāsi.🔽So tassa ovāde ṭhatvā vipassanaṃ ārabhi. Tassa āraddhavipassanassa ābādho uppajji.
analyzed: tassa tasmā ati ha tvam uttiye ādim eva visodhehi iti ādinā saṅkhepena iva ovādam adāsi  so tassa ovāde ṭhatvā vipassanam ārabhi tassa āraddha vipassanassa ābādhaḥ uppajji
translated: gave him advice in brief, saying, “Therefore, Uttiya, purify first of all the beginning.”🔽Uttiya, following the advice of the Teacher, began the practice of insight. As he was engaged in the practice of insight, he became afflicted with a disease.

original: Uppanne pana ābādhe sañjātasaṃvego vīriyārambhavatthuṃ katvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto
analyzed: uppanne pana ābādhe sañjāta saṃvegaḥ vīriya ārambha vatthum katvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ
translated: But when the disease had arisen, he was filled with remorse, and making the arising of the disease a reason for the exercise of energy, he continued the practice of insight.

original: vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: vipassanam ussukkāpetvā arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: and after he had aroused his insight he attained Arahatship. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Candabhāgānadītīre, susumāro ahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: candabhāgā nadī tīre susumāraḥ aham tadā
translated: “On the bank of the Candabhagi River, I was a tortoise then,

translated: Herein, without old age means free from old age. He said this referring to Nibbāna. For that is without old age because it is unborn. analyzed: theraḥ aho andha bālā nāma evam paṭipajjati iti cintetvā kiñci avatvā uṭṭhāya āsanā  araññam eva gataḥ tam āraññakāḥ bhikkhū kim āvuso ati lahum nivattosi ñātakehi
translated: The elder thought, “How blind and foolish are women! They behave like this even towards one like me.” Without saying anything, he rose from his seat🔽and went away to the forest. The forest-dwelling bhikkhus asked him, “Why, friend, did you return so soon? Your kinsfolk did not see you.”

original: na diṭṭhosī”ti pucchiṃsu. Thero tattha pavattiṃ ācikkhanto “anāsannavarā etā”ti gāthaṃ abhāsi.
analyzed: na diṭṭho asi iti pucchiṃsu thero tattha pavattim ācikkhantaḥ anāsanna varāḥ etā ti gātham abhāsi
translated: The elder explained what had happened, and he uttered the stanza, “These women are not good.”

original: 34. Tattha anāsannavarāti etā itthiyo na āsannā anupagatā, dūre eva vā ṭhitā hutvā
analyzed: tattha anāsannavarā ti etāḥ itthiyaḥ na āsannāḥ anupagatāḥ dūre eva vā ṭhitāḥ hutvā
translated: Herein, these women are not good means these women are not good, have not come near, are far away,

original: varā purisassa seṭṭhā hitāvahā, tañca kho niccameva sabbakālameva, na rattimeva,
analyzed: varā purisassa seṭṭhā hita āvahā tat ca kho niccam eva sabbakālam eva na rattim eva
translated: and are the best, the most helpful, for a man, and that always, at all times, not just at night.

original: na divāpi, na rahovelāyapi. Vijānatāti vijānantena. “Anāsannaparā”tipi pāḷi, so evattho.
analyzed: na divā api na vijānatā ati vijānantena saḥ evatthaḥ
translated: nor by day, nor in private. Knowing: knowing. The text has “not to be approached like a boon,” but the meaning is the same.

original: Ayañhettha adhippāyo – caṇḍahatthiassamahiṃsasīhabyagghayakkharakkhasapisācāpi manussānaṃ
analyzed: ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ manussānam
translated: The intention here is this. Even wild elephants, horses, bulls, lions, tigers, leopards, ogres, and demons are not to be approached by men,

original: anupasaṅkamanto varā seṭṭhā, na anatthāvahā, te pana upasaṅkamantā diṭṭhadhammikaṃyeva
analyzed: an upasaṅkamantaḥ varā seṭṭhā na anattha āvahā te pana upasaṅkamantā diṭṭhadhammikam yeva
translated: but they are a boon, the best, not a source of harm. But when they approach, they would only do harm in this present life.

original: anatthaṃ kareyyuṃ. Itthiyo pana upasaṅkamitvā diṭṭhadhammikaṃ samparāyikaṃ vimokkhanissitampi
analyzed: anattham kareyyuṃ itthiyaḥ pana upasaṅkamitvā diṭṭhadhammikam samparāyikam vimokkha nissitam pi
translated: But women, having approached, destroy the good of this life and the next, and even the good that is based on deliverance.

original: atthaṃ vināsetvā mahantaṃ anatthaṃ āpādenti, tasmā anāsannavarā etā niccameva vijānatāti.🔽Idāni tamatthaṃ attūpanāyikaṃ katvā dassento “gāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha gāmāti gāmaṃ.
analyzed: attham vināsetvā mahantam anattham āpādenti tasmai anāsanna varāḥ etāḥ niccam eva vijānata ati  idāni tam attham attūpanāyikam katvā dassentaḥ gāma ati ādim āha tattha gāma ati gāmam
translated: They bring about great harm. Therefore they are not to be approached like a boon. Always know them thus.🔽Now, showing that meaning by making it his own, he said “villages,” etc. Herein, villages means a village.

original: Upayogatthe hi etaṃ nissakkavacanaṃ. Araññamāgammāti araññato āgantvā. Ma-kāro padasandhikaro,
analyzed: upayoga atthe hi etam nissakka vacanam araññam āgamma iti araññataḥ āgantvā makāro pada sandhi karo
translated: For this is a locative in the sense of resort. Having come to the forest: having come from the forest. The syllable ma is a connector of words.

original: nissakke cetaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Tatoti mañcakato. Anāmantetvāti anālapitvā purāṇadutiyikaṃ🔽“appamattā hohī”ti ettakampi avatvā. Posiyoti attānameva paraṃ viya vadati. Ye pana
analyzed: nissakke ca itam upayoga vacanam tatas ti mañcakataḥ an āmantetvā ati an ālapitvā purāṇadutiyikam  appamattā hohi iti ettakam pi avatvā posiyā iti attānam eva param viya vadati ye pana
translated: “In the open air” means in a place not covered by a roof. “From that”: from the bed. “Without informing”: without telling the former wife.🔽“Be careful” is not even said. “My wife”: he speaks of himself as if he were another. But those who read “I will go”

original: “pakkāmi”nti paṭhanti, tesaṃ ahaṃ posiyo pakkāminti yojanā. Ye pana “sā itthī theraṃ🔽gharaṃ upagataṃ bhojetvā palobhetukāmā jātā, taṃ disvā thero tāvadeva gehato nikkhamitvā
analyzed: pakkāmin ti paṭhanti tesam aham posiyo pakkāmin ti yojanā ye pana sā itthī theram  gharam upagatam bhojetvā palobhetu kāmā jātā tam disvā theraḥ tāvat eva gehataḥ nikkhamitvā
translated: should construe it thus: “I will go, my wife.” But those who say that🔽“the woman, having fed the elder who had come to the house, became desirous of seducing him. Seeing this, the elder immediately left the house

original: vihāraṃ gantvā attano vasanaṭṭhāne mañcake nisīdi. Sāpi kho itthī pacchābhattaṃ alaṅkatapaṭiyattā
analyzed: vihāram gantvā attanaḥ vasanaṭṭhāne mañcake nisīdi sā api kho itthī pacchābhattam alaṅkata paṭiyattā
translated: and went to the monastery, where he sat down on his bed in his own dwelling place. The woman, after the meal, adorned and attired,

original: vihāre therassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ upasaṅkami. Taṃ disvā thero kiñci avatvā uṭṭhāya divāṭṭhānameva
analyzed: vihāre therassa vasana ṭṭhānam upasaṅkami tam disvā thero kiñci avatvā uṭṭhāya divāṭṭhānam eva
translated: went to the elder’s dwelling place in the monastery. Seeing her, the elder got up without saying anything and went to his day-quarters.”

original: gato”ti vadanti, tesaṃ “gāmā araññamāgammā”ti gāthāpadassa attho yathārutavaseneva
analyzed: gataḥ ti vadanti tesam gāmā araññam āgamma ati gāthā padassa attho yathā ruta vasena iva
translated: for them the meaning of the line “from the village to the forest” is taken literally.

original: niyyati. Vihāro hi idha “arañña”nti adhippeto.
analyzed: niyyati vihāraḥ hi idha araññanti adhippeto
translated: For here the monastery is what is meant by “forest.”

original: Posiyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: posiya thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Posiya is finished.

original: 5. Sāmaññakānittheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Sukhaṃ sukhatthoti āyasmato sāmaññakānittherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira purimabuddhesu
analyzed: sukham sukha attho ti āyasmataḥ sāmaññakāni therassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira purima buddhesu
translated: The Elder Sāmaññakāni

original: katādhikāro hutvā tattha tattha bhave kusalaṃ upacinanto ito ekanavute kappe vipassissa🔽bhagavato kāle manussayoniyaṃ nibbatto vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannamānaso ekaṃ
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ hutvā tattha tattha bhave kusalam upacinantaḥ itas ekanavute kappe vipassissa  bhagavato kāle manussa yoniyam nibbattaḥ vipassim bhagavantam disvā pasanna mānasaḥ ekam
translated: “Happiness for the sake of happiness”: this verse was spoken by the Elder Sāmaññakāni. How did it originate? He had performed meritorious deeds under former Buddhas,🔽and in the dispensation of the Blessed One Vipassī, after he had passed through a cycle of existences in the heavenly world and the human world, he was reborn in a human womb.

original: mañcaṃ adāsi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde aññatarassa
analyzed: mañcam adāsi saḥ tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde aññatarassa
translated: Seeing the Blessed One Vipassī, he was filled with joy and gave him a couch.🔽By that meritorious deed he passed from one state of existence to another, and in this dispensation he was reborn as the son of a certain wanderer.

original: paribbājakassa putto hutvā nibbatti. Sāmaññakānītissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So viññutaṃ patto🔽satthu yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ disvā pasannamānaso sāsane pabbajitvā cariyānukūlaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: paribbājakassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti sāmaññakānītissa nāmam ahosi saḥ viññutam pattaḥ  satthu yamaka pāṭihāriyam disvā pasanna mānasaḥ sāsane pabbajitvā cariyā anukūlam kammaṭṭhānam
translated: His name was Sāmaññakāni. When he had reached years of discretion,🔽he saw the Twin Miracle performed by the Teacher, and being filled with joy, he went forth in the Dispensation and obtained the going forth and the full admission.🔽He took up a meditation subject suitable to his temperament,

original: gahetvā jhānaṃ nibbattetvā jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: gahetvā jhānam nibbattetvā jhānam pādakam katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: and after developing it, he reached Arahantship.

original: Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Vipassino bhagavato, lokajeṭṭhassa tādino;
analyzed: vipassinaḥ bhagavataḥ loka jeṭṭhassa tādinaḥ
translated: “To Vipassi, the Lord, the world’s chief, the peerless one,

original: Ekaṃ mañcaṃ mayā dinnaṃ, pasannena sapāṇinā.
analyzed: ekam mañcam mayā dinnam pasannena sa pāṇinā
translated: I gave a couch, with faith in my heart.🔽“I rode in chariots drawn by elephants and horses,

original: “Hatthiyānaṃ assayānaṃ, dibbayānaṃ samajjhagaṃ;
analyzed: hatthi yānam assa yānam dibba yānam sa majjhagam
translated: and in divine vehicles, too,

original: Tena mañcaka dānena, pattomhi āsavakkhayaṃ.
analyzed: tena mañcaka dānena pattomhi āsava kkhayam
translated: By the gift of that couch, I attained the destruction of the taints.

original: “Ekanavutito kappe, yaṃ mañcamadadiṃ tadā;
analyzed: ekanavutitaḥ kappe yam mañcamadadim tadā
translated: “For ninety-one eons, since I gave that couch,

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, mañcadānassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi mañca dānaḥ idam phalam
translated: I do not recall any state of woe; this is the fruit of the gift of the couch.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.🔽Therassa pana gihisahāyako kātiyāno nāma paribbājako buddhuppādato paṭṭhāya titthiyānaṃ
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti  therassa pana gihi sahāyakaḥ kātiyānaḥ nāma paribbājakaḥ buddhuppādato paṭṭhāya titthiyānam
translated: “My defilements are destroyed … The Buddha’s teaching is done.”🔽But the Elder’s lay friend, the wanderer named Katyayana,🔽from the time of the Buddha’s appearance had been deprived of gain and honour by the sectarians.

original: hatalābhasakkāratāya ghāsacchādanamattampi alabhanto ājīvakāpakato theraṃ upasaṅkamitvā🔽“tumhe sākiyaputtiyā nāma mahālābhaggayasaggappattā sukhena jīvatha, mayaṃ pana dukkhitā
analyzed: hata lābha sakkāra tāya ghāsa chādana mattam pi a labhantaḥ theram upasaṅkamitvā  tumhe sākiya puttiyāḥ nāma sukhena jīvatha mayam pana dukkhitā
translated: Unable to get even food and clothing, he left the Ajivakas and approached the Elder,🔽saying, “You Sakyan-son monks live in comfort, having attained great gain and fame, but we are miserable.🔽We have difficulty in making a living. How should one live to find happiness

original: kicchajīvikā, kathaṃ nu kho paṭipajjamānassa diṭṭhadhammikañceva samparāyikañca sukhaṃ
analyzed: kiccha jīvikā katham nu kho paṭipajjamānassa diṭṭhadhammikañca ca iva samparāyikañca sukham
translated: in this world and the next?

original: sampajjatī”ti pucchi. Athassa thero “nippariyāyato sukhaṃ nāma lokuttarasukhameva,
analyzed: sampajjati iti pucchi athassa theraḥ nippariyāyataḥ sukham nāma lokuttara sukham eva
translated: and the Elder replied, “The ultimate happiness is the supramundane happiness.

original: tañca tadanurūpaṃ paṭipattiṃ paṭipajjantassevā”ti attanā tassa adhigatabhāvaṃ pariyāyena
analyzed: tat ca tad anurūpam paṭipattim paṭipajjantassa iva ati attanā tassa adhigata bhāvam pariyāyena
translated: That is obtained only by one who practices the way that is appropriate to it.”

original: vibhāvento “sukhaṃ sukhattho labhate tadācara”nti gāthaṃ abhāsi.
analyzed: vibhāvento sukham sukhatthaḥ labhate tad ācaranti gātham abhāsi
translated: So he spoke the verse, “The one who seeks happiness will find it by practicing the way that leads to happiness.”🔽Herein, happiness is the kind of happiness intended here is the supramundane happiness.

original: 35. Tattha sukhanti nirāmisaṃ sukhaṃ idhādhippetaṃ. Tañca phalasamāpatti ceva nibbānañca.
analyzed: tattha sukham ti nirāmisam sukham idha adhippetam tat ca phala samāpatti ca iva nibbānam ca
translated: And that is both the attainment of fruition and Nibbāna.

original: Tathā hi “ayaṃ samādhi paccuppannasukho ceva āyatiñca sukhavipāko” “nibbānaṃ paramaṃ
analyzed: tathā hi ayam samādhi paccuppanna sukhaḥ ca iva āyatim ca sukha vipākaḥ nibbānam paramam
translated: For it is said, “This concentration is pleasant now and in the future” , and “Nibbāna is the ultimate happiness” .

original: sukha”nti ca vuttaṃ. Sukhatthoti sukhappayojano, yathāvuttena sukhena atthiko. Labhateti
analyzed: sukham ti ca vuttam sukha atthaḥ ti sukha ppayojanaḥ yathā vuttena sukhena atthikaḥ labhateti
translated: The one who seeks happiness is the one who seeks the happiness stated thus, who is desirous of it.🔽Will find it: will obtain it. This happiness is for the one who seeks it, not for the other.

original: pāpuṇāti, atthikassevedaṃ sukhaṃ, na itarassa. Ko pana atthikoti āha “tadācara”nti
analyzed: pāpuṇāti atthikassa iva idam sukham na itarassa kaḥ pana atthikaḥ iti āha tat ācaranti
translated: But who is the one who seeks it? The verse says:

original: tadatthaṃ ācaranto, yāya paṭipattiyā taṃ paṭipattiṃ paṭipajjantoti attho. Na kevalaṃ
analyzed: tad attham ācarantaḥ yāya paṭipattiyā tam paṭipattim paṭipajjantaḥ iti atthaḥ na kevalam
translated: The one who practices the way that leads to it. The meaning is: the one who practices the way that leads to that happiness.🔽Not only does the one who practices the way that leads to happiness find happiness, but also

original: tadācaraṃ sukhameva labhate, atha kho kittiñca pappoti “itipi sīlavā suparisuddhakāyavacīkammanto
analyzed: sukham eva labhate atha kho kittim ca pappoti sīlavā su parisuddha kāya vacī kammanto
translated: He gains happiness by his practice. And then he gains fame, in the form of the hundredfold reputation that spreads abroad in all directions, as follows: “He is virtuous, his bodily and verbal behaviour are well purified,

original: suparisuddhājīvo jhāyī jhānayutto”tiādinā kittiṃ parammukhā patthaṭayasataṃ pāpuṇāti.🔽Yasassa vaḍḍhatīti sammukhe guṇābhitthavasaṅkhāto parivārasampadāsaṅkhāto ca yaso
analyzed: su parisuddha ājīvaḥ jhāyī jhāna yuttaḥ ti ādinā kittim parammukhā patthaṭaya satam pāpuṇāti  yasassa vaḍḍhati iti sammukhe guṇa abhitthava saṅkhāto ca yasaḥ
translated: he is a meditator, devoted to meditation” and so on.🔽His fame increases: his reputation, called “following” because it is a following of those who proclaim his special qualities,

original: assa paribrūhati. Idāni “tadācara”nti sāmaññato vuttamatthaṃ sarūpato dassento –🔽“yo ariyamaṭṭhaṅgikamañjasaṃ ujuṃ, bhāveti maggaṃ amatassa pattiyā”ti āha. Tassattho
analyzed: assa paribrūhati idāni tat ācaranti sāmaññataḥ vuttam attham sarūpataḥ dassento  yaḥ ariyam aṭṭhaṅgikam añjasam ujum bhāveti maggam amatassa pattiyā iti āha tassa atthaḥ
translated: increases in the direction of his face. Now, in order to show the meaning stated in a general way in the words “by his practice,” he said, “Who develops the noble right concentration with its supports,” etc.

original: yo puggalo kilesehi ārakattā parisuddhaṭṭhena paṭipajjantānaṃ ariyabhāvakaraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: yaḥ puggalaḥ kilesehi āraka ttā parisuddha ṭṭhena paṭipajjantānam ariya bhāva karaṇa ṭṭhena
translated: The meaning is this. Who develops the noble path, which is called “noble” because it is purified by being free from defilements, and because it causes the noble state of the noble person to arise,

original: ariyaṃ, sammādiṭṭhiādiaṭṭhaṅgasamudāyatāya aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ, antadvayarahitamajjhimapaṭipattibhāvato
analyzed: ariyam sammādiṭṭhi ādi aṭṭhaṅga samudāya tāya aṭṭhaṅgikam anta dvaya rahitam ajjhima paṭipatti bhāvato
translated: which is called “right concentration” because it is the culmination of steadiness of mind, which is called “with its supports” because it is accompanied by the factors that accompany concentration, which is called “the eight-factored path” because it is the collection of the eight factors beginning with right view, which is called “straight” because it is the middle way free from the two extremes,

original: akuṭilaṭṭhena añjasaṃ, kāyavaṅkādippahānato ujuṃ, nibbānatthikehi magganiyaṭṭhena
analyzed: akuṭila ṭṭhena añjasam kāya vaṅka ādi ppahānataḥ ujum nibbāna atthikehi magganiya ṭṭhena
translated: which is called “direct” because it is the way to the deathless for those who seek Nibbāna, which is called “the noble path” because it is the way to the state of the noble person.

original: kilese mārento gamanaṭṭhena ca “magga”nti laddhanāmaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminipaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: kilese mārentaḥ gamana ṭṭhena ca magganti laddha nāmam dukkha nirodha gāmini paṭipadam
translated: and he develops the path, which is called “path” in the sense of going, since it goes to the destruction of defilements,

original: amatassa asaṅkhatāya dhātuyā pattiyā adhigamāya bhāveti attano santāne uppādeti vaḍḍheti
analyzed: amatassa asaṅkhatāya dhātuyā pattiyā adhigamāya bhāveti attano santāne uppādeti vaḍḍheti
translated: for the attainment, for the realization of the unformed element, which is deathless. He generates it, increases it in his cognizance.

original: ca, so nippariyāyena “sukhattho tadācara”nti vuccati, tasmā yathāvuttaṃ sukhaṃ labhati.
analyzed: ca saḥ nippariyāyena sukha atthaḥ tat ācaranti vuccati tasmai yathā vuttam sukham labhati
translated: He is called “one who goes for the sake of happiness” in the true sense, and so he obtains the happiness stated thus.

original: Taṃ sutvā paribbājako pasannamānaso pabbajitvā sammā paṭipajjanto nacirasseva vipassanaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā paribbājakaḥ pasanna mānasaḥ pabbajitvā sammā paṭipajjantaḥ nacirassa iva vipassanam
translated: When the wanderer heard that, he became confident, and after going forth he made his way rightly and in no long time

original: vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Idameva therassa aññābyākaraṇaṃ ahosi.
analyzed: vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇi idam eva therassa aññā byākaraṇam ahosi
translated: he increased his insight and reached Arahantship. This was his declaration of final knowledge.

original: Sāmaññakānittheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sāmaññakānitthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Sāmaññakāni is finished.

original: 6. Kumāputtattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Sādhu sutanti āyasmato kumāputtattherassa gāthā. Kā uppati? So kira purimabuddhesu
analyzed: kumāputta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā  sādhu sutanti āyasmataḥ kumāputta therassa gāthā saḥ kira purima buddhesu
translated: The Elder Kumāputta’s Verses

original: katādhikāro ito ekanavute kappe ajinacammavasano tāpaso hutvā bandhumatīnagare rājuyyāne
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ itas ekanavute kappe ajina camma vasanaḥ tāpasaḥ hutvā bandhumatī nagare rāja uyyāne
translated: The Elder Kumāputta’s verses. Where was this verse uttered? They say that in the past, in one of the intervals between two Buddhas, he was a forest-dwelling ascetic wearing a dress of antelope hide. He was living in the royal park in Bandhumati.

original: vasanto vipassiṃ bhagavantaṃ passitvā pasannamānaso pādabbhañjanatelaṃ adāsi. So
analyzed: vasantaḥ vipassim bhagavantam passitvā pasanna mānasaḥ pādabbhañjana telam adāsi saḥ
translated: and while he was living there he saw the Lord Buddha Vipassi and gave him oil for anointing his feet.

original: tena puññakammena devaloke nibbatto. Tato paṭṭhāya sugatīsuyeva saṃsaranto imasmiṃ
analyzed: tena puñña kammena deva loke nibbatto tatas paṭṭhāya sugatīsuyā iva saṃsarantaḥ imasmin
translated: By that root of merit he was reborn in the world of the gods. Thenceforth, wandering in happy states of existence,

original: buddhuppāde avantiraṭṭhe veḷukaṇṭakanagare gahapatikule nibbatto. “Nando”tissa nāmaṃ

translated: They say: He made the water stand still: he did not allow it to flow on, but made it stand still like a mountain peak, turning it into a great mass of water. translated: They say: “He made the water stand still”: he made the water stand still like a mountain peak by turning back the current without allowing it to flow on. “Asita”: he is “asita” because he is free from craving and views, or because he is unfettered by any fetter since he has severed all the fetters called “bonds.” Since he is free from the defilements called “dust,” he is “dustless.” “The bull of the herd”: he is “the bull of the herd” because he is the chief of the herd of great sages. “Gone beyond all ties”: he is “gone beyond all ties” because he has gone beyond all the ties consisting of lust, hatred, delusion, conceit, and views. “The great sage”: he is “the great sage” because he is a sage of the highest grade. “Gone to the far shore of existence”: he is “gone to the far shore of existence” because he has gone to the far shore of existence, which is Nibbāna, and which is of the nature of the destruction of sense-desire, etc. “The gods worship him”: the gods worship him, much more so other kinds of beings.

analyzed: vālavedhi rūpaḥ satthu kappo tumhākam mātula ttheraḥ āgataḥ tasmā samaṇa saññam upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: “As if to sew up the hair-splitters” means like a needle to sew up hair-splitters. Therefore, establishing the perception of a recluse,

original: satisampajaññayuttā eva hutvā viharatha, “yathādhigate vihāre appamattā bhavathā”ti.

translated: live with mindfulness and full awareness, and be heedful in the dwellings you have already attained.

original: Taṃ sutvā te sāmaṇerā dhammasenāpatissa paccuggamanādivattaṃ katvā ubhinnaṃ mātulattherānaṃ
analyzed: tam sutvā te sāmaṇerāḥ dhammasenāpatissa paccuggamana ādi vattam katvā ubhinnam mātulattherānam
translated: When they had heard this, the novices, after doing homage to the General of the Dhamma,

analyzed: paṭisanthāra velāyam na atidūre samādhim samāpajjitvā nisīdiṃsu dhamma senāpati revata therena  saddhim paṭisanthāram katvā uṭṭhāya āsanā te sāmaṇere upasaṅkami te tathā kāla paricchedassa  there upasaṅkamante eva uṭṭhahitvā vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu thero katara katara vihārena  viharatha ati pucchitvā tehi imāya imāya ati vutte dārake pi nāma evam vinentaḥ mayham
translated: sat down not far away, each one in his own meditation. The General of the Dhamma, after doing homage with the Elder Revata,

original: bhātiko paccapādi vata dhammassa anudhamma”nti theraṃ pasaṃsanto pakkāmi.
analyzed: bhātiko paccapādi vata dhammassa anudhammanti theram pasaṃsanto pakkāmi
translated: rose from his seat and approached the novices. They rose up to meet the Elder because they knew the time had come for him to arrive. They paid homage to him and stood to one side. He is a good man indeed who trains novices thus.” And he went on his way praising the Elder.

original: Khadiravaniyattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khadiravaniya thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Khadiravaniya is finished.

original: 3. Sumaṅgalattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: sumaṅgala tthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Sumangala

original: Sumuttikoti āyasmato sumaṅgalattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Sopi purimabuddhesu katādhikāro
analyzed: su muttikā ti āyasmataḥ sumaṅgala ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ api purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ
translated: Sumuttiko. This is said of the venerable Elder Sumangala. What is the origin of the story? He too had made his living by the craft of a weaver in the time of former Buddhas.

original: tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññaṃ upacinanto siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle
analyzed: tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam puññam upacinantaḥ siddhatthassa bhagavato kāle
translated: there, in various existences, accumulating merit, the support for the turning about of the basis, in the time of the Fortunate One Siddhattha,

original: rukkhadevatā hutvā nibbatti. So ekadivasaṃ satthāraṃ nhāyitvā ekacīvaraṃ ṭhitaṃ disvā🔽somanassappatto hutvā apphoṭesi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ
analyzed: rukkhadevatā hutvā nibbatti saḥ eka divasam satthāram nhāyitvā eka cīvaram ṭhitam disvā  somanassa pattaḥ hutvā apphoṭesi so tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin
translated: and in various existences he accumulated merit, the support for his deliverance. In the time of the Buddha Siddhattha he was reborn as a tree-spirit. One day he saw the Teacher standing in his one robe after bathing,🔽and he was filled with joy. He rubbed the robe. By that root of merit he passed through happy states of existence and was reborn in the time of the present Buddha.

original: buddhuppāde sāvatthiyā avidūre aññatarasmiṃ gāmake tādisena kammanissandena daliddakule
analyzed: buddhuppāde sāvatthiyāḥ avidūre aññatarasmin gāmake tādisena kamma nissandena dalidda kule
translated: In a certain village not far from Sāvatthi he was reborn in a poor family,

original: nibbatti. Tassa sumaṅgaloti nāmaṃ ahosi. So vayappatto khujjakāsitanaṅgalakuddālaparikkhāro🔽hutvā kasiyā jīvati. So ekadivasaṃ raññā pasenadikosalena bhagavato bhikkhusaṅghassa
analyzed: nibbatti tassa sumaṅgalaḥ iti nāmam ahosi saḥ vaya patto khujja kāsita naṅgala kuddāla parikkhāro  hutvā kasiyā jīvati saḥ eka divasam raññā pasenadi kosalena bhagavataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa
translated: as the result of similar deeds. His name was Sumangala. When he grew up he became a laborer, carrying a hoe and a basket,🔽and he made a living by working in the fields. One day the king Pasenadi Kosala was making a great offering to the Buddha and the community of monks.

original: ca mahādāne pavattiyamāne dānopakaraṇāni gahetvā āgacchantehi manussehi saddhiṃ dadhighaṭaṃ
analyzed: ca mahādāne pavattiyamāne dāna upakaraṇāni gahetvā āgacchantehi manussehi saddhim dadhi ghaṭam
translated: As men were going about with the requisites for the offering, carrying a pot of curd,

analyzed: gahetvā āgataḥ bhikkhūnam sakkāra sammānam disvā ime samaṇā sakyaputtiyā sukhumavattha sunivatthā
translated: and seeing the respect and honour shown to the monks, he thought, “These ascetics, sons of the Sakyans, are wearing fine clothes and good robes,

original: subhojanāni bhuñjitvā nivātesu senāsanesu viharanti, yaṃnūnāhampi pabbajeyya”nti
analyzed: su bhojanāni bhuñjitvā nivātesu senāsanesu viharanti yat nūna aham pi pabbajeyyanti
translated: eating good food, and living in sheltered dwellings. Suppose I were to go forth?”

original: cintetvā, aññataraṃ mahātheraṃ upasaṅkamitvā attano pabbajjādhippāyaṃ nivedesi. So🔽taṃ karuṇāyanto pabbājetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhi. So araññe viharanto ekavihāre nibbinno
analyzed: cintetvā aññataram mahā theram upasaṅkamitvā attanaḥ pabbajja adhippāyam nivedesi so  tam karuṇāyantaḥ pabbājetvā kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhi so araññe viharantaḥ eka vihāre nibbinno
translated: After thinking thus, he approached a certain senior monk and told him of his desire to go forth.🔽The senior monk, out of compassion, gave him the going forth and instructed him in the meditation subject.🔽While he was living in the forest, he became discontented and restless.

original: ukkaṇṭhito hutvā, vibbhamitukāmo ñātigāmaṃ gacchanto antarāmagge kacchaṃ bandhitvā

original: khettaṃ kasante kiliṭṭhavatthanivatthe samantato rajokiṇṇasarīre vātātapena phussante
analyzed: khettam kasante kiliṭṭhavattha nivatthe samantataḥ rajaḥ kiṇṇa sarīre vāta ātapena phussante
translated: Their clothes were soiled and their bodies were covered with dust, and they were suffering from the heat of the sun and the exertion of their work.

original: kassake disvā, “mahantaṃ vatime sattā jīvikanimittaṃ dukkhaṃ paccanubhontī”ti saṃvegaṃ
analyzed: kassake disvā mahantam vatime sattāḥ jīvika nimittam dukkham paccanubhonti iti saṃvegam
translated: He thought, “Beings undergo great suffering for the sake of livelihood,”

original: paṭilabhi. Ñāṇassa paripākaṃ gatattā yathāgahitaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ upaṭṭhāsi. So aññataraṃ
analyzed: paṭilabhi ñāṇassa paripākam gata ttā yathā gahitam kammaṭṭhānam upaṭṭhāsi so aññataram
translated: and he was deeply moved. And because his knowledge had reached maturity, the meditation subject he had been given presented itself. He went to the senior monk🔽and told him what had happened.

analyzed: rukkha mūlam upagantvā vivekam labhitvā yonisas manasikarontaḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: and after going to the root of a tree and obtaining seclusion and developing insight by means of careful attention,

translated: he reached Arahantship by the order of the paths. Therefore it was said in the Apadāna:

analyzed: nhātvā pitvā ca sambuddhaḥ uttaritvā eka cīvaraḥ
translated: After bathing and drinking, the Fully Enlightened One, after emerging, wearing one robe,

analyzed: aṭṭhāsi bhagavā tattha vilokentaḥ disodisam

analyzed: bhavane upaviṭṭhaḥ oham addasam lokanāyakam
translated: I, after sitting in the dwelling, saw the Leader of the World,

analyzed: haṭṭhaḥ haṭṭhena cittena apphoṭesim aham tadā
translated: and with a joyful mind, I clapped my hands at that time.

original: “Sataraṃsiṃva jotantaṃ, pabhāsantaṃva kañcanaṃ;
analyzed: sa taraṃsim iva jotantam pabhāsantam iva kañcanam
translated: Like a flame, like a lamp, shining like gold,

analyzed: nacca gīte payutta ūham pañcaṅga tūriyamhi ca
translated: I was devoted to dancing and singing, and to the five-piece orchestra.

original: “Yaṃ yaṃ yonupapajjāmi, devattaṃ atha mānusaṃ;
analyzed: yam yam deva ttam atha mānusam
translated: Wherever I was reborn, as a god or a human being,

analyzed: sabbe satte abhibhomi vipulaḥ hoti me yaso
translated: I overcame all beings, and my fame was great.

original: “Namo te purisājañña, namo te purisuttama;
analyzed: namaḥ te purisājañña namaḥ te purisuttama
translated: “Honour to you, O Wise One, honour to you, O Supreme One,

analyzed: attānam tosayitvāna pare tosesi tvam muni
translated: after satisfying yourself, you satisfied others, O Sage.

analyzed: pariggahe nisīditvā hāsam katvāna subbate
translated: “Having sat down in the midst of the crowd, and having laughed, Subhaddā,

analyzed: upaṭṭhahitvā sambuddham tusitam upapajjaham
translated: Having served the Sambuddha, I was reborn in the Tusita heaven.

analyzed: kappa sate dvi nava eka cintitā
translated: “For sixteen hundred eons, for twenty-nine times,

analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are destroyed… I have done what had to be done for the Buddha’s Dispensation.”

analyzed: arahattam pana patvā sampattim attano dukkha vimuttiñca kittana vasena udānam udānentaḥ sumuttikā iti ādim āha
translated: But having attained arahatship, he uttered this exalted utterance in terms of his own attainment and his liberation from suffering: “Sumuttiko.”

analyzed: tattha su muttikaḥ ti sundarā accantika tāya apunabbhavikā mutti etassa ati su muttikaḥ
translated: Herein, sumuttiko means he who has a good, excellent, and very close liberation, a non-recurrent liberation.

original: Tassa pana vimuttiyā pāsaṃsiyatāya acchariyatāya ca apphoṭento āha “sumuttiko”ti.
analyzed: tassa pana vimuttiyā pāsaṃsiya tāya acchariya tāya ca apphoṭentaḥ āha su muttikā ti
translated: But, in order to praise and marvel at his liberation, he said: “Sumuttiko.”

analyzed: puna tattha vimuttiyam attanaḥ pasādassa daḷha bhāvam dassento sāhu su muttikaḥ aham iti
translated: Again, in order to show the strength of his confidence in that liberation, he said: “Sāhu sumuttikomhi.”

original: āha. “Sādhu suṭṭhu muttiko vatamhī”ti attho. “Kuto panāyaṃ sumuttikatā”ti? Kāmañcāyaṃ
analyzed: āha sādhu suṭṭhu muttikaḥ vatamhi iti attho kutas pana ayam su muttika tā ati kāmañca ayam

original: thero sabbasmāpi vaṭṭadukkhato suvimutto, attano pana tāva upaṭṭhitaṃ ativiya aniṭṭhabhūtaṃ
analyzed: thero sabbasmā api vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ su vimuttaḥ attanaḥ pana tāva upaṭṭhitam ativiya aniṭṭha bhūtam
translated: The Elder was well liberated from all suffering in the round of rebirths. But he showed that he had a very undesirable suffering still remaining to him.

original: dukkhaṃ dassento “tīhi khujjakehī”tiādimāha. Tattha khujjakehīti khujjasabhāvehi,
analyzed: dukkham dassentaḥ tīhi khujjakehi itiādim āha tattha khujjakehi iti khujja sabhāvehi

analyzed: khujja ākārehi vā nissakka vacanam ca itam mutta sadda apekkhāya kassakaḥ hi a khujjaḥ api samānaḥ  tīsu ṭhānesu attānam khujjam katvā dasseti lāyane kasane kuddāla kamme ca yaḥ hi pana
translated: or with three things that have a crooked appearance. This is a locative of cause. For a ploughman, even though he is not crooked,🔽shows himself to be crooked in three places, namely, in the ploughing, in the sowing, and in the work of the spade and basket.

original: kassako lāyanādīni karoti, tānipi asitādīni kuṭilākārato khujjakānīti vuttaṃ “tīhi khujjakehī”ti.
