analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgha parivutam vihārataḥ nikkhantam disvā pasanna cittaḥ pupphehi pūjam katvā
translated: departing from the monastery surrounded by the Congregation of Bhikkhus. Filled with joy, he paid worship with flowers,

original: pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu
analyzed: pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi so tena puñña kammena deva manussesu
translated: and after worshipping him with the Fivefold Prostration, he departed, walking around him to the right. By reason of this meritorious deed,

original: saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ hatthārohakule nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto
analyzed: saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam hatthāroha kule nibbattitvā viññutam pattaḥ
translated: he passed from one state of existence to another, and was finally reborn in the time of the present Buddha, in a certain family of elephant-drivers in the city of Sāvatthi. When he had grown up,

original: hatthisippe nipphattiṃ agamāsi. So ekadivasaṃ hatthiṃ sikkhāpento nadītīraṃ gantvā
analyzed: hatthi sippe nipphattim agamāsi saḥ eka divasam hatthim sikkhāpentaḥ nadī tīram gantvā
translated: he became skilled in the art of training elephants. One day, while training an elephant, he went to the bank of a river,

original: hetusampattiyā codiyamāno “kiṃ mayhaṃ iminā hatthidamanena, attānaṃ damanameva vara”nti
analyzed: hetu sampattiyā codiyamānaḥ kim mayham iminā hatthidamanena attānam damanam eva varanti
translated: and as he was being urged on by the power of the root of merit which he had acquired in the past, he said to himself, “What is the use of my training this elephant? It would be far better for me to train myself.”

original: cintetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvāva cariyānukūlaṃ
analyzed: cintetvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā ava cariyā anukūlam
translated: Having thought thus, he approached the Blessed One, heard the Dhamma, gained faith, went forth, and took up a meditation subject suitable for his temperament.🔽While he was doing his meditation subject, his mind, which had been long accustomed to the external meditation subject,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto ciraparicayena kammaṭṭhānato bahiddhā🔽vidhāvantaṃ cittaṃ cheko hatthācariyo viya aṅkusena caṇḍamattavaravāraṇaṃ paṭisaṅkhānaaṅkusena
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ cira paricayena kammaṭṭhānataḥ bahiddhā  vidhāvantam cittam chekaḥ hatthācariyaḥ viya aṅkusena caṇḍa matta vara vāraṇam paṭisaṅkhāna aṅkusena
translated: went out of doors. He controlled it with the goad of reflection,🔽just as a clever elephant driver controls a wild elephant in rut with the goad. He spoke the stanza:

original: niggaṇhanto “idaṃ pure cittamacāri cārika”nti gāthaṃ abhāsi.🔽77. Tattha idanti vuccamānassa cittassa attapaccakkhatāya vuttaṃ. Pureti niggahakālato
analyzed: niggaṇhantaḥ idam pure cittam acāri cārikanti gātham abhāsi  tattha idam ti vuccamānassa cittassa atta paccakkha tāya vuttam purā iti niggaha kālataḥ
translated: “This mind that wandered formerly,🔽I will now control with effort.

original: pubbe. Acārīti vicari, anavaṭṭhitatāya nānārammaṇesu paribbhami. Cārikanti yathākāmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: pubbe acāri iti vicari anavaṭṭhita tāya nānā ārammaṇesu paribbhami cārikanti yathākāma cariyam
translated: Herein, this is said: “This” is said of the mind that is being spoken of. It is said in order to make it evident to the mind itself. “Formerly” is before the time of control. “Wandered” : it roamed, it wandered about among various objects because it was not kept under control. “Wandering” : wandering as it pleased.

original: Tenāha “yenicchakaṃ yatthakāmaṃ yathāsukha”nti. Tanti taṃ cittaṃ. Ajjāti etarahi.
analyzed: tena āha yenicchakam yatthakāmam yathāsukhanti tanti tam cittam etarahi
translated: Hence it is said: “As it liked, wherever it liked, as it pleased” . “That” : that mind. “Now” : at present.

original: Niggahessāmīti niggaṇhissāmi, nibbisevanaṃ karissāmi. Yonisoti upāyena. Yathā kiṃ?
analyzed: niggahessāmi iti niggaṇhissāmi nibbisevanam karissāmi yonisaḥ iti upāyena yathā kim
translated: “I will control” : I will control it, I will make it not wander. “With effort” : with means. How?

original: Hatthippabhinnaṃ viya aṅkusaggaho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – idaṃ mama cittaṃ nāma ito pubbe
analyzed: hatthi ppabhinnam viya aṅkusa ggahaḥ idam vuttam hoti idam mama cittam nāma itas pubbe
translated: This is the meaning: This mind of mine, in the past,

original: rūpādīsu ārammaṇesu yena yena ramituṃ icchati, tassa tassa vasena yenicchakaṃ, yattha
analyzed: rūpa ādīsu ārammaṇesu yena yena ramitum icchati tassa tassa vasena yenicchakam
translated: went wherever it liked, to whatever object it desired, such as visible forms, etc.,

original: yattha cassa kāmo, tassa tassa vasena yatthakāmaṃ, yathā yathā vicarantassa sukhaṃ🔽hoti, tatheva caraṇato yathāsukhaṃ dīgharattaṃ cārikaṃ acari, taṃ ajjapāhaṃ bhinnamadamattahatthiṃ
analyzed: yattha ca assa kāmaḥ tassa tassa vasena yatthakāmam yathā yathā vicarantassa sukham  hoti tathā iva caraṇataḥ yathāsukham dīgharattam cārikam acari tam ajjapāham bhinna mada matta hatthim
translated: and roamed about as it pleased, wherever it wished,🔽and thus it wandered about for a long time in a way that was agreeable to itself. But today I will control it with right reflection,

original: hatthācariyasaṅkhāto cheko aṅkusaggaho aṅkusena viya yonisomanasikārena niggahessāmi,
analyzed: hattha ācariya saṅkhāto chekaḥ aṅkusa ggahaḥ aṅkusena viya yoniso manasikārena niggahessāmi
translated: like a skilled driver controls an elephant in rut with a hook.🔽I will not allow it to transgress.”

original: nāssa vītikkamituṃ dassāmīti. Evaṃ vadanto eva ca thero vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: na assa vītikkamitum dassāmi iti evam vadantaḥ eva ca theraḥ vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam
translated: And as he spoke thus, the Elder developed insight,🔽and realized Arahantship.

original: sacchākāsi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Suvaṇṇavaṇṇo sambuddho, vipassī dakkhiṇāraho;
analyzed: suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ sambuddhaḥ vipassī dakkhiṇā raho
translated: “The Buddha Vipassi, fair of complexion, worthy of offerings,🔽went forth from the monastery,

original: Purakkhato sāvakehi, ārāmā abhinikkhami.
analyzed: purakkhataḥ sāvakehi ārāmā abhinikkhami
translated: with his disciples in front of him.

original: “Disvānahaṃ buddhaseṭṭhaṃ, sabbaññuṃ tamanāsakaṃ;
analyzed: disvān aham buddha seṭṭham sabbaññum tam anāsakam
translated: “When I saw the best of Buddhas, the all-knowing one, the crusher of Mara’s power,

original: Pasannacitto sumano, gaṇṭhipupphaṃ apūjayiṃ.
analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ gaṇṭhi puppham apūjayiṃ
translated: With heart serene and glad, I worshipped with a Gaṇṭhi flower.

original: “Tena cittappasādena, dvipadindassa tādino;
analyzed: tena citta ppasādena dvipad indassa tādinaḥ
translated: “By that serenity of heart, of the Leader of the Two-footed, the Tathāgata,

original: Haṭṭho haṭṭhena cittena, puna vandiṃ tathāgataṃ.🔽“Ekanavutito kappe, yaṃ pupphamabhiropayiṃ;
analyzed: haṭṭhaḥ haṭṭhena cittena puna vandim tathāgatam  ekanavutitaḥ kappe yam puppham abhiropayiṃ
translated: Glad, with a glad heart, I worshipped the Tathāgata again.

translated: Herein, all lust is any kind of lust classed as lust for sense desires, etc. It is abandoned when it is abandoned by the development of the noble path.🔽It is destroyed when it is eradicated by the path. translated: Herein, all lust is all lust classified as lust for sensual desires, etc. It is abandoned means it is abandoned by the noble path in the sense of complete cutting off. All delusion is all delusion classified as the eight kinds with the eight bases of knowledge beginning with “not knowing suffering” and classified in many ways according to the bases of defilement. It is dispelled means it is penetrated by the path. I am cool and quenched means I have attained the state of coolness and I am completely quenched by the complete tranquilization of defilements, since the defilements and their associated states have been completely abandoned by the abandonment of the basic defilements. original: mayā imasmiṃ attabhāve na tādisaṃ pāpaṃ kataṃ atthi, idāni pana tassa sambhavoyeva🔽natthi. Yaṃ pana ito aññāsu jātīsu kataṃ atthi, idheva taṃ vedanīyaṃ, tañhi idheva
analyzed: mayā imasmin atta bhāve na tādisam pāpam katam atthi idāni pana tassa 🔽natthi yam pana itas aññāsu jātīsu katam atthi idha iva tam vedanīyam tat hi idha iva
translated: here itself is the place for it.

original: imasmiṃyeva attabhāve vedayitabbaṃ anubhavitabbaṃ phalaṃ, kasmā? Vatthu aññaṃ na
analyzed: imasmin yeva atta bhāve vedayitabbam anubhavitabbam phalam kasmā vatthu aññam na
translated: The fruit to be experienced must be experienced in this very selfhood. Why? Because there is no other basis.

original: vijjatīti tassa kammassa vipaccanokāso añño khandhappabandho natthi, ime pana khandhā🔽sabbaso upādānānaṃ pahīnattā anupādāno viya jātavedo carimakacittanirodhena appaṭisandhikā
analyzed: vijjati iti tassa kammassa vipaccanokāsaḥ aññaḥ khandha ppabandho natthi ime pana khandhā  sabbaso upādānānam pahīna ttā anupādānaḥ viya jātavedo carimaka citta nirodhena appaṭisandhikā
translated: There is no other aggregate-continuum in which the result of that kamma can be experienced. But these aggregates,

original: nirujjhantīti aññaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: nirujjhanti iti aññam byākāsi
translated: having completely abandoned all the kinds of clinging, cease without further becoming, like a fire without fuel, with the cessation of the last consciousness. Thus he answered.

original: Samitiguttattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samitigutta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Samitigutta is finished.

original: 2. Kassapattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kassapatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Kassapa

original: Yena yena subhikkhānīti āyasmato kassapattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ kira padumuttarassa
analyzed: yena yena subhikkhāni iti āyasmataḥ kassapa ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam kira padumuttarassa
translated: “Where there is plenty of food,” etc. These verses are by the Elder Kassapa. The story of his going forth is given in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: bhagavato kāle brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā tīsu vedesu aññesu ca brāhmaṇasippesu nipphattiṃ
analyzed: bhagavato kāle brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā tīsu vedesu aññesu ca brāhmaṇa sippesu nipphattim
translated: In the time of the Blessed One Padumuttara, it seems, he was reborn in a brahmin family and became proficient in the three Vedas and the other branches of learning of the brahmins.

original: gato, so ekadivasaṃ bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannamānaso sumanapupphehi pūjaṃ akāsi. Karonto
analyzed: gataḥ saḥ eka divasam bhagavantam disvā pasanna mānasaḥ sumana pupphehi pūjam akāsi karontaḥ
translated: One day he saw the Blessed One and, with a mind full of confidence, he worshipped him with jasmine flowers. As he did so,

original: ca satthu samantato upari ca pupphamuṭṭhiyo khipi. Buddhānubhāvena pupphāni pupphāsanākārena
analyzed: ca satthu samantataḥ upari ca buddha anubhāvena pupphāni puppha āsana ākārena
translated: and he threw handfuls of flowers all around the Teacher and above him. By the power of the Buddha the flowers remained in the form of a flower-canopy

original: sattāhaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. So taṃ acchariyaṃ disvā bhiyyosomattāya pasannamānaso ahosi. Aparāparaṃ
analyzed: sattāham saḥ tam acchariyam disvā bhiyyosomattāya pasanna mānasaḥ ahosi apara aparam
translated: for seven days. Seeing this miracle, he became even more devoted.

original: puññāni karonto kappasatasahassaṃ sugatīsuyeva saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ
analyzed: puññāni karontaḥ kappa sata sahassam sugatīsuyā iva saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam
translated: Doing various meritorious deeds, he wandered for a hundred thousand aeons in the happy destinies. In the dispensation of the present Buddha,

original: aññatarassa udiccabrāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti, kassapotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. Tassa
analyzed: aññatarassa udicca brāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti kassapotissa nāmam ahosi tassa
translated: he was reborn in Sāvatthi as the son of a certain brahmin of the Udicca clan. His name was Kassapa.

original: daharakāleyeva pitā kālamakāsi. Mātā taṃ paṭijaggati. So ekadivasaṃ jetavanaṃ gato
analyzed: pitā mātā tam paṭijaggati saḥ eka divasam jetavanam gataḥ
translated: When he was still a boy, his father died. His mother looked after him. One day he went to the Jetavana

original: bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ sutvā hetusampannatāya tasmiṃyeva āsane sotāpanno hutvā mātu🔽santikaṃ gantvā anujānāpetvā pabbajito satthari vuṭṭhavasse pavāretvā janapadacārikaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam sutvā hetu sampanna tāya tasmin yeva āsane sotāpannaḥ hutvā mātu  santikam gantvā anujānāpetvā pabbajitaḥ satthari vuṭṭha vasse pavāretvā janapada cārikam
translated: and heard the Buddha preach the Dhamma. By the power of the root of merit he had acquired, he attained the fruit of stream-entry right there in his seat. He went to his mother🔽and asked her permission to retire from the world. When the Teacher had completed the rainy season and had celebrated the Terminal Festival,

original: pakkante sayampi satthārā saddhiṃ gantukāmo āpucchituṃ mātu santikaṃ agamāsi. Mātā
analyzed: pakkante sayam pi satthārā saddhim gantu kāmaḥ āpucchitum mātu santikam agamāsi mātā
translated: he set out on his tours of the country. Kassapa, too, desiring to go with the Teacher, went to his mother to ask her permission. His mother🔽said to him,

original: vissajjentī ovādavasena –
analyzed: vissajjentī ovāda vasena
translated: She sent him away with this advice:

original: “Yena yena subhikkhāni, sivāni abhayāni ca;
analyzed: yena yena subhikkhāni sivāni abhayāni ca
translated: “Wherever there is plenty, peace, and safety,

original: Tena puttaka gacchassu, mā sokāpahato bhavā”ti. – gāthaṃ abhāsi;
analyzed: tena puttaka gacchassu mā soka apahataḥ bhavāti gātham abhāsi
translated: There, my son, you should go, and not be overcome by sorrow.”

original: Tattha yena yenāti yattha yattha. Bhummatthe hi etaṃ karaṇavacanaṃ, yasmiṃ yasmiṃ🔽disābhāgeti attho. Subhikkhānīti sulabhapiṇḍāni, raṭṭhānīti adhippāyo. Sivānīti khemāni
analyzed: yena yena ati yattha yattha bhummatthe hi yasmin yasmin  disā bhāge ti attho subhikkhāni iti sulabha piṇḍāni raṭṭhāni iti adhippāyaḥ sivāni iti khemāni
translated: Herein, wherever there is means in whatever place. For this is a gerundive of the noun bhūmi, which means in whatever direction.

original: arogāni. Abhayānīti corabhayādīhi nibbhayāni, rogadubbhikkhabhayāni pana “subhikkhāni,🔽sivānī”ti padadvayeneva gahitāni. Tenāti tattha, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ disābhāgeti attho.🔽Puttakāti anukampantī taṃ ālapati. Māti paṭisedhatthe nipāto sokāpahatoti vuttaguṇarahitāni
analyzed: arogāni abhayāni iti cora bhaya ādīhi nibbhayāni roga dubbhikkha bhayāni pana subhikkhāni  sivāni iti pada dvayena iva gahitāni tena ati tattha tasmin tasmin disā bhāga iti  puttaka ati anukampantī tam ālapati mā ati paṭisedha atthe nipāto soka apahataḥ ti vutta guṇa rahitāni
translated: Plenty means easy to get alms in, that is, countries. Peace means safe, free from danger. Safety means free from danger from thieves, etc., and from danger from disease and famine, which are included by the words “plenty” and “peace.” There means there, in whatever direction.🔽My son, she addresses him with affection. And not be overcome by sorrow means do not be overcome by sorrow born of the danger of famine, etc., by going to countries lacking the qualities mentioned in the verse.

original: raṭṭhāni gantvā dubbhikkhabhayādijanitena sokena upahato mā bhava māhosīti attho.
analyzed: raṭṭhāni gantvā dubbhikkha bhaya ādi janitena sokena upahataḥ mā bhava mā ahosi iti attho
translated: The word mā is a negative particle.

original: Taṃ sutvā thero, “mama mātā mayhaṃ sokarahitaṭṭhānagamanaṃ āsīsati, handa mayaṃ sabbaso🔽accantameva sokarahitaṃ ṭhānaṃ pattuṃ yutta”nti ussāhajāto vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā
analyzed: tam sutvā theraḥ mama mātā mayham soka rahita ṭṭhāna gamanam handa mayam sabbaso  accantam eva soka rahitam ṭhānam pattum yuttam ti ussāha jātaḥ vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā
translated: When the Elder heard this, he thought, “My mother wishes me to go to a place where there is no sorrow. Well then, it is fitting that I should go to a place where there is no sorrow at all.

original: nacirasseva arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: ” With this thought he aroused his energy, set about the practice of insight, and in no long time attained Arahatship. Therefore it is said:

original: “Ajjhāyako mantadharo, tiṇṇaṃ vedāna pāragū;
analyzed: ajjhāyakaḥ manta dharaḥ tiṇṇam vedāna pāragū
translated: I was a teacher of the Vedas, a master of the Three Vedas,

original: Abbhokāse ṭhito santo, addasaṃ lokanāyakaṃ.🔽“Sīhaṃ yathā vanacaraṃ, byaggharājaṃva nittasaṃ;
analyzed: abbhokāse ṭhitaḥ santaḥ addasam loka nāyakam  sīham yathā vana caram nittasam
translated: Standing in the open air, I saw the Leader of the world.🔽Like a lion in the forest, like a king of elephants in rut,

original: Tidhāpabhinnamātaṅgaṃ, kuñjaraṃva mahesinaṃ.
analyzed: tidhā apabhinna mātaṅgam kuñjaram iva mahesinam
translated: Like an elephant of three and forty years, a great seer.

original: “Sereyakaṃ gahetvāna, ākāse ukkhipiṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: sereyakam gahetvānaḥ ākāse ukkhipim aham
translated: Taking a garland of flowers, I raised it in the air;

original: Buddhassa ānubhāvena, parivārenti sabbaso.
analyzed: buddhassa ānubhāvena parivārenti sabbaso
translated: By the power of the Buddha, it surrounded him on all sides.

original: “Adhiṭṭhahi mahāvīro, sabbaññū lokanāyako;
analyzed: adhiṭṭhahi mahā vīraḥ sabbaññū loka nāyakaḥ
translated: The Great Hero, the Omniscient One, the Leader of the world,

original: Samantā pupphacchadanā, okiriṃsu narāsabhaṃ.
analyzed: samantā puppha chadanāḥ okiriṃsu narāsabham
translated: Commanded the flowers to rain down on the Best of Men.

original: “Tato sā pupphakañcukā, antovaṇṭā bahimukhā;
analyzed: tato sā puppha kañcukā antovaṇṭā bahimukhā
translated: The flowers, with their stalks turned inward and their petals turned outward,

original: Sattāhaṃ chadanaṃ katvā, tato antaradhāyatha.
analyzed: sattāham chadanam katvā tatas antaradhāyatha
translated: Rained down for seven days, and then disappeared.

original: “Tañca acchariyaṃ disvā, abbhutaṃ lomahaṃsanaṃ;
analyzed: tat ca acchariyam disvā abbhutam loma haṃsanam
translated: Having seen that wonder, that marvel that makes one’s hair stand on end,

original: Buddhe cittaṃ pasādesiṃ, sugate lokanāyake.
analyzed: buddhe cittam pasādesim sugate loka nāyake
translated: I purified my mind in regard to the Buddha, the Fortunate One, the Leader of the World.

original: “Tena cittappasādena, sukkamūlena codito;
analyzed: tena citta ppasādena sukka mūlena coditaḥ
translated: By that purification of mind, by that root of merit,

original: Kappānaṃ satasahassaṃ, duggatiṃ nupapajjahaṃ.
analyzed: kappānam sata sahassam duggatim nu papajjaham
translated: I did not go to a bad destination for a hundred thousand eons.

original: “Pannarasasahassamhi, kappānaṃ pañcavīsati;
analyzed: pannarasa sahassamhi kappānam pañcavīsati
translated: For fifteen thousand eons, and twenty-five more,

original: Vītamalāsanāmā ca, cakkavattī mahabbalā.
analyzed: ca cakkavattī mahabbalā
translated: I was a wheel-turning monarch named Vītamalā, of great power.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: My defilements were destroyed… I did the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā “idameva mātu vacanaṃ arahattappattiyā aṅkusaṃ jāta”nti tameva gāthaṃ paccudāhāsi.
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā idam eva mātu vacanam arahatta ppattiyāḥ aṅkusam jātan ti tam eva gātham paccudāhāsi
translated: But after attaining Liberation, he said this verse again, “This very word of my mother became the goad for attaining Liberation.”

original: Kassapattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kassapa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Kassapa is finished.

original: 3. Sīhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Sīhappamatto viharāti āyasmato sīhattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? So kira purimabuddhesu
analyzed: sīhatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā  sīhappamattaḥ viharāti āyasmataḥ sīha ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ kira purima buddhesu
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Sīha

original: katādhikāro ito aṭṭhārasakappasatamatthake atthadassissa bhagavato kāle candabhāgāya
analyzed: kata adhikāraḥ itas aṭṭhārasa kappa sata matthake atthadassissa bhagavataḥ kāle canda bhāgāya
translated: “He lived heedful, ardent, and resolute” is the verse of the Elder Sīha. What is the origin of this? It seems that in the past, during the time of the Blessed One Atthadassī, he had made an aspiration and had performed good deeds.🔽In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa, he was reborn in a brahmin family in the city of Bandhumatī.

original: nadiyā tīre kinnarayoniyaṃ nibbattitvā pupphabhakkho pupphanivasano hutvā viharanto
analyzed: nadiyāḥ tīre kinnara yoniyam nibbattitvā puppha bhakkho puppha nivasanaḥ hutvā viharantaḥ
translated: He was reborn in the Kinnara world on the bank of a river, and lived on flowers and in flowers.

original: ākāsena gacchantaṃ atthadassiṃ bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannacitto pūjetukāmo añjaliṃ
analyzed: ākāsena gacchantam attha dassim bhagavantam disvā pasanna cittaḥ pūjetu kāmaḥ añjalim
translated: As he was going through the air, he saw the Blessed One, the Giver of Wealth, and filled with joy, he wished to worship him.

original: paggayha aṭṭhāsi. Bhagavā tassa ajjhāsayaṃ ñatvā ākāsato oruyha aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle
analyzed: paggayha aṭṭhāsi bhagavā tassa ajjhāsayam ñatvā ākāsataḥ oruyha aññatarasmin rukkha mūle
translated: He stood with hands clasped in adoration. The Blessed One, knowing his thought, descended from the air and sat down cross-legged at the foot of a certain tree.

original: pallaṅkena nisīdi. Kinnaro candanasāraṃ ghaṃsitvā candanagandhena pupphehi ca pūjaṃ
analyzed: pallaṅkena kinnaraḥ candana sāram ghaṃsitvā candana gandhena pupphehi ca pūjam
translated: The Kinnara crushed the essence of sandal-wood, and with the fragrance of the sandal-wood and with flowers worshipped the Blessed One,

original: katvā vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto
analyzed: katvā vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi so tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ
translated: and after worshipping him, he circumambulated him and departed. By that meritorious deed, he was reborn in the world of the gods and men,

original: imasmiṃ buddhuppāde mallarājakule nibbatti, tassa sīhoti nāmaṃ ahosi. So bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: imasmin buddhuppāde malla rāja kule nibbatti tassa sīhaḥ iti nāmam ahosi saḥ bhagavantam
translated: and in this arising of the Buddha, he was reborn in the family of the King of the Mallas, and his name was Sīha. He,

original: disvā pasannamānaso vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Satthā tassa ajjhāsayaṃ oloketvā dhammaṃ
analyzed: disvā pasanna mānasaḥ vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi satthā tassa ajjhāsayam oloketvā dhammaṃ
translated: seeing the Blessed One, with his mind full of faith, worshipped him and sat down on one side. The Teacher, looking into his thoughts,🔽preached the Dhamma. He, having heard the Dhamma, having obtained faith, went forth, and taking a meditation subject,

original: kathesi. So dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā araññe
analyzed: kathesi so dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā araññe
translated: in the forest

original: viharati. Tassa cittaṃ nānārammaṇe vidhāvati, ekaggaṃ na hoti, sakatthaṃ nipphādetuṃ
analyzed: viharati tassa cittam na anārammaṇe vidhāvati ekaggam na hoti sakattham nipphādetum
translated: His mind runs out after the various aspects of that object, and it does not rest concentrated upon one object.🔽

original: na sakkoti. Satthā taṃ disvā ākāse ṭhatvā –
analyzed: na sakkoti satthā tam disvā ākāse ṭhatvā
translated: The Teacher, seeing him, stood in the air and said,

original: “Sīhappamatto vihara, rattindivamatandito;
analyzed: sīha ppamattaḥ vihara
translated: “Be diligent, be not remiss, day and night;

original: Bhāvehi kusalaṃ dhammaṃ, jaha sīghaṃ samussaya”nti. –
analyzed: bhāvehi kusalam dhammam jaha sīgham samussayanti
translated: Develop the good state of mind, and quickly cast off the burden.”

original: Gāthāya ovadi. So gāthāvasāne vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: gāthāya ovadi so gāthā avasāne vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: At the conclusion of the Stanza the Elder developed Insight, and attained Arahatship. Therefore it is said,

original: “Candabhāgānadītīre, ahosiṃ kinnaro tadā;
analyzed: candabhāgā nadī tīre tadā
translated: “On the bank of the Candabhāgā River, I was a Kinnara then;

original: Pupphabhakkho cahaṃ āsiṃ, pupphanivasano tathā.
analyzed: puppha bhakkho ca ham āsim puppha nivasanaḥ tathā
translated: I lived on flowers, and slept on flowers.

original: “Atthadassī tu bhagavā, lokajeṭṭho narāsabho;
analyzed: attha dassī tu bhagavā loka jeṭṭhaḥ narāsabhaḥ
translated: “The Visionary One, the Blessed One, the Chief of the world, the Best of Men,

original: Vipinaggena niyyāsi, haṃsarājāva ambare.
analyzed: vipina ggena niyyāsi haṃsa rājā ava ambare
translated: Went forth from the forest, like the King of Swans through the air.

original: “Namo te purisājañña, cittaṃ te suvisodhitaṃ;
analyzed: namaḥ te purisājañña cittam te su visodhitam
translated: “Homage to thee, O Man of Vision, thy mind is well cleansed;

original: Pasannamukhavaṇṇosi, vippasannamukhindriyo.
analyzed: pasanna mukha vaṇṇo asi vippasanna mukha indriyo
translated: Thy face is serene, and thy senses are well subdued.

original: “Orohitvāna ākāsā, bhūripañño sumedhaso;
analyzed: ārohitvānaḥ ākāsā bhūri paññaḥ sumedhasaḥ
translated: “Descending from the air, the wise one, the man of great wisdom,

original: Saṅghāṭiṃ pattharitvāna, pallaṅkena upāvisi.
analyzed: saṅghāṭim pattharitvāna pallaṅkena upāvisi
translated: Spread his robe, and sat down cross-legged.

original: “Vilīnaṃ candanādāya, agamāsiṃ jinantikaṃ;
analyzed: vilīnam candana ādāya agama asim jina antikam
translated: I went to the Buddha,

original: Pasannacitto sumano, buddhassa abhiropayiṃ.
analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ buddhassa abhiropayiṃ
translated: and with a serene and joyful mind, I offered it to the Buddha.

original: “Abhivādetvāna sambuddhaṃ, lokajeṭṭhaṃ narāsabhaṃ;
analyzed: abhivādetvāna sambuddham loka jeṭṭham narāsabham
translated: After paying homage to the Buddha, the world’s foremost person,

original: Pāmojjaṃ janayitvāna, pakkāmiṃ uttarāmukho.
analyzed: pāmojjam janayitvāna pakka āmim uttarā mukhaḥ
translated: I left for the north, giving rise to joy.

original: “Aṭṭhārase kappasate, candanaṃ yaṃ apūjayiṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhārase candanam yam apūjayim
translated: For eighteen hundred eons, I made an offering of sandalwood,

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, buddhapūjāyidaṃ phalaṃ.🔽“Catuddase kappasate, ito āsiṃsu te tayo;
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi buddha pūjāya idam phalam  catuddase kappa sate itas āsiṃsu te tayo
translated: I do not recall any bad destination, this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.

original: Rohaṇī nāma nāmena, cakkavattī mahabbalā.
analyzed: rohaṇī nāma nāmena cakkavattī mahat balā
translated: For three hundred and forty eons, they were three universal monarchs named Rohaṇa, of great strength.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: My defilements are destroyed … I have done what had to be done for the Buddha’s instruction.”

analyzed: vikkhīṇaḥ jāti saṃsāraḥ na atthi dāni punabbhavaḥ ti gātham abhāsi  tattha khandhā ti pañca upādānakkhandhā te hi vipassana upalakkhaṇato sāmañña lakkhaṇato
translated: The round of births has been extinguished; there is no more coming to any state of being.”

original: ca ñātapariññādīhi parijānanavasena vipassitabbā. Diṭṭhā yathābhūtanti vipassanāpaññāsahitāya

analyzed: magga paññāya idam dukkham ti ādinā aviparītataḥ diṭṭhāḥ bhavā sabbe padālitā ati kāma bhava ādayo

original: sabbe kammabhavā upapattibhavā ca maggañāṇasatthena bhinnā viddhaṃsitā. Kilesapadālaneneva🔽hi kammopapattibhavā padālitā nāma honti. Tenāha “vikkhīṇo jātisaṃsāro, natthi dāni
analyzed: sabbe kamma bhavā upapatti bhavā ca magga ñāṇa satthena bhinnā viddhaṃsitā kilesa padālanena iva  hi kamma upapatti bhavā padālitāḥ nāma honti tena āha vikkhīṇaḥ jāti saṃsāraḥ natthi dāni
translated: All existences are broken up: all existences of the three planes of becoming, the kamma-process plane of becoming, the rebirth-process plane of becoming, and the resultant plane of becoming, are broken up, destroyed, by the sword of path knowledge.🔽For it is by the sword of the defilement-destroying path that the kamma-process and rebirth-process planes of becoming are broken up.

original: punabbhavo”ti. Tassattho heṭṭhā vuttoyeva.

analyzed: buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam seṭṭhi kule nibbatti ajjunotissa nāmam ahosi so viññu tam

original: Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –

translated: just as a man who is being carried away by the force of a great flood of water, deep and wide, which has no firm ground, might obtain a strong raft provided with oars,

translated: though he was being carried along by the current of the round of rebirths, he was unable to get himself out, to reach the plane of nibbana, by means of the noble path-raft, which is furnished with the calm and insight that the Master had brought him. But how he was able, that he shows

analyzed: ācārena vayena kosallena ca anucchavikam dārikam ānetvā vivāha kammam akaṃsu saḥ tāya
translated: who was equal to him in family, beauty,

analyzed: saṃvigga mānasaḥ satthu santikam gantvā dhammam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbaji tassa

analyzed: satthā kammaṭṭhānam adāsi saḥ kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā katipaya divasa atikkamena ukkaṇṭhā abhibhūtaḥ

analyzed: vihāsi atha satthā tassa citta ppavattim ñatvā ovāda vasena dukkhā kāmā erakā ti  gātham abhāsi saḥ tam sutvā ayuttam mayā katam yaḥ ham evarūpassa satthu santike

analyzed: kudāla piṭakam ādāya samam tam patham

analyzed: yaḥ kāme na kāmayati dukkham saḥ na kāmayati

original: Tattha dukkhā kāmāti ime vatthukāmakilesakāmā dukkhavatthutāya vipariṇāmadukkhasaṃsāradukkhasabhāvato

translated: Herein, pleasures are suffering means that these pleasures of sense desires and defilements are suffering because they are the basis of suffering, because they are the suffering of change, and because they are the suffering inherent in the process of condi- tioned existence.

original: ca, dukkhā dukkhamā dukkhanibbattikā. Vuttañhetaṃ – “appassādā kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā,🔽ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”tiādi. Erakāti paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavā taṃ ālapati, pacchā pana🔽thero attānaṃ nāmena kathesi. Na sukhā kāmāti kāmā nāmete jānantassa sukhā na honti,
analyzed: ca dukkhāḥ dukkhamāḥ dukkha nibbattikāḥ vuttaṃ ha etam appassādāḥ kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsā  ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyoti ādi paṭhamam tāva bhagavā tam ālapati pacchā pana  theraḥ attānam nāmena kathesi na sukhā kāmā ti kāmāḥ nāma ete jānantassa sukhāḥ na honti

original: ajānantassa pana sukhato upaṭṭhahanti. Yathāha – “yo sukhaṃ dukkhato adda, dukkhamaddakkhi🔽sallato”tiādi. analyzed: a jānantassa pana sukhataḥ upaṭṭhahanti yathā āha yaḥ sukham dukkhataḥ adda dukkham addakkhi  yaḥ kāme kāmayati dukkham so kāmayati iti yaḥ satto kilesa kāmena vatthu kāme  kāmayati tassa tam kāmanam sampati sa pariḷāha tāya āyatim apāya dukkha hetu tāya ca  vaṭṭa dukkha hetutāya ca dukkham vatthu kāmāḥ pana dukkhassa vatthu bhūtāḥ iti so dukkha sabhāvam
translated: and they are suffering, suffering-producing, and born of suffering. For this is said: “Pleasures are of little flavour, of much travail and travail is the greater” . Erakāti: first the Blessed One addressed him thus, and afterwards the Elder told him his name. Na sukhā kāmā: they are not pleasures for one who knows them thus. But they appear as pleasure to one who does not know them thus. As it is said: “He who sees suffering in pleasure, and pleasure in suffering,

original: dukkhanimittaṃ dukkhavatthuñca kāmayatīti vutto. Itaraṃ paṭipakkhavasena tamevatthaṃ
analyzed: dukkha nimittam dukkha vatthuñca kāmayati iti vuttaḥ itaram paṭipakkha vasena tam eva attham
translated: sees wrongly” . Yo kāme kāmayatīti yo being desires sense desires by means of the defilement-sense desire, for him that sense desire, when it is present, is suffering because of the fever it brings, and in the future because it is the cause of suffering in the states of loss. And it is the cause of the suffering of the round of rebirths. But the sense desires as objects are the basis for suffering. Thus it is said that he desires the nature of suffering, the sign of suffering, and the basis of suffering. The other passage is the opposite of this.

original: ñāpetuṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā tassattho vuttavipariyāyena veditabbo.

translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Eraka is finished.

translated: I bear my last body, in the Dispensation of the Fully Enlightened One.

analyzed: itas kappa sate āsim paripuṇṇe anūnake
translated: “For a hundred thousand years, complete and full,

analyzed: paccakkhatāya vadati agga ppattena ati aggam sabbaññutam sabbehi vā guṇehi agga bhāvam

analyzed: gahetvā thūpam pūjesi saḥ tena puñña kammena deva loke nibbattitvā aparāparam puññāni

analyzed: kuṭumbikassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti tassa pālo ti nāmam akaṃsu mātā tassa ādhāvitvā
translated: He was born as the son of a householder, and they gave him the name Pālaka. When his mother was running about and

analyzed: paridhāvitvā vicaraṇa kāle aññam puttam labhi tassa mātā pitaro cūḷapālaḥ iti nāmam katvā

translated: “The road is dangerous, and you will be troubled if you go with me. You

translated: “I am blind and sightless, I am lost in the desert path;

analyzed: sayamānaḥ api gacchissam na sahāyena pāpena iti gātham abhāsittha  tattha andhaḥ ti cakkhu vikalaḥ hata netto ti vinaṭṭha cakkhuko tena payoga vipatti vasena aham

original: saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ sāsaṅkaṃ saparisaṅkaṃ kammaṃ anatthasañhitaṃ dukkhapaṭibaddhaṃ nihīnaṃ,
analyzed: saṃkiliṭṭham sa āsaṅkam sa parisaṅkam kammam anattha sañhitam dukkha paṭibaddham nihīnam
translated: For the former was a deed defiled by greed, etc., accompanied by worry and flurry, connected with harm, bound up with suffering, and low;

original: idaṃ pana taṃvipariyāyato uttamaṃ paṇītanti adhippāyo.
analyzed: idam pana uttamam paṇītanti adhippāyaḥ
translated: but this is the opposite of that, and so it is supreme and excellent.”

original: Tissattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tissa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Tissa is finished.

original: 8. Abhayattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: abhayatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Verses of the Elder Abhaya

original: Rūpaṃ disvā sati muṭṭhāti āyasmato abhayattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Sopi purimabuddhesu
analyzed: rūpam disvā sati āyasmataḥ abhaya ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti saḥ api purima buddhesu
translated: “When he sees a visible object, his mindfulness is confused” . This elder’s story is given in the Paṭisambhidā.🔽He too had made his beginning in the time of former Buddhas,

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭūpanissayaṃ puññaṃ upacinanto sumedhassa bhagavato
analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha bhave vivaṭṭu upanissayam puññam upacinantaḥ sumedhassa bhagavato
translated: and he had accumulated his provisions in various existences during the interval since then. He had made his resolution at the time of the seven weeks’ festival at the end of the life of the Perfect Buddha Sumedha.

analyzed: kāle kula gehe nibbattitvā viññutam pattaḥ eka divasam sumedham bhagavantam disvā pasanna cittaḥ
translated: and was reborn in a good family in a village in the Kosala country. When he reached maturity, one day he saw the Buddha Sumedha and with a pure mind

original: saḷalapupphehi pūjamakāsi. So tena puññakammena devesu nibbattitvā aparāparaṃ puññāni
analyzed: saḷala pupphehi pūjam akāsi saḥ tena puñña kammena devesu nibbattitvā apara aparam puññāni
translated: he worshipped him with six flowers. By that meritorious deed he was reborn among the gods and, after doing various meritorious deeds,

original: katvā sugatīsuyeva saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ brāhmaṇakule nibbattitvā
analyzed: katvā sugatīsuyā iva saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam brāhmaṇa kule nibbattitvā

original: abhayoti laddhanāmo viññutaṃ patto hetusampattiyā codiyamāno ekadivasaṃ vihāraṃ gato

translated: He was given the name Abhayo. When he reached maturity, he was urged by the power of his previous good deeds and one day he went to the monastery.

original: satthu dhammadesanaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā katapubbakicco vipassanāya
analyzed: satthu dhamma desanam sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā kata pubba kiccaḥ vipassanāya
translated: After hearing the Dhamma taught by the Buddha, he became a faithful lay disciple. He then went forth and did the duties of a novice. He was practicing insight meditation.

original: kammaṃ karonto viharati. Athassa ekadivasaṃ gāmaṃ piṇḍāya paviṭṭhassa alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ
analyzed: kammam karontaḥ viharati athassa eka divasam gāmam piṇḍāya paviṭṭhassa alaṅkata paṭiyattam
translated: One day, while he was entering the village for alms, he saw a woman who was well adorned and well dressed.

original: mātugāmaṃ disvā ayonisomanasikāravasena tassa rūpaṃ ārabbha chandarāgo uppajji, so
analyzed: mātugāmam disvā a yonisoma nasikāra vasena tassa rūpam ārabbha chanda rāgaḥ uppajji so
translated: Because of improper attention, lust arose in him in regard to her form.

original: vihāraṃ pavisitvā “satiṃ vissajjitvā olokentassa rūpārammaṇe mayhaṃ kileso uppanno,
analyzed: vihāram pavisitvā satim vissajjitvā olokentassa rūpa ārammaṇe mayham kilesaḥ uppanno
translated: He entered the monastery and, looking around, he thought: “Lust has arisen in me in regard to the object of form.

original: ayuttaṃ mayā kata”nti attano cittaṃ niggaṇhanto tāvadeva vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: ayuttam mayā katanti attano cittam niggaṇhantaḥ tāvat eva vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam
translated: “It was not right for me to do that,” and he restrained his mind. Immediately he increased his insight and attained arahatship.

original: pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Sumedho nāma nāmena, sayambhū aparājito;
analyzed: sumedhaḥ nāma nāmena sayambhū aparājitaḥ
translated: “My name was Sumedha, I was self-become, unconquered;

original: Vivekamanubrūhanto, ajjhogahi mahāvanaṃ.
analyzed: vivekam anubrūhantaḥ mahā vanam

original: “Saḷalaṃ pupphitaṃ disvā, ganthitvāna vaṭaṃsakaṃ;
analyzed: sa ḷalam pupphitam disvā ganthitvāna vaṭaṃsakam
translated: “Seeing a tree in blossom with six branches, I wove a garland of flowers;

original: Buddhassa abhiropesiṃ, sammukhā lokanāyakaṃ.
analyzed: buddhassa abhiropesim sammukhā lokanāyakam
translated: I placed it in the presence of the Buddha, the Leader of the World.

original: “Tiṃsakappasahassamhi, yaṃ pupphamabhiropayiṃ;
analyzed: tiṃsa kappa sahassamhi yam
translated: “For twenty-one thousand eons, the flower I placed there;

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, buddhapūjāyidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim nā abhijānāmi buddha pūjāya idam phalam
translated: I do not recall any evil state, this is the fruit of worshipping the Buddha.

original: “Ūnavīse kappasate, soḷasāsuṃ sunimmitā;
analyzed: ūnavīse kappa sate soḷasa asum su nimmitā
translated: “In nineteen hundred eons, sixteen of them were well-made;

original: Sattaratanasampannā, cakkavattī mahabbalā.
analyzed: satta ratana sampannā cakkavattī mahat balā
translated: Endowed with the seven treasures, I was a powerful universal monarch.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are burned up… I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā attano kilesuppattinidassanena “kilese anuvattentassa vaṭṭadukkhato nattheva sīsukkhipanaṃ. Ahaṃ pana te nānuvatti”nti dassento –
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā attanaḥ kilesa uppatti nidassanena kilese anuvattentassa vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ nattha iva sīsu khipanam aham pana te na anuvattin ti dassento
translated: But having attained arahatship, showing the arising of his defilements, “For one who follows the defilements, there is no escape from the suffering of the round. But I did not follow them.”

original: “Rūpaṃ disvā sati muṭṭhā, piyaṃ nimittaṃ manasikaroto;
analyzed: rūpam disvā sati muṭṭhā piyam nimittam manasikaroto
translated: “When one sees a form, his mindfulness is lost, and he gives attention to a sign dear;

original: Sārattacitto vedeti, tañca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati;
analyzed: sāratta cittaḥ vedeti tat ca ajjhosa tiṭṭhati
translated: He feels it with a greedy mind, and he persists in that feeling.

original: Tassa vaḍḍhanti āsavā, bhavamūlopagāmino”ti. – gāthaṃ abhāsi;
analyzed: tassa vaḍḍhanti āsavāḥ bhava mūla upagāminaḥ iti gātham abhāsi

original: Tattha rūpanti rajjanīyaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ, taṃ panettha itthirūpaṃ adhippetaṃ. Disvāti

analyzed: cakkhunā disvā cakkhu dvāra anusārena nimitta anubyañjana sat lakkhaṇa vasena tam gahetvā

analyzed: tassa tathā gahaṇa hetu uti attho sati asubha sabhāve kāye asubha ntu eva pavattana sati

analyzed: yathā upaṭṭhitam ārammaṇam subham sukhanti ādinā piya nimittam katvā a yoniso manasikārena

translated: And for him thus functioning,

analyzed: abhayatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Abhaya is finished.

translated: “For twenty-two eons, since I gave that gift

analyzed: mayam tam paripūressāma ati āhaṃsu theraḥ na mayham āvuso uḷārehi paccayehi atthaḥ
translated: we will make up the deficiency.” The Elder said, “I have no need of superior requisites,

translated: I get by on inferior ones. I am satisfied with the taste of the Dhamma.” To show this he recited the stanza:

analyzed: tattha na aham etena atthikā iti yena mama tumhe tad petu kāmā paripūressāma ati vadatha
translated: Herein, I have no need of this means I have no need of the requisites you want to give me, thinking “We will satisfy him.”

analyzed: etena āmisa lābhena paccaya āmisa rasena na aham atthikaḥ mayham etena atthaḥ natthi santuṭṭhi
translated: I have no need for the gain of material things, I have no use for the gain of material things, I am satisfied with whatever comes by way of requisites.

translated: and with the taste of the ninefold supramundane Dhamma, I am satisfied, I am well-provided with the highest happiness.🔽Having drunk the supreme taste, the best of all tastes, I stand firm.

original: dhammarasaṃ pivitvā ṭhito, tenāha – “sabbarasaṃ dhammaraso jinātī”ti. Na ca kāhāmi🔽visena santhavanti evarūpaṃ rasuttamaṃ dhammarasaṃ pivitvā ṭhito visena visasadisena
analyzed: dhamma rasam pivitvā ṭhitaḥ tena āha sabba rasam dhamma rasaḥ jināti iti na ca  visena santhavanti evarūpam rasuttamam dhamma rasam pivitvā ṭhitaḥ visena visa sadisena
translated: The meaning is, having drunk the taste of the Dhamma, which is the best, the supreme, among all tastes, I stand firm. Therefore it was said: “The taste of the Dhamma surpasses all tastes” .🔽I will not make a bargain with poison.

original: visarasena santhavaṃ saṃsaggaṃ na karissāmi, tathākaraṇassa kāraṇaṃ natthīti attho.
analyzed: visa rasena santhavam saṃsaggam na karissāmi tathākaraṇassa kāraṇam na atthi iti attho
translated: Having drunk the taste of the Dhamma, which is such a supreme taste, I will not make a bargain, I will not associate with poison, with a taste that is like poison. The meaning is, there is no reason for me to do so.

original: Bandhurattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bandhura thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Bandhu is finished.

original: katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto padumuttarassa bhagavato kāle🔽yakkhasenāpati hutvā nibbatto ekadivasaṃ yakkhasamāgame nisinno satthāraṃ aññatarasmiṃ
analyzed: kata adhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ kāle  yakkha senāpati hutvā nibbattaḥ eka divasam yakkha samāgame nisinno satthāram aññatarasmiṃ
translated: having begun the work of a bodhisatta, accumulated merit in various existences, and in the time of the exalted Padumuttara,🔽being born as a general of the Yakkhas, one day, while sitting at a meeting of the Yakkhas, saw the Teacher sitting at the foot of a certain tree,

original: rukkhamūle nisinnaṃ disvā upasaṅkamitvā satthāraṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Tassa
analyzed: rukkha mūle nisinnam disvā upasaṅkamitvā satthāram vanditvā ekamantam nisīdi tassa
translated: and approaching him, paid obeisance to the Teacher and sat down respectfully on one side. The Teacher

original: satthā dhammaṃ desesi. So dhammaṃ sutvā uḷāraṃ pītisomanassaṃ pavedento apphoṭento
analyzed: satthā dhammaṃ desesi saḥ dhammam sutvā uḷāram pīti somanassam pavedentaḥ apphoṭentaḥ
translated: preached the Law to him. He, having heard the Law, was filled with exceeding great joy and gladness, and rising up,

original: uṭṭhahitvā satthāraṃ vanditvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu
analyzed: uṭṭhahitvā satthāram vanditvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi so tena puñña kammena deva manussesu
translated: paid obeisance to the Teacher, saluted him from the right, and departed. By that meritorious deed he passed through the round of existences among gods and men,

original: saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ brāhmaṇakule nibbatti, khitakotissa nāmaṃ
analyzed: saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam brāhmaṇa kule nibbatti khitakotissa nāmaṃ
translated: and was reborn in a brahmin family in Sāvatthi in the dispensation of this Buddha. His name was Khīṇhaka.

original: ahosi. So viññutaṃ patto mahāmoggallānattherassa mahiddhikabhāvaṃ sutvā “iddhimā
analyzed: ahosi so viññutam pattaḥ mahāmoggallāna therassa mahiddhika bhāvam sutvā iddhimā
translated: He became a monk and, having attained wisdom, heard of the Elder Moggallāna the Great’s great power of supernormal knowledge.

original: bhavissāmī”ti pubbahetunā codiyamāno pabbajitvā bhagavato santike kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: bhavissāmi iti pubba hetunā codiyamānaḥ pabbajitvā bhagavato santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā
translated: He became a monk and received a meditation subject from the Blessed One.🔽He did his work on serenity and insight and in no long time reached Arahantship with the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: samathavipassanāsu kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva chaḷabhiñño ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: samatha vipassanāsu kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva chaḍḍa abhiññaḥ ahosi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: That is why it was said of him in the Apadāna:🔽“Paduma by name was he,

original: “Padumo nāma nāmena, dvipadindo narāsabho;
analyzed: padumaḥ nāma nāmena dvipad indo narāsabhaḥ
translated: Two-footed Best of Men;🔽He went forth from the Pāvā country,

original: Pavanā abhinikkhamma, dhammaṃ deseti cakkhumā.
analyzed: pavanā abhinikkhamma dhammaṃ deseti cakkhumā
translated: And taught the Dhamma, he whose eye was clear.🔽“A time there was when Yakkhas met,

original: “Yakkhānaṃ samayo āsi, avidūre mahesino;
analyzed: yakkhānam samayaḥ āsi avidūre mahesinaḥ
translated: Not far from the Great Seer;🔽They came to him for what they had to do,

original: Yena kiccena sampattā, ajjhāpekkhiṃsu tāvade.
analyzed: yena kiccena sampattāḥ ajjhāpekkhiṃsu tāvade
translated: And waited there for him.

original: “Buddhassa giramaññāya, amatassa ca desanaṃ;
analyzed: buddhassa giram aññāya amatassa ca desanam
translated: “When he had understood the Buddha’s word,🔽And the teaching of the Deathless too,🔽With confident heart and glad,

original: Pasannacitto sumano, apphoṭetvā upaṭṭhahiṃ.
analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ apphoṭetvā upaṭṭhahim
translated: I rubbed him down and waited on.🔽“See the fruit of the service done

original: “Suciṇṇassa phalaṃ passa, upaṭṭhānassa satthuno;
analyzed: su ciṇṇassa phalam passa upaṭṭhānassa satthuno
translated: To the Teacher, so well performed;🔽For thirty thousand aeons

original: Tiṃsakappasahassesu, duggatiṃ nupapajjahaṃ.
analyzed: tiṃsa kappa sahassesu duggatim nu papajjaham
translated: I never went to states of woe.🔽“For thirty-one aeons

original: “Ūnatiṃse kappasate, samalaṅkatanāmako;
analyzed: ūnatiṃse kappa sate samalaṅkata nāmakaḥ
translated: I was the one called Samalaṅkata,🔽Endowed with the seven treasures,

original: Sattaratanasampanno, cakkavattī mahabbalo.
analyzed: satta ratana sampannaḥ cakkavattī mahat balaḥ
translated: A mighty Universal King.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.🔽Arahattaṃ pana patvā savisesaṃ iddhīsu vasībhāvena anekavihitaṃ iddhividhaṃ paccanubhonto
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti  arahattam pana patvā sa visesam iddhīsu vasībhāvena aneka vihitam iddhi vidham paccanubhonto
translated: “My defilements are burnt up, and so on up to: The Buddha’s Dispensation is done.”

original: iddhipāṭihāriyena anusāsanīpāṭihāriyena ca sattānaṃ anuggahaṃ karonto viharati. So
analyzed: iddhi pāṭihāriyena anusāsanī pāṭihāriyena ca sattānam anuggaham karontaḥ viharati saḥ
translated: But when he had reached Arahantship, he lived by favouring beings with the miracle of psychic power and the miracle of teaching, experiencing the various kinds of psychic power with mastery over them.

original: bhikkhūhi, “kathaṃ tvaṃ, āvuso, iddhi vaḷañjesī”ti puṭṭho tamatthaṃ ācikkhanto –
analyzed: bhikkhūhi katham tvam āvuso iddhi vaḷañjesi iti puṭṭho tam attham ācikkhantaḥ
translated: When he was asked by bhikkhus, “How is it, friend, that you have such psychic power?” he explained the matter,

original: “Lahuko vata me kāyo, phuṭṭho ca pītisukhena vipulena;
analyzed: lahukaḥ vata me kāyaḥ phuṭṭhaḥ ca pīti sukhena vipulena
translated: saying: “How light my body is, and how it is suffused with bliss!

original: Tūlamiva eritaṃ mālutena, pilavatīva me kāyo”ti. –
analyzed: tūlam iva eritam mālutena pilavatī iva me
translated: Like a cotton ball my body is moved by the wind. ”

original: Gāthaṃ abhāsi. “Udānavasenā”tipi vadantiyeva.🔽Tattha lahuko vata me kāyoti nīvaraṇādivikkhambhanena cuddasavidhena cittaparidamanena
analyzed: gātham abhāsi vadantiyā iva  tattha lahukaḥ vata me kāyaḥ iti nīvaraṇa ādi vikkhambhanena cuddasavidhena citta paridamanena
translated: They say that this is a verse of joy.

original: caturiddhipādakabhāvanāya suṭṭhu ciṇṇavasībhāvena ca me rūpakāyo sallahuko vata,
analyzed: catur iddhipādaka bhāvanāya suṭṭhu ciṇṇavasībhāvena ca me rūpa kāyaḥ sat lahukaḥ vata
translated: Herein, how light my body is: my material body is very light indeed, owing to the mastery of the four roads to power by the suppression of the hindrances, etc., and by the fourteen ways of constraining the mind, and owing to the mastery of the four roads to power by the development of the four foundations of success.

original: yena dandhaṃ mahābhūtapaccayampi nāma imaṃ karajakāyaṃ cittavasena pariṇāmemīti adhippāyo.🔽Phuṭṭho ca pītisukhena vipulenāti sabbatthakameva pharantena mahatā uḷārena pītisahitena
analyzed: yena dandham mahābhūta paccayam pi nāma imam karaja kāyam citta vasena pariṇāmemi iti adhippāyaḥ  phuṭṭhaḥ ca pīti sukhena vipulena ati sabbatthakam eva pharantena mahatā uḷārena pīti sahitena
translated: and the intention is that it is because of the mind that this physical body, which is a condition for sluggishness, is transformed.🔽And the construction is: ‘I am touched by the extensive happiness and bliss’ .

original: sukhena phuṭṭho ca me kāyoti yojanā. Idañca yathā kāyo lahuko ahosi, taṃ dassanatthaṃ
analyzed: sukhena phuṭṭhaḥ ca me kāyaḥ iti yojanā idam ca yathā kāyaḥ lahukaḥ ahosi tam dassana ttham
translated: And this is said in order to show how light the body was.

original: vuttaṃ. Sukhasaññokkamanena hi saddhiṃyeva lahusaññokkamanaṃ hoti. Sukhassa pharaṇañcettha
analyzed: vuttam sukha saññā ukkamanena hi saddhiṃyeva lahu saññā ukkamanam hoti sukhassa
translated: For the occurrence of the perception of lightness is simultaneous with the occurrence of the perception of bliss.🔽And here the spreading of the bliss should be regarded as the occurrence of the material instances originated by that bliss.

original: taṃsamuṭṭhānarūpavasena daṭṭhabbaṃ kathaṃ pana catutthajjhānasamaṅgino pītisukhapharaṇaṃ,
analyzed: tad samuṭṭhāna rūpa vasena daṭṭhabbam katham pana catuttha jhāna samaṅginaḥ pīti sukha pharaṇam
translated: But how can there be the spreading of happiness and bliss in one who possesses the fourth jhāna, since he has transcended happiness and bliss?

original: samatikkantapītisukhañhi tanti ce? Saccametaṃ, idaṃ pana na catutthajjhānalakkhaṇavasena
analyzed: samatikkanta pīti sukham hi ce saccam etam idam pana na catuttha jhāna lakkhaṇa vasena
translated: That is so, but this is not said in order to define the fourth jhāna,🔽but rather in order to show the prior stage.

original: vuttaṃ, atha kho pubbabhāgavasena. “Pītisukhenā”ti pana pītisahitasadisena sukhena,
analyzed: vuttam atha kho pubba bhāga vasena pīti sukhena ati pana pīti sahita sadisena sukhena
translated: And ‘by the happiness and bliss’ is said figuratively for the happiness and bliss accompanied by happiness.

original: upekkhā hi idha santasabhāvatāya ñāṇavisesayogato ca sukhanti adhippetaṃ. Tathā hi
analyzed: upekkhā hi idha santa sabhāva tāya ñāṇa visesa yogataḥ ca sukhanti adhippetam tathā hi
translated: For equanimity is intended here as pleasure because of its state of peacefulness and because of its association with a special kind of knowledge.

original: vuttaṃ “sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca okkamatī”ti. Pādakajjhānārammaṇena rūpakāyārammaṇena
analyzed: vuttam sukha saññañca lahu saññañca okkamati iti pādaka jhāna ārammaṇena rūpa kāya ārammaṇena
translated: For this is said: “He enters upon and abides in a blissful perception and a buoyant perception” .

original: vā iddhicittena sahajātaṃ sukhasaññañca lahusaññañca okkamati pavisati phusati sampāpuṇātīti
analyzed: vā iddhi cittena sahajātam sukha saññañca lahu saññañca okkamati pavisati phusati sampāpuṇāti iti
translated: Either with the jhāna that is the footing for success or with the mind-made body that is the object of that jhāna, he enters upon and abides in a blissful perception and a buoyant perception that are conascent with that jhāna.

original: ayampi tattha attho. Tathā cāha aṭṭhakathāyaṃ – “sukhasaññā nāma upekkhāsampayuttā🔽saññā. Upekkhā hi santaṃ sukhanti vuttaṃ sāyeva saññā nīvaraṇehi ceva vitakkādipaccanīkehi
analyzed: ayam pi tattha attho tathā ca āha aṭṭhakathā ayam sukha saññā nāma upekkhā sampayuttā  saññā upekkhā hi santam sukhan ti vuttam sāya iva saññā nīvaraṇehi ca iva vitakka ādi paccanīkehi
translated: This is the meaning here. And in the commentary to the Peṭaka it is said: “‘A blissful perception’: perception associated with equanimity.

original: ca vimuttattā lahusaññātipi veditabbā. Taṃ okkantassa panassa karajakāyopi tūlapicu🔽viya sallahuko hoti. So evaṃ vātakkhittatūlapicuno viya sallahukena dissamānena kāyena
analyzed: ca vimutta ttā lahu saññā atipi veditabbā tam okkantassa panassa karaja kāyaḥ api tūla picu  viya sat lahukaḥ hoti saḥ evam vāta khitta tūla picunaḥ viya sat lahukena dissamānena kāyena
translated: For equanimity is called ‘blissful’ because it is peaceful. That same perception should be understood as ‘buoyant’ because it is liberated from hindrances and from its opposing states beginning with applied thought.🔽And when he has entered upon that, his physical body too becomes buoyant like cotton wool.🔽So with his body seeming as buoyant as a tuft of cotton wafted by the wind, he goes to the Brahmā-world” .

original: brahmalokaṃ gacchatī”ti. Tenāha “tūlamiva eritaṃ mālutena, pilavatīva me kāyo”ti.
analyzed: brahma lokam gacchati iti tena āha tūlam iva eritam mālutena pilavati iva me
translated: That is why it was said above: “As though on flowing air borne upward he” .

original: Tassattho – yadāhaṃ brahmalokaṃ aññaṃ vā iddhiyā gantukāmo homi, tadā mālutena vāyunā
analyzed: tassa atthaḥ yadā aham brahma lokam aññam vā iddhiyā gantu kāmo homi tadā mālutena vāyunā
translated: The meaning is this: When I want to go to the Brahmā-world or elsewhere by my psychic power, then I go by means of the wind-element.

original: eritaṃ cittaṃ tūlapicu viya ākāsaṃ laṅghantoyeva me kāyo hotīti.
analyzed: eritam cittam tūla picu viyas ākāsam me kāyaḥ hoti iti
translated: The meaning is: “When I want to go to the Brahmā-world or elsewhere by my psychic power, then my body becomes like a tuft of cotton-wool, floating in the air, being moved by the wind of my mind.”

original: Khitakattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: khitaka thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of the Elder Khīṇaka is finished.

original: 5. Malitavambhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Ukkaṇṭhitoti āyasmato malitavambhattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ kira padumuttarassa
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ ti āyasmataḥ malitavambha ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam kira padumuttarassa
translated: The Story of the Elder Malitavambhiya

original: bhagavato kāle himavantato avidūre aññatarasmiṃ jātassare sakuṇo hutvā nibbatti,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ kāle himavantataḥ avidūre aññatarasmin jātassare sakuṇaḥ hutvā nibbatti
translated: “Dissatisfied,” etc. This religious instruction was given by the Teacher while he was in residence at Jetavana with reference to Elder Malitavambhiya. The story goes that in the dispensation of the Buddha Padumuttara this Elder was reborn among the birds in a certain lake not far from the Himalayas.

original: padumuttaro bhagavā taṃ anuggaṇhanto tattha gantvā jātassaratīre caṅkamati. Sakuṇo
analyzed: padumuttaraḥ bhagavā tam anuggaṇhantaḥ tattha gantvā jātassara tīre caṅkamati sakuṇaḥ
translated: The Buddha Padumuttara, in order to benefit this bird, went to that place and walked up and down on the bank of the lake. The bird

original: bhagavantaṃ disvā pasannamānaso sare kumudāni gahetvā bhagavantaṃ pūjesi. So tena
analyzed: bhagavantam disvā pasanna mānasaḥ sare kumudāni gahetvā bhagavantam pūjesi saḥ tena
translated: saw the Buddha and became filled with joy. He took some waterlilies from the lake and worshipped the Buddha.

original: puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde kurukacchanagare aññatarassa
analyzed: puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde kurukaccha nagare aññatarassa
translated: As the fruit of this deed he passed through the round of existences in happy states of existence, and in the dispensation of the present Buddha he was reborn in the city of Kuru as the son of a certain Brahman.

original: brāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti, malitavambhotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So viññutaṃ patto
analyzed: brāhmaṇassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti malitavambhotissa nāmam ahosi saḥ viññutam patto
translated: He was reborn as the son of a brahmin and was named Malitavambhi. When he had reached years of discretion,

original: pacchābhūmahātheraṃ upasaṅkamitvā tassa santike dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā🔽vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto viharati. Tassa ca ayaṃ sabhāvo, yattha bhojanasappāyo
analyzed: pacchābhū mahā theram upasaṅkamitvā tassa santike dhammaṃ sutvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā  vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ viharati tassa ca ayam sabhāvaḥ yattha bhojana sappāyo
translated: he went to the Elder Pacchābhu and listened to the Dhamma in his presence. He became a believer and went forth into homelessness.

original: dullabho, itare sulabhā, tato na pakkamati. Yattha pana bhojanasappāyo sulabho, itare🔽dullabhā, tattha na vasati pakkamateva. Evaṃ viharanto ca hetusampannatāya mahāpurisajātikatāya
analyzed: dullabhaḥ itare sulabhā tatas na pakkamati yattha pana bhojana sappāyo sulabhaḥ itare  dullabhā tattha na vasati evam viharantaḥ ca hetu sampanna tāya mahā purisa jātika tāya
translated: He made his persistence in insight his practice and lived in a place where the requisites were hard to obtain and other things easy, and he did not leave that place. But when the requisites were easy to obtain and other things hard, he did not stay there but left.

original: ca nacirasseva vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: ca nacirassa iva vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: While living thus, he soon developed insight by reason of his possession of the root cause and because of his being a great man, and he reached Arahantship. Hence it is said in the Apadana:🔽“Not far from the Himalayas

original: “Himavantassāvidūre, mahājātassaro ahu;
analyzed: himavantaḥ sāvidūre mahā jātaḥ saraḥ ahu
translated: was a great lake🔽Covered with lotuses and water lilies,

original: Padumuppalasañchanno, puṇḍarīkasamotthaṭo.
analyzed: paduma uppala sañchannaḥ
translated: and with white water lilies in bloom.

original: “Kukuttho nāma nāmena, tatthāsiṃ sakuṇo tadā;
analyzed: kukutthaḥ nāma nāmena tattha asim sakuṇaḥ tadā
translated: “I was a bird called a cuckoo there,🔽and I was virtuous, wise,

original: Sīlavā buddhisampanno, puññāpuññesu kovido.
analyzed: sīlavā buddhi sampannaḥ puññāpuññesu kovidaḥ
translated: and skilled in what is good and bad.”

original: “Padumuttaro lokavidū, āhutīnaṃ paṭiggaho;
analyzed: padumuttaraḥ loka vidū āhutīnam paṭiggahaḥ
translated: “Padumuttara, the world’s knower, the receiver of offerings,

original: Jātassarassāvidūre, sañcarittha mahāmuni.
analyzed: jātaḥ saraḥ sa avidūre mahā muni
translated: The great sage wandered in the vicinity of the Jātasaddā River.

original: “Jalajaṃ kumudaṃ chetvā, upanesiṃ mahesino;
analyzed: jala jam kumudam chetvā upanesim mahesinaḥ
translated: “Having cut a water-born lotus, I offered it to the Great Seer;

original: Mama saṅkappamaññāya, paṭiggahi mahāmuni.
analyzed: mama saṅkappam aññāya paṭiggahi mahā muni
translated: The great sage received it, knowing my intention.

original: “Tañca dānaṃ daditvāna, sukkamūlena codito;
analyzed: tat ca dānam daditvāna sukka mūlena
translated: “Having given that gift, urged by the root of merit,

original: Kappānaṃ satasahassaṃ, duggatiṃ nupapajjahaṃ.
analyzed: kappānam sata sahassam duggatim nu papajjaham
translated: For a hundred thousand eons, I did not fall into a bad destination.

original: “Soḷaseto kappasate, āsuṃ varuṇanāmakā;
analyzed: āsum varuṇa nāmakā
translated: “For sixteen hundred eons, there were those named Varuṇa;

original: Aṭṭha ete janādhipā, cakkavattī mahabbalā.
analyzed: aṭṭha ete janādhipā cakkavattī mahat balā
translated: These eight world-rulers, powerful wheel-turners,

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are burned away… the Buddha’s teaching is done.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā attano paṭipattiṃ paccavekkhitvā udānento –
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā attanaḥ paṭipattim paccavekkhitvā udānento
translated: But having attained arahatship, reflecting on his own practice, he uttered this exalted utterance:

original: “Ukkaṇṭhitopi na vase, ramamānopi pakkame;
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitaḥ api na vase ramamānaḥ api pakkame
translated: “Even if dissatisfied, one should not stay; even if delighted, one should depart.

original: Na tvevānatthasaṃhitaṃ, vase vāsaṃ vicakkhaṇo”ti. – gāthaṃ abhāsi;
analyzed: na tu eva anattha saṃhitam vase vāsam vicakkhaṇo ti gātham abhāsi
translated: The discerning one should not stay in a place that is not conducive to welfare.”

original: Tattha ukkaṇṭhitopi na vaseti yasmiṃ āvāse vasantassa me bhojanasappāyālābhena adhikusalesu
analyzed: tattha ukkaṇṭhitaḥ api na vaseti yasmin āvāse vasantassa me bhojana sappāya alābhena adhi kusalesu
translated: Herein, even if dissatisfied means if, while dwelling in a certain dwelling, one does not obtain suitable food, etc., and is dissatisfied,

original: dhammesu ukkaṇṭhā anabhirati uppajjati, tattha ukkaṇṭhitopi vasāmiyeva itarasappāyalābhena
analyzed: dhammesu ukkaṇṭhā anabhirati uppajjati tattha ukkaṇṭhitaḥ api vasāmiya iva itara sappāya lābhena
translated: Dissatisfaction and discontent arise in him about the Dhamma. There, though dissatisfied, he still lives on, not departing, not going away, because of the availability of other favorable conditions.

original: na pakkame na pakkamāmi. Na vaseti ettha na-kārenapi pakkametipadaṃ sambandhitabbaṃ.
