translated: Or they must be guarded all the time because they must be guarded by the husband’s giving them clothes and ornaments, etc., in order to keep their minds from straying elsewhere.

original: vā mālāgandhādīhi paṭicchādanavasena rakkhitabbacittatāya rakkhitabbāti. Yāsu saccaṃ🔽sudullabhanti yāsu saccavacanaṃ laddhuṃ na sakkā, itthiyo hi aggimpi pavisanti, visampi
analyzed: vā mālā gandha ādīhi paṭicchādana vasena rakkhitabba citta tāya rakkhitabbā ati yāsu saccam  su dullabhanti yāsu sacca vacanam laddhum na sakkā itthiyaḥ hi aggim pi pavisanti visam pi
translated: Or they must be guarded because they must be guarded by concealing their bodily nature with garlands, scents, etc.

original: khādanti, satthampi āharanti, ubbandhitvāpi kālaṃ karonti, na pana sacce ṭhātuṃ sakkonti.
analyzed: khādanti sattham pi āharanti ubbandhitvā api kālam karonti na pana sacce ṭhātum sakkonti
translated: In whom truth is very hard to find: in whom a true statement is very hard to find. For women enter the fire, eat poison, take their own life, and hang themselves, but they cannot keep to the truth.

original: Tasmā evarūpā itthiyo vajjetvā ṭhitā munayo sukhitā vatāti dasseti.🔽138. Idāni yassa appahīnattā evarūpāsu itthīsupi bajjhanti, tassa kāmassa attano
analyzed: tasmai evarūpāḥ itthiyaḥ vajjetvā ṭhitāḥ munayaḥ sukhitāḥ vata ati dasseti 🔽idāni yassa appahīna ttā evarūpāsu itthīsu pi bajjhanti tassa kāmassa attano
translated: So the sage who rejects such women and abides aloof is happy, is what is shown.🔽Now, in order to show the danger in the kind of pleasure that is not abandoned in the seven kinds of women, he said:

original: suppahīnataṃ accantaniṭṭhitatañca dassento dutiyaṃ gāthamāha. Vadhaṃ carimha te kāmāti🔽ambho kāma, tava vadhaṃ accantasamucchedaṃ ariyamaggena carimha, “vadhaṃ carimhase”tipi
analyzed: su ppahīna tatam accanta niṭṭhita tatam ca dassentaḥ dutiyam gātham āha vadham carimha te kāmā ti  ambho kāma tava vadham ariya maggena carimha vadham
translated: Showing the state of being well abandoned and the state of being utterly finished, he uttered the second verse:🔽“We have gone to your destruction, O Desire,

original: pāṭho, vadhāya pahānāya maggabrahmacariyaṃ acarimhāti attho. Anaṇā dāni te mayanti
analyzed: vadhāya pahānāya magga brahmacariyam acarimha ati attho anaṇā dāni te
translated: “O Desire, we have gone to your destruction, to your utter annihilation, by the Noble Path. The reading “We have gone to your destruction” is also acceptable. The meaning is: we have lived the holy life for the abandoning of destruction.🔽“We are now free from your debt,

original: idāni aggamaggapattito paṭṭhāya iṇabhāvakarāya pahīnattā kāma te anaṇā mayaṃ, na🔽tuyhaṃ iṇaṃ dhārema. Avītarāgo hi rāgassa vase vattanato tassa iṇaṃ dhārento viya
analyzed: idāni agga magga pattitaḥ paṭṭhāya iṇa bhāva karāya kāma te anaṇāḥ mayam na  tuyham iṇam dhārema a vīta rāgaḥ hi rāgassa vase tassa iṇam dhārentaḥ viya
translated: From now on, from the time of attaining the path of stream-entry, we are free from the state of being indebted to you, O Desire, because we have abandoned the state of being indebted to you.🔽For one who is not free from lust, by acting under the influence of lust, becomes as if indebted to him .

original: hoti, vītarāgo pana taṃ atikkamitvā paramena cittissariyena samannāgato. Anaṇattā🔽eva gacchāma dāni nibbānaṃ, yattha gantvā na socati yasmiṃ nibbāne gamanahetu sabbaso
analyzed: hoti vīta rāgaḥ pana tam atikkamitvā paramena cittissariyena samannāgataḥ anaṇattā  eva gacchāma dāni nibbānam yattha gantvā na socati yasmim nibbāne gamana hetu sabbaso
translated: But one who is free from lust, having overcome that , is endowed with the highest kind of freedom.🔽“We are now free from your debt,

original: sokahetūnaṃ abhāvato na socati, taṃ anupādisesanibbānameva idāni gacchāma anupāpuṇāmāti attho.
analyzed: soka hetūnam abhāvataḥ na socati tam anupādisesa nibbānam eva idāni gacchāma anupāpuṇāma ati attho
translated: we now go to Nibbāna, having gone to which one does not grieve, to that Nibbāna for the sake of going to which one does not grieve because of the absence of all causes for grief. The meaning is: we now go to Nibbāna without remainder.

original: Gotamattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: gotama thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Gotama is finished.

original: 10. Vasabhattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vasabhatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: Vasabha’s verses

original: Pubbe hanati attānanti āyasmato vasabhattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu🔽katādhikāro tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto buddhasuññe loke brāhmaṇakule
analyzed: pubbe āyasmataḥ vasabha ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu  kata adhikāraḥ tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ buddha suññe loke brāhmaṇa kule
translated: “He first of all destroys himself” . This was said, it seems, by the venerable elder Vasabha. What was its origin? This elder too, while he was still a bodhisatta,🔽had made his aspiration under a Paccekabuddha and had fulfilled the practice of the pāramīs. In the dispensation of the same Conqueror he had become a Paccekabuddha himself.🔽After he had passed away, the world was empty of Buddhas for a long period of time. Then in a certain existence in the time of the Buddha Kassapa he aroused his mind to the life of a contemplative, and after he had completed and fulfilled the ten perfections beginning with giving, he was reborn in the Brahma-world.

original: nibbattitvā vayappatto brāhmaṇānaṃ vijjāsippesu nipphattiṃ gantvā nekkhammajjhāsayatāya🔽gharāvāsaṃ pahāya tāpasapabbajjaṃ pabbajitvā cuddasasahassatāpasaparivāro himavantassa
analyzed: nibbattitvā vaya ppattaḥ brāhmaṇānam vijjā sippesu nipphattim gantvā nekkhamma ajjhāsaya tāya  ghara āvāsam pahāya tāpasa pabbajjam pabbajitvā cuddasa sahassa tāpasa parivāraḥ himavantassa
translated: When the world was empty of Buddhas, he was reborn in a brahmin family in the city of Bandhumati.🔽When he grew up and had mastered the three Vedas with their vocabularies, rituals, liturgy, and etymology, and the histories as the fifth, he went forth into homelessness in the doctrine of the Buddha Kassapa.🔽He lived in a hermitage on the Samgha mountain, fourteen thousand leagues from the Himalayas.

original: avidūre samagge nāma pabbate assamaṃ kāretvā vasanto jhānābhiññāyo nibbattetvā tāpasānaṃ
analyzed: avidūre samagge nāma pabbate assamam kāretvā vasantaḥ jhāna abhiññāyaḥ nibbattetvā tāpasānam
translated: He attained the jhānas and the direct knowledges and gave advice and instruction to the ascetics.

original: ovādānusāsaniyo dento ekadivasaṃ evaṃ cintesi – “ahaṃ kho dāni imehi tāpasehi sakkato
analyzed: ovāda anusāsaniyaḥ dentaḥ eka divasam evam cintesi aham kho dāni imehi tāpasehi sakkataḥ
translated: One day he thought: “I am honoured, revered, esteemed, and worshipped by these ascetics, but I do not see anyone to honour.

original: garukato pūjito viharāmi, mayā pana pūjetabbo na upalabbhati, dukkho kho panāyaṃ
analyzed: garukataḥ pūjitaḥ viharāmi mayā pana pūjetabbaḥ na upalabbhati dukkhaḥ kho pana ayam
translated: It is painful to be a teacher of the Dhamma.”

original: loke yadidaṃ agaruvāso”ti. Evaṃ pana cintetvā purimabuddhesu katādhikāratāya purimabuddhānaṃ🔽cetiye attanā kataṃ pūjāsakkāraṃ anussaritvā “yaṃnūnāhaṃ purimabuddhe uddissa pulinacetiyaṃ🔽katvā pūjaṃ kareyya”nti haṭṭhatuṭṭho iddhiyā pulinathūpaṃ suvaṇṇamayaṃ māpetvā suvaṇṇamayādīhi
analyzed: loke yat idam evam pana cintetvā purima buddhesu kata adhikāra tāya  cetiye attanā katam pūjā sakkāram anussaritvā yaṃ nūna aham purima buddhe uddissa pulina cetiyam  katvā pūjam kareyyanti haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ iddhiyā pulina thūpam suvaṇṇa mayam māpetvā suvaṇṇa maya ādīhi
translated: the best in the world is the robe of the Ascetic.”🔽Having thought thus, he remembered the worship and honour he had himself paid to the shrines of the Buddhas of the past, because he had performed acts of merit under them.🔽“Suppose I were to build a shrine on the bank of the river and worship it in honour of the Buddhas of the past?”

original: tisahassamattehi pupphehi devasikaṃ pūjaṃ karonto yāvatāyukaṃ puññāni katvā aparihīnajjhāno
analyzed: ti sahassa mattehi pupphehi devasikam pūjam karontaḥ yāvatāyukam puññāni katvā a parihīna jjhānaḥ
translated: Delighted and joyful, he had a golden shrine built by his psychic power on the bank of the river, and he worshipped it daily with three thousand flowers of gold and other precious substances.

original: kālaṃ katvā brahmaloke nibbatto. Tatthapi yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā tato cuto tāvatiṃse🔽nibbattitvā aparāparaṃ devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde vesāliyaṃ licchavirājakule
analyzed: kālam katvā brahmaloke nibbatto tattha api yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā tatas cuto tāvatiṃse  nibbattitvā apara aparam deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde vesāliyam licchavi rāja kule
translated: For the remainder of his life he performed works of merit, and when he died he was reborn in the Brahma-world, still in possession of the jhānas.🔽After living there for the remainder of his life, he was reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, and passing from one state of bliss to another in the worlds of the gods and men,🔽he was reborn in the Licchavi royal family at Vesālī in this dispensation of the Buddha.

original: nibbattitvā vasabhoti laddhanāmo vayappatto bhagavato vesāligamane buddhānubhāvaṃ
analyzed: nibbattitvā vasabhaḥ iti laddha nāmaḥ vaya pattaḥ bhagavataḥ vesāli gamane buddha anubhāvam
translated: He was given the name Vasabha, and when he reached manhood, he saw the psychic powers of the Buddha during the Buddha’s visit to Vesālī.

original: disvā paṭiladdhasaddho pabbajitvā vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā nacirasseva arahattaṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: disvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ pabbajitvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi
translated: Having seen him, he gained faith, went forth, and after developing insight, he attained arahantship in no long time.

original: Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Himavantassāvidūre, samaggo nāma pabbato;
analyzed: himavantassa avidūre samaggaḥ nāma pabbataḥ
translated: “Not far from the Himalayas, there is a mountain named Samagga;

original: Assamo sukato mayhaṃ, paṇṇasālā sumāpitā.
analyzed: assamaḥ su kataḥ mayham paṇṇa sālā su māpitā
translated: My hermitage was well-made, my leaf-hut well-built.

original: “Nārado nāma nāmena, jaṭilo uggatāpano;
analyzed: nāradaḥ nāma nāmena jaṭilaḥ
translated: “My name was Nārada, I was a knotted-haired ascetic, a man of great austerities;

original: Catuddasasahassāni, sissā paricaranti maṃ.
analyzed: catuddasa sahassāni sissā paricaranti mama
translated: Fourteen thousand disciples served me.

original: “Paṭisallīnako santo, evaṃ cintesahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: paṭisallīnakaḥ santo evam cintesaham tadā
translated: “I was secluded and peaceful, and at that time I thought thus:

original: Sabbo jano maṃ pūjeti, nāhaṃ pūjemi kiñcanaṃ.
analyzed: sabbaḥ janaḥ mam pūjeti na aham pūjemi kiñcanaṃ
translated: All people honor me, I do not honor anyone.

original: “Na me ovādako atthi, vattā koci na vijjati;
analyzed: na me ovādakaḥ atthi vattā koci na vijjati
translated: “There is no one to advise me, there is no one to reprove me;

original: Anācariyupajjhāyo, vane vāsaṃ upemahaṃ.
analyzed: vane vāsam
translated: Without a teacher or preceptor, I live in the forest.

original: “Upāsamāno yamahaṃ, garucittaṃ upaṭṭhahe;
analyzed: upāsamānaḥ yam aham garu cittam upaṭṭhahe
translated: “As I was attending on one who was venerable, with a mind of respect,

original: So me ācariyo natthi, vanavāso niratthako.
analyzed: saḥ me ācariyaḥ natthi vana vāsaḥ niratthakaḥ
translated: He is not my teacher, living in the forest is useless.

original: “Āyāgaṃ me gavesissaṃ, garuṃ bhāvaniyaṃ tathā;
analyzed: āyāgam me gavesissam garum bhāvaniyam tathā
translated: “I will seek one to honor, one who is venerable and worthy of esteem;

original: Sāvassayo vasissāmi, na koci garahissati.
analyzed: sa avassayaḥ vasissāmi na koci garahissati
translated: I will live with confidence, no one will reprove me.

original: “Uttānakūlā nadikā, supatitthā manoramā;
analyzed: uttāna kūlā nadikā supatitthā manoramā
translated: “There is a river with a pleasant ford, with sloping banks, delightful;

original: Saṃsuddhapulinākiṇṇā, avidūre mamassamaṃ.
analyzed: saṃsuddha pulina ākiṇṇāḥ avidūre
translated: And a pure sand-bank not far from my hermitage.

original: “Nadiṃ amarikaṃ nāma, upagantvānahaṃ tadā;
analyzed: nadim amarikam nāma upagantvā an aham tadā
translated: “Having gone to the river called Aṃarikā,

original: Saṃvaḍḍhayitvā pulinaṃ, akaṃ pulinacetiyaṃ.
analyzed: saṃvaḍḍhayitvā pulinam akam pulina cetiyam
translated: I increased the sand-bank, and made the Sand-bank Shrine.

original: “Ye te ahesuṃ sambuddhā, bhavantakaraṇā munī;
analyzed: ye te ahesum sambuddhāḥ bhavanta karaṇāḥ munī
translated: “Those who were the Awakened Ones, the Sages who remove (the possibility of) existence,

original: Tesaṃ etādiso thūpo, taṃ nimittaṃ karomahaṃ.
analyzed: tesam etādisaḥ thūpaḥ tam nimittam karomaham
translated: Their shrines were like this, I make that sign.

original: “Karitvā pulinaṃ thūpaṃ, sovaṇṇaṃ māpayiṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: karitvā pulinam thūpam sovaṇṇam aham
translated: “Having made the Sand-bank Shrine, I had it made of gold,

original: Soṇṇakiṅkaṇipupphāni, sahasse tīṇi pūjayiṃ.
analyzed: soṇṇa kiṅkaṇi pupphāni sahasse tīṇi
translated: And with three thousand golden flowers I worshipped it.

original: “Sāyapātaṃ namassāmi, vedajāto katañjalī;
analyzed: sāyapātam namassāmi veda jātaḥ katañjalī
translated: “In the evening I worshipped, having given rise to knowledge, with my hands joined in respect,

original: Sammukhā viya sambuddhaṃ, vandiṃ pulinacetiyaṃ.
analyzed: sammukhāḥ sambuddham vandim pulina cetiyam
translated: And as if face to face with the Awakened One, I worshipped the Sand-bank Shrine.

original: “Yadā kilesā jāyanti, vitakkā gehanissitā;
analyzed: yadā kilesāḥ jāyanti vitakkāḥ geha nissitā
translated: “When defilements and thoughts connected with the household life arise,

original: Sarāmi sukataṃ thūpaṃ, paccavekkhāmi tāvade.
analyzed: sarāmi su katam thūpam paccavekkhāmi tāvade
translated: I remember the well-made shrine, and at that time I reflect (on it).

original: “Upanissāya viharaṃ, satthavāhaṃ vināyakaṃ;
analyzed: upanissāya viharam satthavāham vināyakam
translated: “Dwelling in dependence on the Teacher, the Leader,

original: Kilese saṃvaseyyāsi, na yuttaṃ tava mārisa.
analyzed: kilese saṃvaseyyāsi na yuttam tava mārisa
translated: You should not live with defilements, dear Sir, it is not right for you.

original: “Saha āvajjite thūpe, gāravaṃ hoti me tadā;
analyzed: sahaḥ āvajjite thūpe gāravam me tadā
translated: “When I advert to the shrine, at that time I have respect,

original: Kuvitakke vinodesiṃ, nāgo tuttaṭṭito yathā.
analyzed: ku vitakke nāgaḥ tutta ṭṭitaḥ yathā
translated: And I dispel bad thoughts, like an elephant (sprayed with) water when (in musth).

original: “Evaṃ viharamānaṃ maṃ, maccurājābhimaddatha;
analyzed: evam viharamānam mam maccu rāja abhimaddatha
translated: “Thus did I live, O King of Death, you who would destroy me;

original: Tattha kālaṅkato santo, brahmalokamagacchahaṃ.
analyzed: tattha kālaṅkataḥ santaḥ brahma lokam agacchaham
translated: And having died there, I went to the world of the Brahmās.

original: “Yāvatāyuṃ vasitvāna, tidive upapajjahaṃ;
analyzed: yāvatā āyum vasitvāna tidive upapad jaham
translated: “Having lived there for the full life-span, I was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three;

original: Asītikkhattuṃ devindo, devarajjamakārayiṃ.
analyzed: devindaḥ deva rajjam akārayim
translated: Eighty times I was Sakka, king of the devas,

original: “Satānaṃ tīṇikkhattuñca, cakkavattī ahosahaṃ;
analyzed: satānam cakkavattī ahosaham
translated: “Three times a king of the Suras, a universal monarch;

original: Padesarajjaṃ vipulaṃ, gaṇanāto asaṅkhiyaṃ.
analyzed: padesa rajjam vipulam gaṇanātaḥ asaṅkhiyam
translated: And countless times a king of a small territory.

original: “Soṇṇakiṅkaṇipupphānaṃ, vipākaṃ anubhomahaṃ;
analyzed: vipākam
translated: “I experienced the result of the golden flowers;

original: Dhātīsatasahassāni, parivārenti maṃ bhave.
analyzed: dhātī sata sahassāni parivārenti mam bhave
translated: A hundred thousand treasures surrounded me in existence.

original: “Thūpassa pariciṇṇattā, rajojallaṃ na limpati;
analyzed: thūpassa pariciṇṇattā rajaḥ jallam na limpati
translated: “Because I worshipped the Thūpa, dust and dirt did not stick to me;

original: Gatte sedā na muccanti, suppabhāso bhavāmahaṃ.
analyzed: gatte sedāḥ na muccanti su pabhāsaḥ bhavāmaham
translated: Sweat did not flow from my body, I became very radiant.

original: “Aho me sukato thūpo, sudiṭṭhāmarikā nadī;
analyzed: aho me su kataḥ thūpaḥ su diṭṭhā amarikā nadī
translated: “Ah, well made is my Thūpa, well seen is the Arikā River;

original: Thūpaṃ katvāna pulinaṃ, pattomhi acalaṃ padaṃ.
analyzed: thūpam katvāna pulinam acalam padam
translated: Having made the Thūpa on the sandbank, I have attained the unshakable state.

original: “Kusalaṃ kattukāmena, jantunā sāragāhinā;
analyzed: kusalam kattu kāmena jantunā sāra gāhinā
translated: “By one who desires to do good, by a person who seeks the essence,

original: Natthi khettaṃ akhettaṃ vā, paṭipattīva sādhakā.
analyzed: natthi khettam akhettam vā paṭipatti iva sādhakā
translated: There is no field or non-field, only practice is effective.

original: “Yathāpi balavā poso, aṇṇavaṃtaritussahe;
analyzed: yathā api balavā posaḥ anṇavaṃtarituḥ sahe
translated: “Just as a strong man, having crossed a swamp with difficulty,

original: Parittaṃ kaṭṭhamādāya, pakkhandeyya mahāsaraṃ.
analyzed: parittam kaṭṭham ādāya pakkhandeyya mahā saram
translated: Taking a small piece of wood, he would cross the great ocean.

original: “Imāhaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ nissāya, tarissāmi mahodadhiṃ;
analyzed: imā aham kaṭṭham nissāya tarissāmi mahā udadhim
translated: “Relying on this piece of wood, I will cross the great ocean.

original: Ussāhena vīriyena, tareyya udadhiṃ naro.
analyzed: ussāhena vīriyena tareyyaḥ udadhim naraḥ
translated: Through persistence and energy, a man can cross the ocean.

original: “Tatheva me kataṃ kammaṃ, parittaṃ thokakañca yaṃ;
analyzed: tathā iva me katam kammam parittam thokakam ca yam
translated: “So too, the small and little deed that I did,

original: Taṃ kammaṃ upanissāya, saṃsāraṃ samatikkamiṃ.
analyzed: tam kammaṃ upanissāya saṃsāram samatikkamiṃ
translated: Relying on that deed, I have crossed the round of rebirths.

original: “Pacchime bhave sampatte, sukkamūlena codito;
analyzed: pacchime bhave sampatte sukka mūlena codito
translated: “In my last existence, urged on by the root of merit,

original: Sāvatthiyaṃ pure jāto, mahāsāle suaḍḍhake.
analyzed: sāvatthiyam pure jātaḥ mahāsāle suaḍḍhake
translated: I was born in the city of Sāvatthī, in a large and wealthy household.

original: “Saddhā mātā pitā mayhaṃ, buddhassa saraṇaṃ gatā;
analyzed: saddhā mātā pitā mayham buddhassa saraṇam gatā
translated: “My mother and father had faith and went for refuge to the Buddha.

original: Ubho diṭṭhapadā ete, anuvattanti sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: ubho diṭṭhapadāḥ ete anuvattanti sāsanam
translated: Both of them had seen the state of peace, and they followed the Teacher’s instruction.

original: “Bodhipapaṭikaṃ gayha, soṇṇathūpamakārayuṃ;
analyzed: bodhipa paṭikam gayha
translated: “They took a piece of Bodhi tree and had a golden stūpa made.

original: Sāyapātaṃ namassanti, sakyaputtassa sammukhā.
analyzed: sāyapātam namassanti sakya puttassa sammukhā
translated: They worshipped it at the proper time, in the presence of the Son of the Sakyans.

original: “Uposathamhi divase, soṇṇathūpaṃ vinīharuṃ;
analyzed: uposathamhi divase soṇṇa thūpam vinīharum
translated: “On the Uposatha day, they decorated the golden stūpa.

original: Buddhassa vaṇṇaṃ kittentā, tiyāmaṃ vītināmayuṃ.
analyzed: buddhassa vaṇṇam kittentā ti yāmam vītināmayum
translated: Praising the Buddha, they spent the day and night.

original: “Saha disvānahaṃ thūpaṃ, sariṃ pulinacetiyaṃ;

original: te payirupāsanāya ārādhitacittā kañci upanisīditukāmā honti, atha ne upanisīditvā
analyzed: te payirupāsanāya ārādhita cittā kañci upanisīditu kāmāḥ honti atha ne upanisīditvā
translated: and when he wishes to sit down near him, he should sit down near him

original: adhigatāya sotumicchāya ohitasotena sotabbaṃ hotīti garusannivāsopi sussūsāhetutāya
analyzed: adhigatāya sotum icchāya ohita sotena sotabbam hoti iti garu sannivāsaḥ api sussūsā hetutāya
translated: and listen with his mind bent on learning. So the eager hearer is a cause for the eager hearer because he is a condition for the eager hearer.

original: “sussūsā”ti vuccati. Sā panāyaṃ sussūsā saccapaṭiccasamuppādādipaṭisaṃyuttaṃ sutaṃ
analyzed: sussūsā ati vuccati sā pana ayam sussūsā sacca paṭiccasamuppāda ādi paṭisaṃyuttam sutam
translated: “One who is listening” is called a listener. This listening to the teaching of the Dhamma, which is concerned with the four noble truths, the three characteristics, dependent origination, etc.,

original: taṃsamaṅgino puggalassa vaḍḍheti brūhetīti sutavaddhanī, bāhusaccakārīti attho. Sutaṃ🔽paññāya vaddhananti yaṃ taṃ “sutadharo sutasannicayo”ti “idhekaccassa bahukaṃ sutaṃ
analyzed: tad samaṅgino puggalassa bāhusaccakārī iti  paññāya yam tam suta dharo suta sannicayo ti idha ekaccassa bahukam sutam
translated: increases, expands, and extends the person who possesses it. Thus it is called the “development of listening,” the meaning being that it is the doer of much.

original: hoti suttaṃ geyyaṃ veyyākaraṇa”nti ca evamādinā nayena vuttaṃ bāhusaccaṃ, taṃ akusalappahānakusalādhigamanahetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: hoti suttam geyyam veyyākaraṇam ti ca evamādinā nayena vuttam bāhusaccam tam akusala ppahāna kusala adhigamana hetu bhūtam
translated: The development of wisdom through listening: the much learning that was spoken of in the way beginning, “Here someone has learned much, he has remembered and kept it in mind, he has investigated it with his mind, and has well penetrated it with his views” is the cause for the abandoning of the unwholesome and the acquiring of the wholesome.

original: paññaṃ vaddhetīti sutaṃ paññāya vaddhanaṃ, vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: paññam vaddha iti iti sutam paññāya vaddhanam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: It develops wisdom, which is the cause for the abandoning of the unwholesome and the acquiring of the wholesome.

original: “Sutāvudho kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako akusalaṃ pajahati, kusalaṃ bhāveti, sāvajjaṃ pajahati, anavajjaṃ bhāveti, suddhaṃ attānaṃ pariharatī”ti.
analyzed: sutāvudhaḥ kho bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ akusalam pajahati kusalam bhāveti sāvajjam pajahati anavajjam bhāveti suddham attānam pariharati iti
translated: This is said by the Blessed One: “Bhikkhus, the noble disciple who is possessed of learning abandons the unwholesome and develops the wholesome. He abandons the reproachable and develops the irreproachable. He keeps himself pure” .

original: Paññāya atthaṃ jānātīti bahussuto sutamayañāṇe ṭhito taṃ paṭipattiṃ paṭipajjanto
analyzed: paññāya attham jānāti iti bahu sutaḥ suta maya ñāṇe ṭhitaḥ tam paṭipattim paṭipajjanto
translated: The wise one knows the meaning through wisdom: the one who is established in the knowledge consisting in what is heard, who practices the practice consisting in what is heard,

original: sutānusārena atthūpaparikkhāya dhammanijjhānena bhāvanāya ca lokiyalokuttarabhedaṃ
analyzed: suta anusārena attha upaparikkhāya dhamma nijjhānena bhāvanāya ca lokiya lokuttara bhedam
translated: He understands and penetrates the meaning of the truths, which is divided into mundane and supramundane,

original: diṭṭhadhammādivibhāgaṃ dukkhādivibhāgañca atthaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti ca paṭivijjhati
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma ādi vibhāgam dukkha ādi vibhāgañca attham yathābhūtam pajānāti ca paṭivijjhati
translated: and the meaning of the truths, which is divided into that of the present life, etc., and that of suffering, etc., as they truly are.

original: ca, tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: ca tena āha bhagavā
translated: Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Sutassa yathāpariyattassa atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hotī”ti.
analyzed: sutassa yathā pariyattassa attha maññāya dhamma maññāya dhamma anudhamma ppaṭipannaḥ hoti iti
translated: “When he has understood the meaning and the Dhamma as declared by him, he becomes one who practices in accordance with the Dhamma” .

original: “Dhatānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhati, atthaṃ upaparikkhato dhammā nijjhānaṃ khamanti,
analyzed: dhatānam dhammānam attham upaparikkhati attham upaparikkhataḥ dhammāḥ nijjhānam khamanti
translated: “He examines the meaning of the teachings he has remembered, and as he does so, the teachings are clarified.

original: dhammanijjhānakkhantiyā sati chando jāyati, chandajāto ussahati, ussahitvā tuleti,🔽tulayitvā padahati, pahitatto samāno kāyena ceva paramasaccaṃ sacchikaroti, paññāya
analyzed: dhamma nijjhāna khantiyā sati chandaḥ jāyati chanda jātaḥ ussahati ussahitvā tuleti  tulayitvā padahati pahitatto samāno kāyena ca iva paramasaccam sacchikaroti paññāya
translated: When there is clarification of the teachings, desire arises. When there is desire, he makes an effort. When he makes an effort, he achieves the ability to understand and penetrate the meaning of the truths.

original: ca naṃ ativijjha passatī”ti ca.
analyzed: ca nam ativijjha passati iti ca
translated: When he has achieved the ability to understand and penetrate the meaning of the truths, he realizes the ultimate truth with his body and sees it with wisdom.”

original: Ñāto attho sukhāvahoti yathāvutto diṭṭhadhammikādiattho ceva dukkhādiattho ca yāthāvato ñāto adhigato lokiyalokuttarabhedaṃ sukhaṃ āvahati nipphādetīti attho.
analyzed: ñātaḥ attho sukha āvaho ti yathā vuttaḥ diṭṭhadhammika ādi attho ca iva dukkha ādi attho ca yāthāvataḥ ñātaḥ adhigataḥ lokiya lokuttara bhedam sukham āvahati nipphādeti iti attho
translated: The meaning known brings happiness: the meaning stated as the kind of happiness in the here-and-now, etc., and the kind of happiness beginning with the absence of pain, is known, understood, as it really is, and it brings about, produces, happiness, which is divided into mundane and supramundane.

original: Ṭhitāya bhāvanāpaññāya sutamatteneva na sijjhatīti tassā paṭipajjanavidhiṃ dassento
analyzed: ṭhitāya bhāvanā paññāya suta mattena iva na sijjhati iti tassā paṭipajjana vidhim dassento
translated: Since it is not accomplished by mere learning when understanding is established by development, he said “One should frequent,” etc., showing the way to undertake it.

original: “sevetha…pe…vippamokkha”nti āha. Tattha sevetha pantāni senāsanānīti kāyavivekamāha.🔽Tena saṃyojanappahānassa ca vakkhamānattā vivekārahasseva vivekavāsoti sīlasaṃvarādayo🔽idha avuttasiddhā veditabbā. Careyya saṃyojanavippamokkhanti yathā saṃyojanehi cittaṃ
analyzed: āha tattha sevetha pantāni senāsanāni iti kāya vivekam āha  tena saṃyojana ppahānassa ca vakkhamāna ttā sīla saṃvara ādayaḥ  idha a vutta siddhā veditabbā careyya saṃyojana vippamokkhanti yathā saṃyojanehi cittam
translated: Herein, one should frequent remote abodes: he mentions bodily seclusion.🔽Since the abandoning of fetters is about to be stated, the dwelling in seclusion is for one who is worthy of the secluded life.🔽The restraint of the rules, etc., should be understood as already accomplished here.

original: vippamuccati, tathā vipassanābhāvanaṃ maggabhāvanañca careyya paṭipajjeyyāti attho.
analyzed: vippamuccati tathā vipassanā bhāvanam magga bhāvanañca careyya paṭipajjeyya ati attho
translated: One should practice for the deliverance of the mind from fetters: the meaning is that one should practice, undertake, insight and path development in such wise that the mind is delivered from fetters.

original: Sace ratiṃ nādhigaccheyya tatthāti tesu pantasenāsanesu yathāladdhesu adhikusaladhammesu
analyzed: sace ratim na adhigaccheyya tattha ati tesu panta senāsanesu yathā laddhesu adhi kusala dhammesu
translated: If one does not find delight there: in those remote abodes and in the more and more profitable states that have been obtained.

original: ca ratiṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesassa alābhato abhiratiṃ na labheyya, saṅghe bhikkhusamūhe🔽rakkhitatto kammaṭṭhānaparigaṇhanato rakkhitacitto chasu dvāresu satiārakkhāya upaṭṭhapanena
analyzed: ca ratim pubbena aparam visesassa alābhataḥ abhiratim na labheyya saṅghe bhikkhu samūhe  rakkhita ttaḥ kammaṭṭhāna parigaṇhanataḥ rakkhita citto chasu dvāresu sati ārakkhāya upaṭṭhapanena
translated: In the Sangha, in the community of bhikkhus,🔽he should be guarded, guarded in his meditation subject, and he should be mindful, should live mindfully, by establishing mindfulness as a door-keeper at the six doors.

original: satimā vaseyya vihareyya, evaṃ viharantassa ca api nāma saṃyojanavippamokkho bhaveyyāti adhippāyo.
analyzed: satimā vaseyya vihareyya evam viharantassa ca api nāma saṃyojana vippamokkhaḥ bhaveyya ati adhippāyaḥ
translated: The intention is that he should be liberated from the fetters.

original: Mahācundattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahācunda thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Maha-Cunda is finished.

original: 2. Jotidāsattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
translated: Jotidāsa-theragāthā-vanṇanā

original: Ye kho teti āyasmato jotidāsattherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayampi purimabuddhesu katādhikāro
analyzed: ye kho te iti āyasmataḥ jotidāsa therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam pi purima buddhesu kata adhikāraḥ
translated: Ye kho te, etc. These are the verses of the Elder Jotidāsa. Where did this Elder originate? He too had made his beginning under former Buddhas,

original: tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinanto sikhissa bhagavato kāle kulagehe nibbattitvā
analyzed: tattha tattha bhave puññāni upacinantaḥ sikhissa bhagavato kāle kula gehe nibbattitvā
translated: and in various existences had accumulated merit. In the dispensation of the Blessed One Sikhī he was reborn in a family of high standing,

original: viññutaṃ patto ekadivasaṃ satthāraṃ piṇḍāya gacchantaṃ disvā pasannacitto kāsumārikaphalaṃ
analyzed: viññutam patto eka divasam satthāram piṇḍāya gacchantam disvā pasanna cittaḥ kāsumārika phalam
translated: and when he had reached years of discretion, one day he saw the Teacher going on his alms round, and with a mind full of faith he gave him a mango fruit.

original: adāsi. So tena puññakammena devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde pādiyatthajanapade
analyzed: adāsi saḥ tena puñña kammena deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde pādiyattha janapade
translated: and he gave it. Through that deed of merit he went from birth to birth in the heavenly worlds and among men, and in this dispensation he was reborn in the Pādiyattarajanapaḍa

original: vibhavasampannassa brāhmaṇassa putto hutvā nibbatti, jotidāsotissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So🔽viññutaṃ patvā gharamāvasanto ekadivasaṃ mahākassapattheraṃ attano gāme piṇḍāya carantaṃ
analyzed: vibhava sampannassa brāhmaṇassa puttaḥ hutvā nibbatti jotidāsaḥ tissa nāmam ahosi so  viññutam patvā gharam āvasantaḥ eka divasam mahākassapa theram attanaḥ gāme piṇḍāya carantam
translated: as the son of a wealthy brāhmaṇa, and his name was Jotidāsa. When he🔽had reached years of discretion, he lived at home. One day he saw the Elder Mahākassapa going on his alms-round in his village,

original: disvā pasannacitto bhojetvā therassa santike dhammaṃ sutvā attano gāmasamīpe pabbate
analyzed: disvā pasanna cittaḥ bhojetvā therassa santike dhammaṃ sutvā attano gāma samīpe pabbate
translated: and with a glad heart he fed him. After hearing the Law from the Elder, he had a great monastery built on a mountain near his village,

original: mahantaṃ vihāraṃ kāretvā theraṃ tattha vāsetvā catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhahanto therassa
analyzed: mahantam vihāram kāretvā theram tattha vāsetvā catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhahantaḥ therassa
translated: and after inviting the Elder to live there, he ministered to him with the four requisites.

original: dhammadesanāya paṭiladdhasaṃvego pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva
analyzed: dhamma desanāya paṭiladdha saṃvegaḥ pabbajitvā vipassanāya kammam karontaḥ nacirassa eva
translated: When he heard the Elder preach the Law, he was deeply moved, and after he had gone forth and applied himself to the practice of insight,

original: chaḷabhiñño ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: chaḍabhiññaḥ ahosi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: he attained the six super-knowledges in no long time. Therefore it is said in the Apadāna:

original: “Kaṇikāraṃva jotantaṃ, nisinnaṃ pabbatantare;
analyzed: kaṇikāram iva jotantam nisinnam pabbata antare
translated: “Like a shining bush of kaṇikāra,

analyzed: addasam virajam buddham loka jeṭṭham narāsabham
translated: I saw the stainless Buddha, the chief of the world, the bull of a man,🔽seated in the midst of a mountain.🔽With a glad and joyful heart,

original: “Pasannacitto sumano, sire katvāna añjaliṃ;
analyzed: pasanna cittaḥ sumanaḥ sire katvāna añjalim
translated: I raised my joined hands in reverence,

original: Kāsumārikamādāya, buddhaseṭṭhassadāsahaṃ.
analyzed: kāsumārikam ādāya buddha seṭṭhaḥ sadāsaham
translated: And took a mango fruit, and gave it to the best of Buddhas.

original: “Ekatiṃse ito kappe, yaṃ phalaṃ adadiṃ tadā;
analyzed: ekatiṃse itas kappe yam phalam adadim tadā
translated: “Thirty-one cycles of time have passed away since then, and the fruit which I gave at that time

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, phaladānassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim na abhijānāmi phala dānassa idam phalam
translated: I do not remember having been reborn in any state of suffering. This is the fruit of giving the fruit.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My passions have been quenched. … The Dispensation of the Buddha has been fulfilled.”

original: Chaḷabhiñño pana hutvā tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā visesato vinayapiṭake sukusalabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pana hutvā tīṇi piṭakāni uggahetvā visesataḥ vinaya piṭake su kusala bhāvam
translated: After he had attained the six psychic powers, he learned the three Piṭakas by heart, and after he had become especially skilled in the Vinaya Piṭaka,

original: patvā dasavassiko parisupaṭṭhāko ca hutvā bahūhi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ bhagavantaṃ vandituṃ
analyzed: patvā dasa vassiko parisupaṭṭhāko ca hutvā bahūhi bhikkhūhi saddhim bhagavantam vanditum
translated: he became a teacher of the Order, and when he had reached the age of ten years, he went with many monks to Sāvatthi to pay his respects to the Buddha.

original: sāvatthiṃ gacchanto antarāmagge addhānaparissamavinodanatthaṃ titthiyānaṃ ārāmaṃ
analyzed: sāvatthim gacchantaḥ antarāmagge addhāna parissama vinodana attham titthiyānam ārāmam
translated: On the way he entered the monastery of the sectarians in order to rest from his journey.

original: pavisitvā ekamantaṃ nisinno ekaṃ pañcatapaṃ tapantaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ disvā, “kiṃ, brāhmaṇa,
analyzed: pavisitvā ekamantam nisinnaḥ ekam pañcatapam tapantam brāhmaṇam disvā kim brāhmaṇa
translated: While he was sitting on one side, he saw a brāhmaṇa who was practising the five austerities. He asked him, “Brāhmaṇa,

original: aññasmiṃ tapanīye aññaṃ tapatī”ti āha. Taṃ sutvā brāhmaṇo kupito, “bho, muṇḍaka,
analyzed: aññasmin tapanīye aññam tapati iti āha tam sutvā brāhmaṇaḥ kupitaḥ bho muṇḍaka
translated: do you practise one austerity and teach another?” When the brāhmaṇa heard this, he became angry and said, “You shaveling monk,

original: kiṃ aññaṃ tapanīya”nti āha. Thero tassa –
analyzed: kim aññam tapanīyanti āha thero tassa
translated: what do you mean by saying that?” The Elder said to him,🔽“

original: “Kopo ca issā paraheṭhanā ca, māno ca sārambhamado pamādo;
analyzed: kopaḥ ca issā para heṭhanā ca mānaḥ ca sa ārambha madaḥ pamādaḥ
translated: “Anger, envy, and the harming of others, pride, violence, and heedlessness,

original: Taṇhā avijjā bhavasaṅgatī ca, te tappanīyā na hi rūpakhandho”ti. –
analyzed: taṇhā avijjā bhava saṅgatī ca te tappanīyāḥ na hi rūpa khandhaḥ ti
translated: Craving, ignorance, and attachment to existence: these are to be regretted, not the form-aggregate.”

original: Gāthāya dhammaṃ desesi. Taṃ sutvā so brāhmaṇo tasmiṃ titthiyārāme sabbe aññatitthiyā
analyzed: gāthāya dhammam desesi tam sutvā so brāhmaṇaḥ tasmin titthiya ārāme sabbe añña titthiyā
translated: Having heard this verse, the brahmin went to all the other sectarians in that heretical monastery

original: ca therassa santike pabbajiṃsu. Thero tehi saddhiṃ sāvatthiṃ gantvā bhagavantaṃ vanditvā
analyzed: ca therassa santike pabbajiṃsu theraḥ tehi saddhim sāvatthim gantvā bhagavantam vanditvā
translated: and they all went forth in the presence of the Elder. The Elder went with them to Sāvatthī, paid homage to the Blessed One,

original: katipāhaṃ tattha vasitvā attano jātibhūmiṃyeva gato dassanatthaṃ upagatesu ñātakesu
analyzed: katipāham tattha vasitvā attanaḥ jāti bhūmiṃyā iva gataḥ dassana attham upagatesu ñātakesu
translated: stayed there for a few days, and then went to his own birthplace. When his relatives came to see him,🔽he advised them, who had performed various sacrifices and were purified by them,

original: nānāladdhike yaññasuddhike ovadanto –🔽“Ye kho te veṭhamissena, nānattena ca kammunā;
analyzed: nānāladdhike yaññasuddhike ovadantaḥ  ye kho te veṭha missena nānattena ca kammunā
translated: with the two verses:🔽“Those people who oppress others with deceit and various actions,

original: Manusse uparundhanti, pharusūpakkamā janā;
analyzed: manusse uparundhanti pharusūpakkamā janā
translated: those harsh and violent people,

original: Tepi tattheva kīranti, na hi kammaṃ panassati.
analyzed: te pi tattha iva kīranti na hi kammam panassati
translated: they too are destroyed right there; for an action does not perish.

original: “Yaṃ karoti naro kammaṃ, kalyāṇaṃ yadi pāpakaṃ;
analyzed: yam karoti naraḥ kammam kalyāṇam yadi pāpakam
translated: “Whatever action a man performs, whether good or bad,

original: Tassa tasseva dāyādo, yaṃ yaṃ kammaṃ pakubbatī”ti. – gāthādvayaṃ abhāsi;
analyzed: tassa tassa iva dāyādaḥ yam yam kammam pakubbati iti gāthā dvayam abhāsi
translated: he is the heir of all that; whatever action he performs, that he inherits.”

original: Tattha yeti aniyamuddeso. Teti aniyamato eva paṭiniddeso. Padadvayassāpi “janā”ti
analyzed: tattha yā iti aniyama uddeso tā iti aniyamataḥ eva paṭiniddeso pada dvayassa api janāti
translated: Herein, “therein” is a term of indefinite reference; “they” is the corresponding term of definite reference. Both terms are “people.”

original: iminā sambandho. Khoti nipātamattaṃ. Veṭhamissenāti varattakhaṇḍādinā sīsādīsu veṭhadānena.
analyzed: iminā sambandhaḥ kho ti nipāta mattam veṭha missena ati varatta khaṇḍa ādinā sīsa ādīsu veṭha dānena
translated: Herein, “there” is an indefinite expression. “They” is the definite expression. The two words “people” are connected by “there.” “Indeed” is merely a particle. “With violence” means by striking the head, etc., with a cudgel, a stick, etc.

original: “Vedhamissenā”tipi pāḷi, so evattho. Nānattena ca kammunāti hananaghātanahatthapādādicchedanena
analyzed: vedha missena atipi saḥ evatthaḥ nānattena ca kammunā ati hanana ghātana hattha pāda ādi chedanena
translated: The reading is also “with violence” . The meaning is the same. “With various kinds of work” means with various kinds of work of injuring others, such as killing, beating, cutting off hands and feet, etc.,

original: khuddakaseḷadānādinā ca nānāvidhena parūpaghātakammena. Manusseti nidassanamattaṃ,
analyzed: khudda kaseḷa dāna ādinā ca nānāvidhena paru paghāta kammena manussā iti nidassana mattam
translated: and giving small rations, etc. “People” is merely an illustration.

original: tasmā ye keci satteti adhippāyo. Uparundhantīti vibādhenti. Pharusūpakkamāti dāruṇapayogā,🔽kurūrakammantāti attho. Janāti sattā. Tepi tattheva kīrantīti te vuttappakārā puggalā
analyzed: tasmai ye keci sattā iti adhippāyaḥ uparundhanti iti vibādhenti dāruṇa payogā  kurūra kammantā ti atthaḥ janāti sattā te pi tattha eva kīranti iti te vutta ppakārā puggalā
translated: Therefore the intention is: “whatever beings.” “Oppress” means afflict. “With harshness” means with cruel means.🔽The meaning is: “with cruel deeds.” “People” means beings. “They too” means those persons of the aforementioned kinds.

original: yāhi kammakāraṇāhi aññe bādhiṃsu. Tattheva tāsuyeva kāraṇāsu sayampi kīranti pakkhipīyanti,
analyzed: yāhi kamma kāraṇāhi aññe bādhiṃsu tattha iva tāsu yeva kāraṇāsu sayam pi kīranti
translated: “Are oppressed” means are afflicted. “There too” means in those very causes. “They too” means they are also thrown into those very causes.

original: tathārūpaṃyeva dukkhaṃ anubhavantīti attho. “Tatheva kīrantī”ti ca pāṭho, yathā sayaṃ
analyzed: tathārūpam yeva dukkham anubhavanti iti atthaḥ tathā iva kīranti iti ca pāṭhaḥ yathā sayam
translated: the meaning is, they experience suffering of that kind.

original: aññesaṃ dukkhaṃ akaṃsu, tatheva aññehi karīyanti, dukkhaṃ pāpīyantīti attho, kasmā?🔽Na hi kammaṃ panassati kammañhi ekantaṃ upacitaṃ vipākaṃ adatvā na vigacchati, avasesapaccayasamavāye
analyzed: aññesam dukkham tathā iva aññehi karīyanti dukkham pāpīyanti iti attho kasmā  na hi kammam panassati kamman hi ekantam upacitam vipākam a datvā na vigacchati avasesa paccaya samavāye
translated: The reading “They are tormented thus” is also found. The meaning is that just as they tormented others, so they are tormented by others, they are made to experience suffering. Why?

original: vipaccatevāti adhippāyo.🔽Idāni “na hi kammaṃ panassatī”ti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vibhajitvā sattānaṃ kammassakataṃ
analyzed: vipaccatā iva ati adhippāyaḥ  idāni na hi kammam panassati iti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vibhajitvā sattānam
translated: Because the deed does not perish. The intention is that a deed does not disappear without having given its fruit, since it is accumulated as a single whole, but it ripens when the other conditions are present.

original: vibhāvetuṃ “yaṃ karotī”ti gāthaṃ abhāsi. Tassattho yaṃ kammaṃ kalyāṇaṃ kusalaṃ, yadi🔽vā pāpakaṃ akusalaṃ satto karoti, karonto ca tattha yaṃ kammaṃ yathā phaladānasamatthaṃ
analyzed: vibhāvetum yam karoti iti gātham abhāsi tassa atthaḥ yam kammam kalyāṇam kusalam yadi  vā pāpakam akusalam satto karoti karonto ca tattha yam kammam yathā phala dāna samattham
translated: Now, in order to analyze the meaning of the statement “the deed does not perish,” and in order to demonstrate the ownership of kamma to beings, he uttered the stanza, “Whatever deed he does.” Its meaning is this: Whatever deed a being does, whether it is good, that is, wholesome,🔽or bad, that is, unwholesome, and when he does it, he performs it, he accumulates it, in such a way that it becomes capable of giving its fruit,

original: hoti, tathā pakubbati upacinoti. Tassa tasseva dāyādoti tassa tasseva kammaphalassa
analyzed: hoti tathā pakubbati upacinoti tassa tassa iva dāyādo ti tassa tassa iva kamma phalassa
translated: he is the heir of that very deed. He is the heir of that very fruit of the deed.

original: gaṇhanato tena tena kammena dātabbavipākassa bhāgī hotīti attho. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: gaṇhanataḥ tena tena kammena dātabba vipākassa bhāgī hoti iti atthaḥ tena āha bhagavā
translated: the meaning is that he becomes a partaker of the ripening that should be given by that and that kamma. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “kammassakā, māṇava, sattā kammadāyādā”tiādi. Imā gāthā sutvā therassa ñātakā kammassakatāyaṃ patiṭṭhahiṃsūti.
analyzed: kammassakā māṇava sattā imā gāthā sutvā therassa ñātakā kammassaka tāyam patiṭṭhahiṃsu iti
translated: “Young man, beings are owners of their kamma, heirs of their kamma; they originate from their kamma, are bound to their kamma, have their kamma as their refuge. It is kamma that distinguishes beings as inferior and superior” . When they had heard these stanzas, the elder’s relatives were established in the ownership of kamma.

original: Jotidāsattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jotidāsa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The story of the elder Jotidāsa is ended.

original: 3. Heraññakānittheragāthāvaṇṇanā🔽Accayanti ahorattāti āyasmato heraññakānittherassa gāthā. Kā uppatti? Ayaṃ kira padumuttarassa
analyzed: accayanti ahorattā ati āyasmataḥ heraññakāni therassa gāthā kā uppatti ayam kira padumuttarassa
translated: The story of the elder Heraññakāni🔽Accayanti ahorattain, etc. These are the verses of the elder Heraññakāni. How did they originate? This elder, it seems, was reborn in a good family in the city of Haṃsavatī in the time of the Blessed One Padumuttara.

original: bhagavato kāle haṃsavatīnagare kulagehe nibbattitvā viññutaṃ patto paresaṃ bhatako🔽hutvā jīvanto ekadivasaṃ sujātassa nāma satthusāvakassa paṃsukūlaṃ pariyesantassa
analyzed: bhagavato kāle haṃsavatī nagare kula gehe nibbattitvā viññutam patto paresam bhatako  hutvā jīvantaḥ eka divasam sujātassa nāma satthu sāvakassa paṃsukūlam pariyesantassa
translated: When he had grown up and attained to manhood, he made a living by working for others.🔽One day, while he was looking for rags in a rubbish heap, he gave half a piece of cloth to a disciple of the name of Sujāta of the Teacher Padumuttara.

original: upaḍḍhadussaṃ pariccaji. So tena puññakammena tāvatiṃsesu nibbattitvā aparāparaṃ
analyzed: upaḍḍhadussam pariccaji saḥ tena puñña kammena tāvatiṃsesu nibbattitvā apara aparam
translated: By that root of merit he was reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven after dying there and here in the course of rebirths in happy destinies.

original: devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde kosalarañño gāmabhojakassa coravosāsakassa
analyzed: deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde kosala raññaḥ gāmabhojakassa cora vosāsakassa
translated: In this generation of the Buddha he was reborn in the family of a village headman who was a counsellor of the king of Kosala.

original: putto hutvā nibbatti, heraññakānītissa nāmaṃ ahosi. So vayappatto pitu accayena raññā
analyzed: puttaḥ hutvā heraññakānītissa nāmam ahosi saḥ vaya ppattaḥ pitu accayena raññā
translated: and was reborn as his son. His name was Heraññakānītissa. When he grew up, after his father’s death, he was appointed

original: tasmiṃyeva gāmabhojakaṭṭhāne ṭhapito jetavanapaṭiggahaṇe buddhānubhāvaṃ disvā paṭiladdhasaddho
analyzed: tasmin yeva gāmabhojaka ṭṭhāne ṭhapitaḥ jetavana paṭiggahaṇe buddha anubhāvam disvā paṭiladdha saddhaḥ
translated: to the same position as his father. When he saw the Buddha’s power in accepting the Jetavana Monastery, he gained faith,

original: attano kaniṭṭhassa taṃ ṭhānantaraṃ dāpetvā rājānaṃ āpucchitvā pabbajitvā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: attano kaniṭṭhassa tam ṭhāna ntaram dāpetvā rājānam āpucchitvā pabbajitvā vipassanam
translated: and after giving that position to his younger brother, he took leave of the king, went forth, and began insight meditation.

original: paṭṭhapetvā nacirasseva arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: paṭṭhapetvā nacirassa iva arahattam pāpuṇi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Before long he attained arahatship. Therefore it is said in the Apadāna:

original: “Padumuttarabhagavato, sujāto nāma sāvako;
analyzed: padumuttara bhagavataḥ sujātaḥ nāma sāvakaḥ
translated: “The disciple of the Lord Padumuttara named Sujāta

original: Paṃsukūlaṃ gavesanto, saṅkāre carate tadā.
analyzed: paṃsukūlam saṅkāre carate tadā
translated: was searching for a rag to be made into a robe and was wandering in the dust-heap.

original: “Nagare haṃsavatiyā, paresaṃ bhatako ahaṃ;
analyzed: nagare haṃsavatiyā aham
translated: “In the city of Haṃsavatī I was a servant of another,

original: Upaḍḍhadussaṃ datvāna, sirasā abhivādayiṃ.
analyzed: upaḍḍhadussam sirasā abhivādayim
translated: and after giving half a dukkaḍa, I bowed down with my head.

original: “Tena kammena sukatena, cetanāpaṇidhīhi ca;
analyzed: tena kammena su katena cetanā paṇidhīhi ca
translated: “By that good deed, by my intention and aspiration,

original: Jahitvā mānusaṃ dehaṃ, tāvatiṃsamagacchahaṃ.
analyzed: jahitvā mānusam deham tāvatiṃsam agaccha aham
translated: having abandoned the human body, I went to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: “Tettiṃsakkhattuṃ devindo, devarajjamakārayiṃ;
analyzed: tettiṃsa khattum devindaḥ deva rajjam akārayim
translated: “Thirty-three times I was Sakka, king of the gods,

original: Sattasattatikkhattuñca, cakkavattī ahosahaṃ.
analyzed: cakkavattī ahosaham
translated: and seventy-seven times I was a wheel-turning monarch.

original: “Padesarajjaṃ vipulaṃ, gaṇanāto asaṅkhiyaṃ;
analyzed: padesa rajjam vipulam gaṇanātaḥ asaṅkhiyam
translated: “I have had a vast kingdom, Incalculable in extent,

original: Upaḍḍhadussadānena, modāmi akutobhayo.
analyzed: modāmi akutobhayaḥ
translated: Through giving half a robe, I rejoice, free from fear.

original: “Icchamāno cahaṃ ajja, sakānanaṃ sapabbataṃ;
analyzed: icchamānaḥ ca ham ajja sa kānanam sa pabbatam
translated: “If I so wished, I could today Cover the whole earth with its trees and mountains

original: Khomadussehi chādeyyaṃ, aḍḍhadussassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: khoma dussehi chādeyyam phalam
translated: With robes of the finest cloth, The fruit of giving half a robe.

original: “Satasahassito kappe, yaṃ dānamadadiṃ tadā;
analyzed: kappe yam dānam adadim tadā
translated: “For a hundred thousand eons, The gift I gave then,

original: Duggatiṃ nābhijānāmi, aḍḍhadussassidaṃ phalaṃ.
analyzed: duggatim na abhijānāmi aḍḍha dussassidam phalam
translated: I do not know of any bad destination, The fruit of giving half a robe.

original: “Kilesā jhāpitā mayhaṃ…pe… kataṃ buddhassa sāsana”nti.
analyzed: kilesāḥ jhāpitāḥ mayham pe katam buddhassa sāsananti
translated: “My defilements are destroyed … The Buddha’s teaching has been done.”

original: Arahattaṃ pana patvā attano kaniṭṭhabhātaraṃ tato kammato nivattetukāmo tasmiṃyeva kamme abhirataṃ disvā taṃ codento –
analyzed: arahattam pana patvā attano kaniṭṭha bhātaram tatas kammataḥ nivattetu kāmo tasmin yeva kamme abhiratam disvā tam codento
translated: But after attaining arahatship, he wanted to turn back his younger brother from that work. Seeing that he was still engaged in that work, he reproved him,

original: “Accayanti ahorattā, jīvitaṃ uparujjhati;
analyzed: accayanti ahar rattāḥ jīvitam uparujjhati
translated: “Day and night pass away, Life comes to an end,

original: Āyu khīyati maccānaṃ, kunnadīnaṃva odakaṃ.
analyzed: āyu khīyati madcānam
translated: The life of mortals fades away Like water in a leaking pot.

original: “Atha pāpāni kammāni, karaṃ bālo na bujjhati;
analyzed: atha pāpāni kammāni karam bālaḥ na bujjhati
translated: “Then the fool who does evil deeds Does not understand,

original: Pacchāssa kaṭukaṃ hoti, vipāko hissa pāpako”ti. –
analyzed: pacchā assa kaṭukam hoti vipākaḥ hissa pāpakaḥ ti
translated: But later it becomes bitter, For its ripening is evil.”

original: Gāthādvayaṃ abhāsi.
analyzed: gāthā dvayam abhāsi
translated: He spoke this pair of stanzas.

original: Tattha accayantīti atikkamanti, lahuṃ lahuṃ apagacchantīti attho. Ahorattāti rattindivā.🔽Jīvitaṃ uparujjhatīti jīvitindriyañca khaṇikanirodhavasena nirujjhati. Vuttañhi “khaṇe
analyzed: tattha accayanti iti atikkamanti lahum lahum apagacchanti iti attho ahorattā ati  jīvitam uparujjhati iti jīvitindriyam ca khaṇika nirodha vasena nirujjhati vuttam hi khaṇe
translated: Herein, it is passing away : it is passing over, the meaning is that it is going quickly. Day and night : night and day.

original: khaṇe, tvaṃ bhikkhu, jāyasi ca jiyyasi ca miyyasi ca cavasi ca upapajjasi cā”ti.
analyzed: khaṇe tvam bhikkhu jāyasi ca jiyyasi ca miyyasi ca cavasi ca upapajjasi ca ati
translated: Life is ceasing : the life faculty is ceasing by momentary cessation. For this is said: “Bhikkhu, in every moment you are born, you age, you die, you pass away, you reappear” .

original: Āyu khīyati maccānanti maritabbasabhāvattā maccāti laddhanāmānaṃ imesaṃ sattānaṃ
analyzed: āyu khīyati maccānanti maritabba sabhāvattāḥ maccāti laddha nāmānam imesam sattānam
translated: The life of mortals fades away : mortals are so called because they are subject to death .

original: āyu “yo ciraṃ jīvati, so vassasataṃ appaṃ vā bhiyyo”ti evaṃ paricchinnakālaparamāyu
analyzed: āyu yaḥ ciram jīvati saḥ vassa satam appam vā evam paricchinna kāla parama āyu
translated: The life of these beings, which is limited by the time stated thus “One who lives long lives for a hundred years or a little more” ,🔽fades away , and it goes to destruction and dispersal. How?

original: khīyati khayañca sambhedañca gacchati, yathā kiṃ? Kunnadīnaṃva odakaṃ yathā nāma
analyzed: khīyati khayam ca sambhedam ca gacchati yathā kim yathā nāma
translated: Like water in a mountain stream : just as the water in mountain streams,

original: kunnadīnaṃ pabbateyyānaṃ khuddakanadīnaṃ udakaṃ ciraṃ na tiṭṭhati, lahutaraṃ khīyati,
analyzed: kunnadīnam pabbateyyānam khuddaka nadīnam udakam ciram na tiṭṭhati lahutaram khīyati
translated: which are mountain torrents, does not last long, but quickly fades away,

original: āgatamattaṃyeva vigacchati, evaṃ sattānaṃ āyu lahutaraṃ khīyati khayaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: vigacchati evam āyuḥ lahutaram khīyati khayam gacchati
translated: and as soon as it comes it goes, so too the life of beings fades away and goes to destruction.

original: Ettha ca udakameva “odaka”nti vuttaṃ, yathā manoyeva mānasanti.
analyzed: ettha ca udakam eva odakanti vuttam yathā
translated: And here the water itself is called “water,” just as the mind itself is called “mental.”🔽But when a fool is doing evil deeds, he does not understand.

original: Atha pāpāni kammāni, karaṃ bālo na bujjhatīti evaṃ saṃsāre aniccepi samāne bālo lobhavasena
analyzed: atha pāpāni kammāni karam bālaḥ na bujjhati iti evam saṃsāre anicce pi samāne bālaḥ lobha vasena
translated: Although samsara is impermanent, a fool,🔽through greed or hatred, does evil deeds.

original: vā kodhavasena vā pāpāni kammāni karoti, karontopi na bujjhati, pāpaṃ karonto ca
analyzed: vā kodha vasena vā pāpāni kammāni karoti karontaḥ api na bujjhati pāpam karontaḥ ca
translated: While doing them, he does not understand.🔽There is no one who does not understand that he is doing evil.

original: “pāpaṃ karomī”ti abujjhanako nāma natthi, “imassa kammassa evarūpo dukkho vipāko”ti
analyzed: pāpam karomi iti abujjhanakaḥ nāma natthi imassa kammassa evarūpaḥ dukkhaḥ vipāko ti
translated: But because he does not know that “this deed has such and such an unpleasant result,”🔽he is said not to understand.

original: pana ajānanato “na bujjhatī”ti vuttaṃ. Pacchāssa kaṭukaṃ hotīti yadipi pāpassa kammassa
analyzed: pana a jānanataḥ na bujjhati iti vuttam pacchā assa kaṭukam hoti iti yadi api pāpassa kammassa
translated: Later on it becomes bitter for him.

original: āyūhanakkhaṇe “imassa kammassa evarūpo vipāko”ti na bujjhati, tato pacchā pana nirayādīsu
analyzed: āyūhana khaṇe imassa kammassa evarūpaḥ vipāko ti na bujjhati tato pacchā pana niraya ādīsu
translated: Although at the time of accumulating evil deeds he does not understand that “this deed has such and such a result,” later on,🔽after he has been reborn in the hells, etc.,🔽that evil deed becomes bitter, unpleasant, and painful for him.

original: nibbattassa assa bālassa kaṭukaṃ aniṭṭhaṃ dukkhameva hoti. Vipāko hissa pāpako yasmā
analyzed: nibbattassa assa bālassa kaṭukam aniṭṭham dukkham eva hoti vipākaḥ hissa pāpakaḥ yasmā
translated: Because the result of that evil deed is evil.

original: assa pāpakammassa nāma vipāko pāpako nihīno aniṭṭho evāti. Imaṃ pana ovādaṃ sutvā
analyzed: assa pāpa kammassa nāma vipākaḥ pāpakaḥ nihīnaḥ aniṭṭhaḥ eva ati imam pana ovādam sutvā
translated: Having heard this advice,

original: therassa kaniṭṭhabhātā rājānaṃ āpucchitvā pabbajitvā nacirasseva sadatthaṃ nipphādesi.
analyzed: therassa kaniṭṭha bhātā rājānam āpucchitvā pabbajitvā nacirassa iva sadattham nipphādesi
translated: The Elder’s younger brother, after taking leave of the king, went forth into homelessness and in no long time reached Arahantship.

original: Heraññakānittheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: heraññakānitthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Heraññakānittha is finished.

original: 4. Somamittattheragāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: somamitta thera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Elder Somamitta’s Verses

analyzed: nibbattitvā soma mittaḥ iti laddha nāmaḥ tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū hutvā vimalena nāma therena

analyzed: pahāya mahākassapa theram upasaṅkamitvā tassa ovāde ṭhatvā vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā
translated: He left the Elder Vimalatissa and approached the Elder Maha Kassapa. He lived in accordance with the Elder Maha Kassapa’s advice, and he began insight meditation.

analyzed: nacirassa iva arahatte patiṭṭhāsi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: Before long he reached Arahantship. Therefore it is said:🔽“Seeing a flowering Kiṃsuka tree,

analyzed: kiṃsukam pupphitam disvā paggahetvāna añjalim
translated: I raised my joined palms in reverence;🔽Remembering the Buddha, the Best of Men,

original: “Assamā abhinikkhamma, pavanaṃ agamāsahaṃ;

analyzed: tatthaddasāsim sambuddham piya dassim mahā āyasam

original: Sunisinnaṃ samāpannaṃ, virocantaṃ mahāvane.
analyzed: su nisinnam samāpannam virocantam mahā vane

original: “Catudaṇḍe ṭhapetvāna, buddhassa uparī ahaṃ;
analyzed: catu daṇḍe buddhassa aham
translated: “Having placed four sticks (around him), above the Buddha,

analyzed: maṇḍapam su katam katvā sāla pupphehi chādayim

analyzed: sattāham maṇḍapam sāla chāditam
translated: “Having held the pavilion covered with Sāla flowers for seven days,

analyzed: tattha cittam pasādetvā buddha seṭṭham avandaham

original: “Bhagavā tamhi samaye, vuṭṭhahitvā samādhito;
analyzed: bhagavā tamhi samaye vuṭṭhahitvā samādhito
translated: “The Fortunate One, at that time, having arisen from concentration,

original: “Sāvako varuṇo nāma, piyadassissa satthuno;
analyzed: sāvakaḥ varuṇaḥ nāma piya dassissa satthunaḥ
translated: “A disciple named Varuna, of the Teacher Piyadassin,

original: Vasīsatasahassehi, upagacchi vināyakaṃ.
analyzed: vasī sata sahassehi upagacchi vināyakam

original: “Piyadassī ca bhagavā, lokajeṭṭho narāsabho;
analyzed: piya dassī ca bhagavā loka jeṭṭhaḥ narāsabhaḥ
translated: “And the Fortunate One, Piyadassin, the world’s chief, the best of men,

analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghe nisīditvāna sitam pātukarī jino
translated: Having sat down in the midst of the Community of monks, the Victor made a smile appear.

translated: “Anuruddha was the attendant of Piyadassin, the Teacher.

analyzed: eka aṃsam cīvaram katvā apucchittha mahā munim
translated: He put his robe over one shoulder and asked the Great Sage:

analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhagavā hetu sita kammassa satthuno

original: “Anokāsaṃ na passāmi, yattha puññaṃ vipaccati;
analyzed: anokāsam na passāmi yattha puññam vipaccati
translated: “‘I do not see the place where merit ripens,

translated: “‘While dwelling in the world of the gods, endowed with meritorious deeds,

analyzed: yāvatā parisā tassa sāla channā bhavissati  tattha dibbehi naccehi gītehi vāditehi ca

original: Ramissati sadā santo, puññakammasamāhito.

analyzed: yāvatā parisā tassa gandha gandhī bhavissati
translated: “‘As long as his assembly will be fragrant with perfume,

analyzed: sālassa puppha vassaḥ ca pavassissati tāvade
translated: for that long a rain of sala flowers will fall.

original: “Tato cutoyaṃ manujo, mānusaṃ āgamissati;
analyzed: tatas cutas yam manujaḥ mānusam āgamissati
translated: “‘When he passes away from there, he will return to the human state.

analyzed: idha api sālacchadanam sabbakālam dharissati

translated: “Here, with dancing and singing, with music and merrymaking,

analyzed: citake jhāyamānassa chadanam tattha hessati

analyzed: so arahattam pana patvā visesataḥ lābha gga yasagga ppattaḥ ahosi tattha keci puthujjana bhikkhū  therassa lābha sakkāram disvā bāla bhāvena asahanā ākāram theraḥ tam ñatvā

translated: Clothes and bedding.

analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā sakkāresu mahat bhayam
translated: “Knowing this danger, the great fear in honour,

analyzed: lābhī hoti saḥ upi bahū sapatte labhati tassa usūyantāḥ bahū sambhavanti tasmai etam
translated: he will get many enemies, and many will be hostile to him. Therefore,

analyzed: evarūpam lābha sakkāresu mahat bhayam vipula bhayam ādīnavam dosam viditvā

analyzed: santosam ca hadaye ṭhapetvā anavajja uppādassa api uppannassa lābhassa parivajjanena appa lābhaḥ
translated: the monk should wander about, not greedy, avoiding even the arising of the slight gain that might arise,

analyzed: vā bhikkhu santuṭṭhi ṭhānīyassa sati sampajaññassa vasena sataḥ hutvā paribbaje careyya

analyzed: vihareyya ati tam sutvā te bhikkhū tāvat eva theram khamāpesuṃ
translated: When they had heard that, they asked the Elder for forgiveness there and then.

analyzed: tissa thera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  kimilatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Verses of the Elder Tissa is finished.🔽The Verses of the Elder Kimbila

analyzed: ā yasmataḥ kimila ttherassa gāthā kā uppatti tassa pubba yogo
translated: The Elder Kimbila’s verses beginning with “In the Eastern Bamboo Park” . What is the origin of these verses? His previous aspiration,

original: saṃveguppatti pabbajjā ca ekakanipāte “abhisatto”ti gāthāya saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttāyeva.🔽Tāya ca gāthāya therena attano visesādhigamassa kāraṇaṃ dassitaṃ. Idha pana adhigatavisesassa
analyzed: saṃvega uppatti pabbajjā ca ekaka nipāte abhisatto ti gāthāya saṃvaṇṇanāyam vuttāya eva  tāya ca gāthāya therena attanaḥ visesa adhigamassa kāraṇam dassitam idha pana adhigata visesassa
translated: his arousal of the thought of the loathsomeness of the round of rebirths, and his going forth are all told in the commentary to the verse “Abhisatto” in the Ones .🔽And the reason for his own special attainment is given by the Elder in that verse. But here his living in concord with the venerable Anuruddha and the venerable Nandiya

original: attano āyasmatā ca anuruddhena āyasmatā ca nandiyena saha samaggavāso dassitoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: attano āyasmatā ca anuruddhena āyasmatā ca nandiyena saha samagga vāsaḥ dassito ti veditabbam
translated: should be understood as shown.

original: Samaggavāsaṃ pana vasantā te yathā ca vasiṃsu, taṃ dassento –
analyzed: samagga vāsam pana vasantā te yathā ca vasiṃsu tam dassentaḥ
translated: But living together in concord, they lived as follows. Showing how they lived, he uttered the two stanzas:🔽In the Eastern Bamboo Park,

original: “Pācīnavaṃsadāyamhi, sakyaputtā sahāyakā;
analyzed: pācīnavaṃsadāyamhi sakya puttā sahāyakā
translated: The Sakyan sons, friends,🔽Renouncing wealth, few their wants,

original: Pahāyānappake bhoge, uñche pattāgate ratā.
analyzed: pahāya anappake bhoge uñche patta āgate ratā
translated: Delighting in what comes unsought.🔽Vigorous, intent,

analyzed: āraddha vīriyā pahita ttā niccam daḷha parakkamā
translated: Always with firm resolve,🔽They rejoiced in the joy of Dhamma,

original: Ramanti dhammaratiyā, hitvāna lokiyaṃ rati”nti. – gāthādvayaṃ abhāsi;🔽Tattha pācīnavaṃsadāyamhīti pācīnavaṃsanāmake rakkhitagopite sahaparicchede vane.
analyzed: ramanti dhamma ratiyā lokiyam gāthā dvayam abhāsi  tattha pācīnavaṃsa dāyamhi iti pācīnavaṃsa nāmake rakkhita gopite saha paricchede vane
translated: Having renounced the world’s delight.🔽Herein, in the Eastern Bamboo Park means in the Eastern Bamboo Park, a protected and guarded enclosure in a forest.

original: Tañhi vanaṃ gāmassa pācīnadisāyaṃ ṭhitattā vaṃsagumbaparikkhittattā ca “pācīnavaṃsadāyo”ti🔽vutto, vaṃsavanabhāvena vāti. Sakyaputtāti anuruddhattherādayo sakyarājakumārā. Sahāyakāti
analyzed: tat hi vanam gāmassa pācīna disāyam ṭhita ttā vaṃsa gumba parikkhitta ttā ca pācīna vaṃsa dāyā ti  vuttaḥ vaṃsa vana bhāvena vā ati sakya puttā ati anuruddhatthera ādayaḥ sakya rāja kumārā sahāyakā ati
translated: For that park was called “Eastern Bamboo Park” because it was situated in the eastern direction from the village and because it was surrounded by bamboo clumps.

analyzed: saṃvega uppatti pabbajja asamaṇa dhamma karaṇa saṃvāsehi saha ayanataḥ pavattanataḥ sahāyakā
translated: The Sakyan sons means the Elder Anuruddha and the other Sakyan princes. Friends means they were friends because they were companions in the arousing of spiritual anxiety, in going forth, in the life of a recluse, and in the practice of the Dhamma.

analyzed: pahāya anappake bhoge ti uḷārena puñña anubhāvena adhigate kula paramparā gate ca mahante
translated: Renouncing wealth, few their wants means they renounced great wealth acquired by the great power of their merit and inherited from their family line.

original: bhogakkhandhe chaḍḍetvā. “Sahāyānappake”tipi pāḷi. Uñche pattāgate ratāti uñchācariyāya🔽ābhatattā uñche patte āgatattā pattāgate pattapariyāpanne ratā abhiratā, saṅghabhattādiatirekalābhaṃ
analyzed: bhogakkhandhe chaḍḍetvā uñche patta āgate uñcha ācariyāya  uñche patte āgatattā patta āgate patta pariyāpanne ratā abhiratā saṅgha bhatta ādi atireka lābham
translated: and having abandoned the mass of possessions. The reading is also “having few friends.”🔽They delight in almsfood that has come to the bowl: they delight in, enjoy, the almsfood that has come to the bowl, that has arrived in the bowl, that is included in the bowl, because it has been obtained by the practice of wandering for alms;

original: paṭikkhipitvā jaṅghabalaṃ nissāya bhikkhācariyāya laddhena missakabhatteneva santuṭṭhāti attho.
analyzed: paṭikkhipitvā jaṅgha balam nissāya bhikkhā cariyāya laddhena missaka bhattena iva santuṭṭhā ati attho
translated: the meaning is, they are satisfied with just the mixed almsfood obtained by the practice of wandering for alms, depending on the strength of their legs, having rejected the extra gains such as the invitation-day meal, etc.

original: Āraddhavīriyāti uttamatthassa adhigamāya āditova pageva sampāditavīriyā. Pahitattāti
analyzed: āraddha vīriyā ti uttama atthassa adhigamāya āditas iva pagā iva sampādita vīriyā pahita ttā ti

original: pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṃ sakkharappabhedānaṃ itihāsapañcamānaṃ padako veyyākaraṇo🔽lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayo nekkhammajjhāsayatāya kāme pahāya tāpasapabbajjaṃ

translated: When the Bodhisatta was born, the king gave him the name Sirivaḍḍha, and when the child was old enough to be presented at court, the king presented him to the queen.🔽The queen, beholding the child, said, “This child is my good fortune ; therefore his name shall be Sirima.”🔽And so the child was called Sirima.🔽When the child was old enough to be presented at court, the king presented him to the queen.🔽The queen, beholding the child, said, “This child is my good fortune ; therefore his name shall be Sirima.”🔽And so the child was called Sirima.

original: pabbajitvā caturāsītisahassaparimāṇena tāpasagaṇena parivuto himavantappadese devatābhinimmite🔽assame jhānābhiññāyo nibbattetvā vasanto purimabuddhesu katādhikāratāya lakkhaṇamantesu
analyzed: pabbajitvā caturāsīti sahassa parimāṇena tāpasa gaṇena parivutaḥ himavanta ppadese devatā abhinimmite  assame jhāna abhiññāyaḥ nibbattetvā vasanto purima buddhesu kata adhikāra tāya lakkhaṇam antesu
translated: and after he had gone forth, he dwelt in a hermitage in the Himalayas, which had been created by the gods, surrounded by an assembly of ascetics numbering eighty-four thousand.🔽After he had developed the meditations and the super-knowledges, he remembered the special qualities of the Buddhas, because he had rendered service to the Buddhas of the past, and because the special qualities of the Buddhas had been included in the Characteristics of the Great Man.

translated: And he made a shrine on the bank of a river, in honour of the Buddhas of the past,

original: pulinacetiyaṃ katvā pūjāsakkārābhirato ahosi. Taṃ disvā tāpasā, “kaṃ uddissa ayaṃ🔽pūjāsakkāro karīyatī”ti pucchiṃsu. So tesaṃ lakkhaṇamante āharitvā tattha āgatāni
analyzed: pulina cetiyam katvā pūjā sakkāra abhirataḥ ahosi tam disvā tāpasā kam uddissa ayaṃ  pūjā sakkāro karīyati iti pucchiṃsu saḥ tesam lakkhaṇa mante āharitvā tattha āgatāni
translated: and he was devoted to the worship and honouring of it. original: mahāpurisalakkhaṇāni vibhajitvā tadanusārena attano bale ṭhatvā buddhaguṇe kittesi.
analyzed: mahāpurisa lakkhaṇāni vibhajitvā tad anusārena attanaḥ bale ṭhatvā buddha guṇe kittesi

original: Taṃ sutvā tepi tāpasā pasannamānasā tato paṭṭhāya sammāsambuddhaṃ uddissa thūpapūjaṃ karontā viharanti.
analyzed: tam sutvā te api tāpasā pasanna mānasā tatas paṭṭhāya sammāsambuddham uddissa thūpa pūjam karontā viharanti
translated: And when the ascetics heard him, they were pleased, and from that time on they lived worshipping the shrine in honour of the Supremely Enlightened.

original: Tena ca samayena padumuttarabodhisatto tusitakāyā cavitvā mātukucchiṃ okkanto hoti.

translated: and worship the shrine at Pulatthinagara. Be devoted to meditation.” And he returned to the Brahma-world.

original: Evaṃ so devamanussesu saṃsaranto imasmiṃ buddhuppāde sāvatthiyaṃ gahapatikule nibbatti,
analyzed: evam saḥ deva manussesu saṃsarantaḥ imasmin buddhuppāde sāvatthiyam gahapati kule nibbatti
translated: Thus he passed through the worlds of gods and men, and in this dispensation he was reborn in a merchant’s family at Sāvatthi.

analyzed: tassa jāta divasataḥ paṭṭhāya tasmin kule siri sampattiyā vaḍḍha mānattā

analyzed: nāmam tassa padasā gamana kāle kaniṭṭha bhātā nibbatti tassa ayam sirim vaḍḍhento

analyzed: disvā paṭiladdha saddhā pabbajiṃsu tesu sirivaḍḍhaḥ na tāva uttari manussa dhammassa

analyzed: lābhī ahosi catunnam paccayānam lābhī gaha ṭṭha pabbajitānam sakkataḥ garukataḥ sirima thero

analyzed: pana pabbajita kālato paṭṭhāya tādisena kamma chiddena appa lābhī ahosi bahu jana asambhāvito
translated: from the time of his going forth, was a recipient of little alms, but was honoured by the multitude,

original: samathavipassanāsu kammaṃ karonto nacirasseva chaḷabhiñño ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ apadāne –
analyzed: samatha vipassanāsu kammam karontaḥ nacirassa iva chaḍḍa abhiññaḥ ahosi tena vuttam apadāne
translated: and he, doing his work in serenity and insight, in no long time became one possessing the six deep knowledges. Therefore it is said in the Apadana:

original: “Pabbate himavantamhi, devalo nāma tāpaso;
analyzed: pabbate himavantamhi devalaḥ nāma tāpaso
translated: “On the Himalayas, the mountain, a devotee named Devala;

original: Tattha me caṅkamo āsi, amanussehi māpito.
analyzed: tattha me caṅkamaḥ āsi amanussehi māpitaḥ
translated: There was my place of meditation, honoured by non-human beings.

original: “Jaṭābhārena bharito, kamaṇḍaludharo sadā;
analyzed: jaṭā bhārena bharitaḥ kamaṇḍalu dharaḥ sadā

original: Uttamatthaṃ gavesanto, vipinā nikkhamiṃ tadā.
analyzed: uttamattham gavesantaḥ vipinā nikkhamim tadā
translated: Seeking the highest good, then I went forth into the homeless state.

original: “Cullāsītisahassāni, sissā mayhaṃ upaṭṭhahuṃ;
analyzed: culla asīti sahassāni sissā mayham
translated: “Eighty-four thousand disciples attended upon me,

original: Sakakammābhipasutā, vasanti vipine tadā.
analyzed: vasanti vipine tadā
translated: and they lived in the forest, devoted to their own duties.

original: “Assamā abhinikkhamma, akaṃ pulinacetiyaṃ;
analyzed: assamā abhinikkhamma akam pulina cetiyam
translated: “Having left the hermitage, I made a shrine of sand,

original: Nānāpupphaṃ samānetvā, taṃ cetiyamapūjayiṃ.
analyzed: nānā puppham samānetvā tam cetiyam apūjayim
translated: and having gathered various flowers, I worshipped that shrine.

original: “Tattha cittaṃ pasādetvā, assamaṃ pavisāmahaṃ;
analyzed: tattha cittam pasādetvā assamam pavisāmaham
translated: “Having gladdened my heart there, I entered the hermitage,

original: Sabbe sissā samāgantvā, etamatthaṃ pucchiṃsu maṃ.
analyzed: sabbe sissā samāgantvā etam attham pucchiṃsu mama
translated: and all the disciples gathered together and asked me this question:

original: “Pulinena kato thūpo, yaṃ tvaṃ deva namassasi;
analyzed: pulinena kataḥ thūpaḥ yam tvam deva namassasi
translated: “‘The shrine that you worship, O god, is made of sand.

original: Mayampi ñātumicchāma, puṭṭho ācikkha no tuvaṃ.
analyzed: mayam pi ñātum icchāma puṭṭhaḥ ācikkha no tuvam
translated: We also wish to know. Tell us when asked.’

original: “Niddiṭṭhā nu mantapade, cakkhumanto mahāyasā;
analyzed: niddiṭṭhāḥ nu manta pade cakkhumantaḥ mahā ayasā
translated: “Have they been pointed out in the words of the elders, the all-seeing ones of great fame?

original: Te kho ahaṃ namassāmi, buddhaseṭṭhe mahāyase.
analyzed: te kho aham namassāmi buddha seṭṭhe mahāyase
translated: I pay homage to them, to the best of the Buddhas, the great seers.

original: “Kīdisā te mahāvīrā, sabbaññū lokanāyakā;
analyzed: kīdisā te mahāvīrā sabbaññū loka nāyakā
translated: “What are those great heroes like, the all-knowing leaders of the world?

original: Kathaṃvaṇṇā kathaṃsīlā, kīdisā te mahāyasā.
analyzed: kathaṃvaṇṇā kathaṃsīlā kīdisā te mahā āyasā
translated: What are their complexion and virtue like? What are they like, those of great fame?

original: “Bāttiṃsalakkhaṇā buddhā, cattālīsadijāpi ca;
analyzed: bāttiṃsa lakkhaṇā buddhā cattālīsa dijā api ca
translated: “The Buddhas have thirty-two marks, and their births are of forty kinds.

original: Nettā gopakhumā tesaṃ, jiñjukā phalasannibhā.
analyzed: nettā gopa khumā tesam jiñjukā phala sannibhā
translated: Their eyes are like the eyes of an ox or a peacock, and their pupils are like the color of a jujube fruit.

original: “Gacchamānā ca te buddhā, yugamattañca pekkhare;
analyzed: gacchamānā ca te buddhāḥ pekkhare
translated: “When walking, those Buddhas look a plough’s length ahead,

original: Na tesaṃ jāṇu nadati, sandhisaddo na suyyati.
analyzed: na tesam jāṇu nadati sandhi saddaḥ na suyyati
translated: Their knees do not creak, nor is there a sound in their joints.

original: “Gacchamānā ca sugatā, uddharantāva gacchare;
analyzed: gacchamānā ca sugatā uddharantā ava gacchare
translated: When walking, the Well-Farers lift up their feet,

original: Paṭhamaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ pādaṃ, buddhānaṃ esa dhammatā.
analyzed: paṭhamam dakkhiṇam pādam buddhānam esa dhamma tā
translated: and the right foot first: this is the nature of the Buddhas.

original: “Asambhītā ca te buddhā, migarājāva kesarī;
analyzed: a sambhītā ca te buddhāḥ miga rājā ava kesarī
translated: Those Buddhas are fearless, like a lion, king of beasts;

original: Nevukkaṃsenti attānaṃ, no ca vambhenti pāṇinaṃ.
analyzed: na iva ukkaṃsenti attānam na u ca vambhenti pāṇinam
translated: they do not advertise themselves, nor do they despise others.

original: “Mānāvamānato muttā, samā sabbesu pāṇisu;
analyzed: māna avamānataḥ muttā samā sabbesu pāṇisu
translated: Free from pride and contempt, they are impartial to all beings.

original: Anattukkaṃsakā buddhā, buddhānaṃ esa dhammatā.
analyzed: anattukkaṃsakāḥ buddhāḥ buddhānam esa dhamma tā
translated: The Buddhas do not praise themselves: this is the nature of the Buddhas.

original: “Uppajjantā ca sambuddhā, ālokaṃ dassayanti te;
analyzed: uppajjantā ca sambuddhāḥ ālokam dassayanti te
translated: When the Fully Enlightened Ones arise, they show light;

original: Chappakāraṃ pakampenti, kevalaṃ vasudhaṃ imaṃ.

analyzed: phala samādhinā upacāra ppanā samādhi mattena iva vā na samāhitaḥ samādhānassa paṭipakkha bhūtānam  kilesānaṃ appahīna ttā vikkhittaḥ vibbhanta cittaḥ hoti ca iti atthaḥ asamāhitaḥ ti ca  etena samādhi nimittānam guṇānam abhāvam dasseti mogham ti bhāva napuṃsaka niddesaḥ visamam
translated: if he is not composed by the path-concentration, the fruition-concentration, or the concentration of access and absorption, then he is distracted, his mind is scattered,🔽because he has not abandoned the defilements which are the opposites of concentration.🔽By “uncomposed” he shows the absence of the benefits of the signs of concentration. “In vain” is a neuter noun, like “in vain the moon and sun revolve irregularly” .

Sesaṃ paṭhamagāthāya
analyzed: dutiya gāthāyam garahanti iti attanaḥ a vidda su bhāvena dosantarāya vā ariyam  samānam asukaḥ bhikkhu jāgariyam na anuyuñjati antamasaḥ go duhana mattam pi kālam kevalam  kāya daḷhi bahulaḥ niddārāmaḥ bhassa ārāmaḥ saṅgaṇikārāmaḥ viharati iti ādinā appaṭipajjamāna tā vibhāvanena  vā guṇa paridhaṃsanena vā garahanti nindanti upakkosanti vā ati attho sesam paṭhama gāthāya
translated: In the second stanza, they are “censorious” because of their own lack of understanding, or because of envy of the noble one’s attainment of jhāna and direct knowledge.🔽They “censor” him by pointing out his lack of practice, saying, “So-and-so does not practice the life of wakening, not even for the time it takes to milk a cow. He is full of bodily strength, delights in sleep, delights in talk, delights in company,” and so on.🔽Or they “censor” him by disparaging his qualities. The meaning is that they “reproach” him, “blame” him, and “criticize” him.

original: vuttapariyāyena veditabbaṃ. Evaṃ therena imāhi gāthāhi attano nikkilesabhāve sirivaḍḍhassa🔽ca sakilesabhāve pakāsite taṃ sutvā sirivaḍḍho saṃvegajāto vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā🔽nacirasseva sadatthaṃ paripūresi, garahakapuggalā ca theraṃ khamāpesuṃ.🔽Sirimattheragāthāvaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vutta pariyāyena veditabbam evam therena imāhi gāthāhi attanaḥ nikkilesa bhāve sirivaḍḍhassa  ca sa kilesa bhāve pakāsite tam sutvā sirivaḍḍhaḥ saṃvega jātaḥ vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā  nacirassa iva sadattham paripūresi garahaka puggalā ca theram khamāpesuṃ  sirimatthera gāthā vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: In the second stanza, they “blame” him, either by their own lack of understanding or by way of their own hatred, and they “blame” him, that is, they censure and revile him, saying, “This bhikkhu does not practice the life of wakening, not even for the time it takes to milk a cow, he is full of bodily strength, he delights in sleep, he delights in talk, he delights in company,” and so on, by showing how he does not practice, or by disparaging his virtues. The rest is as stated in the first stanza. When the elder had thus shown his own sinlessness and Sirivaḍḍha’s sinfulness by means of these stanzas, Sirivaḍḍha, having heard them, became remorseful and undertook insight, and in no long time he fulfilled his own good. And the people who had blamed the elder asked his forgiveness. The commentary on the verses of the elder Sirimata is ended. The commentary on the second chapter is ended.

translated: “Bound by meritorious deeds, I was reborn in Tusita Heaven;

translated: My body fell away, and I rejoiced in the world of the gods.

original: “Chaḷasītisahassāni, nāriyo samalaṅkatā;
analyzed: chaḷasīti sahassāni nāriyaḥ samalaṅkatā
translated: “Sixty-four thousand women, all adorned with ornaments,

translated: “Having come to the human state, I was happy then.

analyzed: bhoge me ūna tā natthi bhisa dānassa idam phalam
translated: I had no lack of wealth. This is the fruit of giving medicine.

original: “Anukampitako tena, devadevena tādinā;
analyzed: tena devadevena tādinā
translated: “I was favored by that god of gods, the Worthy One,
